                         MEETING ANNOUNCEMENT

                    The Portland Linux/Unix Group
                              will meet
                      7 PM Thursday May 1, 2003
                                  at
                      Portland State University
                                in the
                        Smith Memorial Center
                               Room 298
                       On the block bounded by
   SW Montgomery, SW Broadway (7th), SW Harrison, and SW Park (9th)


      **********************************************************

                             PRESENTATION

                         The Open Source Bill

                                  by
                              Ken Barber
                        <pundit at teleport.com>

      House Bill 2892, the Open Source Bill, is a bill in the
      Oregon State House of Representatives to encourage government
      agencies to examine Open Source solutions to their needs
      before purchasing proprietary software.  It also promotes
      the use of open data formats.  Ken Barber who wrote House
      Bill 2892 will be in Portland to discuss this bill, and the
      role of Open Source software in government.

      **********************************************************

          Agenda:

              7:00 - 7:30  Business
                   We will discuss the status of our ongoing projects
                   including the monthly hands on clinics, PLUG for
                   Education, etc.

              7:30 - 8:30  Presentation

                   See above

              9:00 - ...  Beer
                                  The Lucky Labrador Brewing Company
                                  915 SE Hawthorne

From michael at robinson-west.com  Thu May  1 03:23:01 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Thu May  1 03:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Starband blues...
Message-ID: <20030501101724.7523.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

I really hate winproxy and starbands anti Linux anti Mac focus.

A company I'm trying to help, Micron Laser off wagon way near 26 and 
Cornelius, wants to run rsync to update a directory on two 2000 servers
that are supposed to have the same data.  If this data is wrong it could cost
Micron thousands of dollars as they do laser work on printed circuit boards
under contract and have to eat their mistakes.  The datum are Lumonics etc.
files that the machines actually run.  Merix is letting the shop play with one
of their machines for free and has provided real time drivers for Linux where
my brother has put together a debian machine and ported these drivers to 
the 2.4 kernel.  Great, right?!?  Almost, the stupid
Starband 360 satellite modem and winproxy aren't Linux friendly :-\  

I've been plugging away at google, but any link to how to make starband 360 
work under Linux seems broken and I haven't been able to find any information 
on any other two way satellite alternative that actually routes properly.
Also, I doubt there's any way for Micron to sell the Starband 360 to switch
to another satellite.  I have found sites that say efforts to get the 
information to do the compression that is needed for writing starband 360 
Linux drivers have failed.  A number of other sites say that there is 
no chance this is going to change.  There's some word that wine may 
get starband to work on a Linux router, but I don't know if this would allow 
substituting say netfilter with masquerading for winproxy.  I wonder if dns 
requests and rsync can go out on a starband 360 satellite or if that is 
impossible.

Is there any way to get dselect, wget, ftp, anything other than opera with
proxy set to work through starband 360?

My brother thinks cygwin is the answer, but I really doubt it.  I don't like 
the idea of having to come up with a custom proxy program on Windows
2000 to catch the dns, ftp, http, etc. queries of Linux machines that are
not expecting a proxy.  Linux wants dns and that seems broken with
winproxy.

Why is starband forcing or trying to force businesses and others to stick
with Windows?  What is the danger of their compression algorithm being
available to the general public so that someone can write a Linux driver?
Couldn't they have placed the compression in the modem and made the
starband 360 an ordinary router friendly to any machine that speaks 
tcp/ip?  Processors are so cheap these days.

Are there any Linux friendly two way satellite alternatives covering the
area where Cornelius Pass and Highway 26 meet?

     --  Michael

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu May  1 08:55:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu May  1 08:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Starband blues...

On Thu, 1 May 2003, Michael Robinson michael-at-robinson-west.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I really hate winproxy and starbands anti Linux anti Mac focus.
> 
> A company I'm trying to help, Micron Laser off wagon way near 26 and 
> Cornelius, wants to run rsync to update a directory on two 2000 servers
> that are supposed to have the same data.  If this data is wrong it could cost
> Micron thousands of dollars as they do laser work on printed circuit boards
> under contract and have to eat their mistakes.

... trimmed ...

Since Starband requires that Windows software be installed and you're
syncing the Windows systems it makes sense to use rsync on the Windows
systems themselves:

http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=rsync+for+windows

If you want to find a new ISP (sounds like you may want to anyhow), then
the site http://www.dslreports.com often has good info, such as:

http://www.dslreports.com/forum/remark,6493543~root=sat~mode=flat

This guy is running a Linux-based appliance through StarBand using a WinXP
system as a router:

http://www.dslreports.com/forum/remark,6316973~root=sat~mode=flat

He does not give enough details to duplicate the config, but says:

"We recently got our StarBand system up and running. We are running Sat
Modem --- stripped down XP pro ICS box w/ remote management --- Toshiba
SG20 server --- LAN. All are connected in a linear fashion and in that
order."

The big competition to StarBand seems to be Direcway.  The biggest gripe
about them is that they reduce your bandwidth if you use it too much in a
short timeframe.  (The Fair Access Policy)  Since it sounds like you plan
to send a reasonable amount of data across, this probably would not work
well for you.

  -- Steve

From michael at robinson-west.com  Thu May  1 16:47:01 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Thu May  1 16:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Starband blues...
In-Reply-To: <14344-73320@sneakemail.com>

Ok, what is ICS under Windows 2000 Server and if Winproxy is removed what
steps need to be taken to protect the 2000 server and allow a Linux router 
behind it to do routing and packet filtering?

    I am looking at the following setup:

laser machines on             90.0.0.0/24 network

laser machines on             91.0.0.0/24 network

personal computers on     92.0.0.0/24 network

laser machines on             93.0.0.0/24 network
     . 
     .
     .

there  could be another but it this is good enough...

Current Windows 2000 server gateway with 5 nics where one goes to satellite
box and the others connect to each of the above networks.

There could be a Merix key on the current winproxy server that Merix needs
to access for the laser machines to work.  I believe this 2000 server can 
serve the Merix key and close all other services  that aren't initiated from
inside the shop.  Mail is through imap or pop3 from satellite provider and 
needs to be virus filtered before it is picked up by any of the personal 
computers.  The Merix key plugs in to the parallel port where other than it 
the winproxy machine is the closest the business can get to the equivalent 
of having a network bridge.  Trouble is that it isn't working as a proper 
bridge right now where the transparent proxy feature is broken,  otherwise 
Linux would be able to go out.  On google, tech tips has a suggestion to use
ICS and stay away from winproxy because it isn't supported by Starband
or Microsoft.

I think a standard forwarding Linux router is needed behind Windows ICS 
server and that this router should host all the private networks that winproxy
currently should, but can't.  Winproxy would be removed.  Would a Linux 
router use masquerading or not?  If not, where can I get info on writing 
forwarding rules under iptables to go from say network A to network B?
DNS requests say on net A need to be on net B, ICS network, where the 
windows gateway will move it on to the Internet from there.  Net B is
different than what I have already worked with because it is another
private network where I have only ever done a router that goes from 
private to public.

As far as rsync on Windows, good tip.  I should point out that the 2000
server that hosts this directory is on a private subnet right now and because
ftp doesn't work through winproxy the shop has been using 56k dialup and 
pc anywhere.  The latter is what my brother and I have been asked to
fix first.  He's trying to write a proxy today thinking he can enable routing 
of dns and ftp through an application layer socket.  I'd like to find a 
solution that doesn't involve writing Windows software as results 
can't be predicted and making a mess would not be good.  The job 
is to prevent a thirty thousand dollar loss as unintrusively as possible.

<gripe>
Maybe a bill should be passed that bans software modems for which no 
information is made available to competitors of the system the software is 
written for.  Considering that this satellite company has a monopoly on two
way satellite technology that even comes close to what DSL is, this
win modem abuse is not a trivial problem.  You can't even use this 
satellite on a Mac directly where they could have distributed a binary.
Unfortunately, the cost of sending a satellite into orbit and the limited
real estate in space is partially to blame for this abusive situation as
the latter high costs prevent competition.  Not to mention, I think Microsoft
is responsible for placing anticompetitive pressure on Starband.  Another
right I think that neds to be protected is the right to not register
a hardware or software product even if it is commercial and proprietary
because of all the junk email/mail problems and the intrusiveness of that.
If I'm not mistaken, XP breaks when you can't query an internet registration
database and Microsoft audits whatever they want whenever they want. 
It's legal to run Linux, but what can stop Microsoft from breaking their
own operating systems remotely because they want Linux users to 
have problems that will lead them to Windows for everything?
What prevents blackmail, "it's either our system or no system"?
<\gripe>

NOTE:  ICS is the Microsoft Internet Connection Sharing software.

If there is a routable broadband alternative, broadband without Windows,
I can suggest it.  I doubt there is though, but it is the case that houses 
are coming closer and I have seen the comcast van near this area from 
when I was going to Rock Creek this Winter.  Can the starband 360 
satellite be sold or traded for a comcast cable modem?  It limits my
ability to do progamming for this shop if this Internet connectivity is
broken and I need the money.  I earned my general studies degree

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu May  1 17:12:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu May  1 17:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Starband blues...
In-Reply-To: <20030501234211.8446.qmail@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Thu, 1 May 2003, Michael Robinson michael-at-robinson-west.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

Michael:

Lots of your questions are good, valid questions-- but it sounds like if
you choose to go with a Windows-system-as-NAT-router config you're going
to need more help than a mailing list can provide.  Find someone you know
or can hire to help out with your very complex network design should you
decide this is the way to go.

> As far as rsync on Windows, good tip.  I should point out that the
> 2000 server that hosts this directory is on a private subnet right now
> and because ftp doesn't work through winproxy the shop has been using
> 56k dialup and pc anywhere.  The latter is what my brother and I have
> been asked to fix first.

Try to get SSH working.  Once that is going you can tunnel both VNC (for
PCAnywhere-like functions) and rsync (for file transfer) over the same SSH
transport layer.

As much as you might want to avoid Cygwin, in this case it is likely to
make your life very easy.  Cygwin now comes with a working ssh/sshd
package, but I don't think it's part of the default install. 
(http://cygwin.com/packages/)

For info on getting VNC to work over SSH see:

http://www.uk.research.att.com/vnc/sshvnc.html
http://www.uk.research.att.com/vnc/sshwin.html

> He's trying to write a proxy today thinking he can enable routing of
> dns and ftp through an application layer socket.

This sounds like overkill.  Fun, but overkill.  FTP is notoriously bad at
being transparently tunnelled, as I'm sure he will discover soon.  ;-)

> I'd like to find a solution that doesn't involve writing Windows
> software as results can't be predicted and making a mess would not be
> good.  The job is to prevent a thirty thousand dollar loss as
> unintrusively as possible.

No matter what transfer method you choose, I suggest the following:
  + archive the files into a single file (i.e. ZIP, TAR, etc.)
  + checksum the file on both the source and destination sides
  + compare the checksums to be sure the file came over OK
    - do this in addition to any checksums the archiver does
    - MD5SUM for Windows can be found at:
      http://downloads.activestate.com/contrib/md5sum/Windows/

This will help prevent or at least detect that one of these valuable files
didn't make it.

  -- Steve

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Fri May  2 10:31:01 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Fri May  2 10:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Minnis bows to lobbyists of Microsoft
In-Reply-To: <3EB285CF.7040508@hevanet.com>
References: <3EB285CF.7040508@hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <200305021031.16651.matt@legalizefreedom.org>

The way Mr. Barber puts this reminds me of an analysis I once read about 
organized crime at the turn of the century. A few "clean" politicians would 
listen to reason and try to create legislation to clean up their act while 
the rest secretly pocketed large amounts of money and, for a long while, 
nothing changed.

The scene is different but the actions are the same. 

I guess we could take a look at history and see how, in the face of large 
dollars lobbying politicians towards "the dark side", a grass-roots movement 
can change the law. In the past this took the face of a heavy media campaign, 
letting people know what was happening. This involved some heavy-duty 
journalism, getting to the source, finding who was taking money (and why) and 
letting people know the reasons behind why their politicians did not vote to 
outlaw organized crime. The problem being that taking money is very 
commonplace today (and people are so "over-media"ed that they will not listen 
unless something is particularly seedy or interesting.) Our politicians and 
leaders can take "contributions" and be "forced" to "listen" to corporations 
(like Microsoft). People don't care because they are not that interested in 
what their computers run. People see Microsoft as a great corporation that 
contributes money to schools and non-profits.

Perhaps this bill is "too much, too soon". It is also reminiscent of the 
marijuana legalization bills that, inevitably, will be on the ballot every 
other year. Peoples opinions are too closed. They don't know what this bill 
means. They don't know what open source software is. They know Windoze, 
because they use it at work (and at home on their crappy PC they bought at 
best buy or the home shopping network) and they feel threatened by something 
they don't know, and don't understand. 

I guess what I'm getting at is that part of the reason this billed failed is 
not just Mircosoft's intervention (we all know that is the REAL reason). Our 
government is currently organized to give a bigger voice to the corporate 
influence. Whether this is right or not, it is LEGAL and the strategy of open 
source must act accordingly..

That said, does anyone have any ideas on how to combat having a neighbor like 
M$ next door? No matter what the legislation, they are close enough that they 
will interfere with almost anything that goes on in our capitol. We will 
always have to deal with weak politicians and deep pockets of M$ lobbying. 
How can we get around this? How do you convince people that a big company 
that they may not like (though secretly admire and envy) is bad news when it 
comes to the bottom line?

I think "Kicking Microsoft out of our schools" isn't the right approach
as it is what most students will see in the work place and you won't get
many parents to support this.  I think a better approach is to convince
people that the combination of many types of software platforms is the
best way to allow the students to have a wider range of knowledge as
well as save some money.  We all know that Open Source Software has made
a large surge into the business market, but it has a long way to go.
Getting children familiar with it at an early age is important, but you
won't get into a position to promote it if you are threatening to take
away what is familiar.  Microsoft has it place as does Open Source.
Good luck convincing parents that what 90 percent of them have at home
isn't what their children will be learning.  You would have better luck
explaining to them that they can still use what they have, as well as
other choices.  
Of course, all of this is "IMO"    

--Brian

This argument worked really, really well trying to get rid of the

Also, to harp on the "schools don't teach products, they teach skills"
critique once more . . . 

Our educators should *not* be teaching a specific word processor or
spreadsheet, but the general idea of how to use a word processor or
spreadsheet.  As such, I'd say it's a good idea to "kick Microsoft out
of our schools" and teach vendor-neutral skills rather than MS-specific
ones.  

Additionally, by the time our K-12 students get into the workplace, who
is to say that Microsoft Office will still be such a dominant force? (I,
for one, highly doubt it, especially for the 'K' students).  Teaching
skills on a 3rd party application forces a focus on the skill, not the
product simply because you cannot ignore the fact that it may work
differently on a Microsoft product.

On Fri, 2 May 2003, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> Speaking of which, is there a union to represent IT workers?

IT workers have traditionally been considered "white collar" and no unions
have existed.

Today, however, with so many telephone, on-line and floor technicians,
there is definitely a place for organizing among the laborers.  (It
certainly would have helped alleviate the problems of the dot bust when
senior technicians were laid off in favor of cheaper labor.)

I think SAGE had the potential to be a fantastic tradesman's guild, but
has since given up any such aspirations.  The closest they come to
collective bargaining and setting professional standards is a salary
survey and newsletter.  Pretty weak.

As we continue our race to the bottom, we'll see more and more need for
organization among the working classes (whether we see more organization
or not).

I've considered working to organize groups such as the NOC technicians of
the various telcos and data carriers (often, in my experience, as highly
skilled as the engineers they support but having less formal education and
uniformly lower pay).  I've been unable to do anything of the sort because
I've had to try to find ways to support myself and there's no money in
organizing.  (Of course, that's the great strength of the system:  It
forces us to concentrate on our own survival individually to prevent us
from working toward our own propserity collectively.)  If there were a
sponsoring union, it might be possible to get a paid organizer into some
of the shops and make some change.  Unfortunately, as you point out, many
of the unions today are weak and many others have degraded into purely
capitalist organizations that exploit their own members for the profit of
the management.

J.

(note the small formfactor, and odd resolution).

ebay.

bothered with the modem, or the firewire. Everything else works great,

From qubex at punkass.com  Fri May  2 14:05:12 2003
From: qubex at punkass.com (Matt Chorman)
Date: Fri May  2 14:05:12 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Minnis bows to lobbyists of Microsoft
In-Reply-To: <3EB285CF.7040508@hevanet.com>
References: <3EB285CF.7040508@hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <200305020912.37483.qubex@punkass.com>

The way Mr. Barber puts this reminds me of an analysis I once read about 
organized crime at the turn of the century (last one, not this one). A few 
"clean" politicians would listen to reason and try to create legislation to 
clean up their act while the rest secretly pocketed large amounts of money 
and, for a long while, nothing changed.

The scene is different but the actions are the same. 

I guess we could take a look at history and see how, in the face of large 
dollars lobbying politicians towards "the dark side", a grass-roots movement 
can change the law. In the past this took the face of a heavy media campaign, 
letting people know what was happening. This involved some heavy-duty 
journalism, getting to the source, finding who was taking money (and why) and 
letting people know the reasons behind why their politicians did not vote to 
outlaw organized crime. The problem being that taking money is very 
commonplace today (and people are so "over-media"ed that they will not listen 
unless something is particularly seedy or interesting.) Our politicians and 
leaders can take "contributions" and be "forced" to "listen" to corporations 
(like Microsoft). People don't care because they are not that interested in 
what their computers run. People see Microsoft as a great corporation that 
contributes money to schools and non-profits.

Perhaps this bill is "too much, too soon". It is also reminiscent of the 
marijuana legalization bills that, inevitably, will be on the ballot every 
other year. Peoples opinions are too closed. They don't know what this bill 
means. They don't know what open source software is. They know Windoze, 
because they use it at work (and at home on their crappy PC they bought at 
best buy or the home shopping network) and they feel threatened by something 
they don't know, and don't understand. 

I guess what I'm getting at is that part of the reason this billed failed is 
not just Mircosoft's intervention (we all know that is the REAL reason). Our 
government is currently organized to give a bigger voice to the corporate 
influence. Whether this is right or not, it is LEGAL and the strategy of open 
source must act accordingly..

That said, does anyone have any ideas on how to combat having a neighbor like 
M$ next door? No matter what the legislation, they are close enough that they 
will interfere with almost anything that goes on in our capitol. We will 
always have to deal with weak politicians and deep pockets of M$ lobbying. 
How can we get around this? How do you convince people that a big company 
that they may not like (though secretly admire and envy) is bad news when it 
comes to the bottom line?

From techmage at aracnet.com  Fri May  2 14:18:01 2003
From: techmage at aracnet.com (Prutzer)
Date: Fri May  2 14:18:01 2003
Subject: Possible Virus          Was      Re: [PLUG] Minnis bows to lobbyists of Microsoft
In-Reply-To: <200305021031.16651.matt@legalizefreedom.org>
References: <3EB285CF.7040508@hevanet.com> <200305021031.16651.matt@legalizefreedom.org>
Message-ID: <2t2yPioOf2+kTuP5aiNpaxfeFTl=@4ax.com>

Hi all,
While Reading the Plug list today Norton discovered a Virus on my
machine. Yes, it's a win98 box, No, I don't know how it got here.
I had just finished changing some shares on the box so my network here
could function a little freer. I writing to let you know it is
something you might want to check your system for.

It's called the W32/Opaserv-a virus on Sophos.
(www.sophos.com/virusinfo/analyses/w32opaserva.html)

it uses an ip vulnerability to computers with open  c: shares and
netbios enabled.

Not hard to get rid of if you catch it early.

Norton caught it and alerted me and I was able to go to Google and
find the fix.

I'm passing this on so you can be made aware that it's in the portland
area, that anyone connected to the Internet can get it(well, it
doesn't work on Linux or Mac's) and that even those of us who should
know better( Mea  Maxima Culpa)  can fall to this one while doing
things we take for granted should be safe.
 
So, thanks for reading, I now return you to the discussion on how best
to fillet and cook a politician.

Harry
AKA Prutzer
Sed Quis Custodiet Ipsos Custodes?

>author, HB 2892 (Oregon)
We can use his testimony, only in the NEXT go round.
We can lose a battle and not lose the war. Oregon was just the opening
Skirmish in what is going to be the "Mother of all Battles" in the
Computer world. Yes, we took some licks here. But we still have the
better weapons. We must fight in the style that can beat down the
opposition. Consider ourselves as Guerilla fighters. We work quietly
at converting the masses to our way of thinking by working alongside
them and showing them the benefits and cost savings of using Open
Source Software. We fight for one little hamlet at a time. When we are
attacked, we fade into the jungle and come up somewhere else to
provoke and fight.
 
In the  night, we go directly against the opposition and develop tools
and programs and hardware that work, not just as good, but better.
It may take years, we must face the fact that we cannot take them on
dollar for dollar, our base of power against them doesn't have it. But
we can win, by winning the hearts and minds of users, of small
businesses and local school districts. 

We take it to those places the opposition considers to small and
menial to deal with. We do it by building LUGS in every city, county
and state. Slowly, one at a time, if necessary. We shall prevail. We
shall be the opening wedge that will change how corporate America and
the world does business.
We do not oppose profit, we support it, but just not on the backs of
our users and not out of the pockets of our tax payers and citizens
and school districts.

Every person, teenager, student and Little Old Lady we can convert to
Open Source, becomes a warrior in our cause. As one against the Giant
we are lost, but organized together, there is no army of "legal
Experts" ,"Corporate Software Bullies", there is no enemy we cannot
take on and win. 

I believe in the words of the American Hero, Benjamin Franklin, who
said as he signed the Declaration of Independence:

" If we do not hang together, then we shall surely hang separately"

We need to use the same tactics the Revolutionary Warriors did. To
fire our shots at the enemy and to fade into the trees. Let "them"
fight in regimented rows in bright uniforms and with their "tried and
true" weapons and tactics. While we use our wits and our connections
to the people. Let us use the disgruntled user who is tired of
re-booting his computer to fix an error that comes installed as a
"Feature"

When we took up the cause of Open Source Software, we did so in the
full knowledge that it was an uphill fight. Let us not lose that
courage of our convictions because one setback has slowed the pace of
the battle locally. Now, is the time to regroup and to develop our
plans for the next battle.
Now is the time to organize and subvert those who would be hinge
points in our battle.
Politicians who oppose us, must be removed. Legal rulings against us
must be fought against. And we must use whatever weapons fall to our
hands, whether they are ethical or not, for we are engaged in a war
that will change history more than the battles in the Middle East
will. We must take our fight to the People, let the People decide who
is the better for them. But we must also enlighten and teach the
people, so they realize they HAVE an alternative.

Let each of us create a "Cell" that trains, just three people, and in
exchange, those three teach three more and form another cell. Let that
be the COST we incur, so that our posterity may live in a better
place, perhaps, than where we are now. Let us fight for the future,
rather than the present. Let our vision be one that is FAR sighted
rather than so near-sighted we lose the scope of the battle.

The People of the World are looking to us to start that process that
will free them from the tyranny they now struggle against. Let us have
hope in ourselves, so that we can give hope to those who cannot join
us at the barricades.Let us not waiver from our goals nor let us lose
hope that we shall prevail.For those without hope are dead already and
those who fight on have no use for the dead. Let us give that last
ounce, that last full measure to our cause. For in the end, whether we
succeed this year or next or the years after, those who follow us in
the fight need our resolve to help them conquer, even if we ourselves
should fall. Let us therefore resolve to commit all our energy and
passion to this, our cause. I know not what the future will bring, but
I stand ready to defend my beliefs, even to the fires of Hell.


Thank you for taking the time to read this,
Harry Howard

Sed Quis Custodiet Ipsos Custodes?

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat May  3 08:38:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat May  3 08:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sharing a modem
In-Reply-To: <20030503145259.GA10090@boora.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305030834010.2547-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 3 May 2003, Michael Montagne wrote:

> My wife is moving her company and needs to use a modem to connect to the
> internet until her DSL is installed.  They are all Win98/95 machines.
> Someone told her that she could set up a Win2000 machine as a phone
> server.  Then:
> Me:  "You should use a linux box"
> Her: "A linux box!!  Can you set that up for me?"
> Me:  "Well, err, I, um , well......"

  Until we installed dsl almost four years ago we shared a modem among all
machines and it would dial and connect whenever someone went to fetch a Web
page, do a ftp transfer or when fetchmail went to get mail from the ISP. So,
the answer is, "Yes".

  I _thought_ there was a daemon called, "diald", but I cannot find it on my
system. However, there's a PPP-HOWTO and you'll want to read 'man pppd' and
'man wvdial'.

  When you have specific questions someone more knowledgeable than I will
answer them for you.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Sat May  3 08:52:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Sat May  3 08:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sharing a modem
In-Reply-To: <20030503145259.GA10090@boora.com>
Message-ID: <25878-79152@sneakemail.com>

On Sat, 3 May 2003, Michael Montagne montagne-at-boora.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> My experience is limited to my home network using DSL and an IP
> masquerading firewall.  Ridiculously easy.  Could I employ the same
> technique with a dial up modem?

Yes.  The masquerading setup will be the same as if your upstream IP
connection is a DSL line.  The masquerading software doesn't care, just so
long as you have a place for it to send its IP packets.

> How to set that up?

http://www.tldp.org/HOWTO/IP-Masquerade-HOWTO/

> What application is used to dial up?

"pppd"

> How will it automatically dial when accessed by a client on their
> network?

Look in the pppd documentation for the "demand" configuration option.  It
will probably be easiest to get pppd working without this option first,
then enable it once you're sure the modem and ISP login are both working
properly.

This somewhat outdated document may also be useful:

http://handsonhowto.com/dodip.html

> Can it be shared ala a DSL/NIC style setup?

Yes.  Though obviously it will be quite slow in comparison.

  -- Steve

From jon at manymoons.net  Sat May  3 11:16:01 2003
From: jon at manymoons.net (Jon Jacob)
Date: Sat May  3 11:16:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Oregonian letter, HB 2892
In-Reply-To: <200305031053.44721.pundit@teleport.com>
References: <200305031053.44721.pundit@teleport.com>
Message-ID: <1051985712.15795.657.camel@lana>

I thought he made some interesting points.  However, it did leave me
wondering about several things.

1) How pervasive is OSS in the State offices?  He never gave details
about how many servers, desktops, or whatever run OSS versus those that
don't.

2) He is an assistant sys admin, and therefore may not have an eagle eye
view of all systems.  With this in mind, he states it may cost more
money to mandate something that many sys admins already do.  If they do
use OSS, this is a good point; however, since he never explains how
pervasive OSS is in the State government, we never get a clear picture
of how much would be spent vesus how much would be saved.

3) Finally, he states that the definition of OSS that the bill provides
is very "restrictive".  Is this true?  I have not seen the definition of
OSS provided in the bill.

Basically, his overall argument is "let the admins decide".  Not really
a bad argument, however the role of government is to make policy and
part of this policy is to run efficiently.  Those who advocate OSS want
the State to make policy that is uniform and clear.  If all admins do
what they want without direction, we would be left with systems that do
not work in concert and are very inefficent.  So, I am somewhat
sympathetic toward the idea of input from the admin, but to advocate no
policy on the matter leaves the State wasting money where they could
actually be saving it.

Just some thoughts, for what its worth.

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Sat May  3 12:10:02 2003

On Sat, 2003-05-03 at 11:15, Jon Jacob wrote:
> I thought he made some interesting points.  However, it did leave me
> wondering about several things.
> 
> 1) How pervasive is OSS in the State offices?  He never gave details
> about how many servers, desktops, or whatever run OSS versus those that
> don't.

Theses numbers are available on a department level. For example, DAS
will be able to tell you what they have but is not likely to have the
numbers for DHS. 

I can tell you that our department has several Linux boxes running OSS.
I can also tell you that the largest platform in my department contains
an engine that is dedicated to Linux. This engine has the capacity of
running a maximum of 30000 Linux servers and there is documented
evidence of like platforms, in other states, running 8000+ Linux
production servers (see oss.software.ibm.com/linux390). Our first
opportunity, if successful, will replace roughly 300 workstations with
OSS clients. All of this has the blessing of state IS and Business
management. Production CVS and other infrastructure service requests are
coming in rapidly.

> 2) He is an assistant sys admin, and therefore may not have an eagle eye
> view of all systems.  With this in mind, he states it may cost more
> money to mandate something that many sys admins already do.  If they do
> use OSS, this is a good point; however, since he never explains how
> pervasive OSS is in the State government, we never get a clear picture
> of how much would be spent vesus how much would be saved.

I am a Senior Systems Admin with the state and I don't look at what unit
has which OS. We tend to look at what fits best for the business need
and deploy that OS and app. Also, I know of no "Eagle" that watches over
all departments and counts what OS or Application is installed and
compares the numbers (this is not to say that an "Eagle" does not
exist). The state departments and agencies are big on working standards
that they can maintain and manage. Finding the number of devices using
"Standard A" and those using "Standard B" should, I guess, be possible
although, considering the volume, this would be a daunting and expensive
task.

> 3) Finally, he states that the definition of OSS that the bill provides
> is very "restrictive".  Is this true?  I have not seen the definition of
> OSS provided in the bill.

It would be interesting to see what the bill ended up looking like after
amendment. Is there a link to the finished bill?

> Basically, his overall argument is "let the admins decide".  Not really
> a bad argument, however the role of government is to make policy and
> part of this policy is to run efficiently.  Those who advocate OSS want
> the State to make policy that is uniform and clear.  If all admins do
> what they want without direction, we would be left with systems that do
> not work in concert and are very inefficent.  So, I am somewhat
> sympathetic toward the idea of input from the admin, but to advocate no
> policy on the matter leaves the State wasting money where they could
> actually be saving it.
> 
> Just some thoughts, for what its worth.

Let the admins decide is not going to make it here. The task is actually
to prove that an OSS solution works, is manageable, stable and cost
effective. The task then shifts to selling the solution to the business
units that have to use the product in their daily operation. All of this
is about the same as it is in private sector corporations.

-- 
Steven A. Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com>

being stopped not due to the technical reasons he mentions, but because
a lobbyist (obviously working on behalf of Microsoft) wanted it dead &
buried. In other words, his point is that this bill should be debated,
when the issue is that Craven does not want anyone inside government
(& perhaps even outside of it) to have the debate.

BTW, Ken I submitted the link to your letter in the Oregonian to both
Slashdot & Linuxtoday. Despite my pitch (& I thought it was a decent one),
/. passed on it, while Linuxtoday featured it today. Perhaps /. was
too busy looking for stories to post duplicates of.

Geoff

I've been an observer to the debates and differences
of opinion between Ken and Ray in the recent past. I
think one of the primary reasons for this conflict is
their dramatically different experiences with State
government. Ken was fired from a State job because he
advocated keeping an existing OSS system in place that
was reliable and doing the job. His manager fired him
because he didn't agree that the system should be
scrapped and replaced with a Microsoft-only system.

While I don't know for sure, I suspect that this has
never happened to Ray because he works for a State
agency where common sense prevails much or most of
the time.

My experiences outside of State government more
closely match Ken's experiences. I've lost lots of
work because customers want to go with Microsoft
solutions even when they're the worst of all solutions.
The playing field is horribly uneven because of the
mass bias toward Microsoft products in spite of the
high cost and the frequent problems. 

I think HB2892 is needed because we need the
equivalent of an affirmative action program for
software in order to level the playing field, Clearly,
when you talk about affirmative action many people
are not going to agree because it causes them some
inconvenience and is perceived as reverse discrimination.
However, that's the price we all pay when we're trying
to repair problems brought about by years of abuse by
those in power.

One such abuse was the Republican-controlled Federal
government letting Microsoft escape the punishment for
crimes they were convicted of and allowing them to
continue committing these crimes. 

When our Federal government lets us down, our State
governments could step in with a partial remedy but
even a highly diluted remedy (HR2892) was killed -
also by a Republican.

It pisses me off but I still respect Ray's opinion.

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

From raanders at acm.org  Sat May  3 13:52:02 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Sat May  3 13:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sharing a modem
In-Reply-To: <20030503145259.GA10090@boora.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0305031343530.12729-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Sat, 3 May 2003, Michael Montagne wrote:

> My wife is moving her company and needs to use a modem to connect to the
> internet until her DSL is installed.  They are all Win98/95 machines.
> Someone told her that she could set up a Win2000 machine as a phone
> server.  Then:
> Me:  "You should use a linux box"
> Her: "A linux box!!  Can you set that up for me?"
> Me:  "Well, err, I, um , well......"

Well I'd strongly suggest an Asante (or other company's) hardware firewall
verses trying to knock something together.  For around $120 (a year ago
price) you can have a decent firewall in place that will work with a
modem or Ethernet connection.
   I ran a diald based system for years and built several for companies
and churches before the advent of inexpensive firewalls.  Then about a
year ago I started having problems with my internal modem so decided to go
with an external which worked fine but I wanted a more commercial touch to
my home setup (which I use to demostrate what can be done) so I bought an
Asante (with serial port).  I had it up and working within 30 minutes
which included _reading_ the installation guide (very MS oriented) and the
UNIX network portion of the manual.
   I now have DSL but the modem is still connected to the firewall (which
is behind my DSL bridge/router) just incase the DSL (SDSL - not shared
line) circuit goes down.  I can reconfigure to use the modem in about 5
minutes.

Kind of goes against the grain to use something not Linux but I'm
pragmative about these things.  I use Microsoft products until I can find
an easy or decent Open Source/Linux solution.


Rod

  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

the general public so I don't think my comments are going
to antagonize Republicans everywhere. 

Facts are facts. In all major battles between corporate 
monopolists and the U.S. government (DOJ and FTC) that
I've paid attention to, it was a Republican administration
that dropped the case, or forgave the crime in some way.
One of the more obvious examples in the computer industry
is IBM (Ronald Regan administration), where the case was
dropped. Now Microsoft (Bush administration), where the
company was convicted but was not punished for the crime.

I don't agree that it should be depoliticized. This is
all about the politics of big business, special interests,
and the politicians that allow corruption to flourish.
Many of us here know that "arguments of fact" don't work
and some of us here have lost our jobs or significant
amounts of work because of this issue.   

This is not the forum for suicide and abortion issues and
they have nothing to do with computer industry monopolies.
Please let's not go off on that tangent.

She was elevated to the Federal District Court in 1997 by President Clinton,
and today she was widely praised for being evenhanded and diligent.

http://www.hagley.lib.de.us/1980.htm
the case was withdrawn by William F. Baxter, assistant attorney general in
charge of the Antitrust Division, Department of Justice, on January 8, 1982.
Baxter signed a Stipulation of Dismissal that stated the government's charges
were "without merit." It was later discovered that Baxter had failed to
disclose that he had been retained as a consultant to a West Coast law firm
defending IBM in private antitrust cases. 

http://www.stanford.edu/dept/facultysenate/archive/1999_2000/reports/106339/106
421.html
But the high point of Bill's career was unquestionably the Bell System
divestiture, comparable only to the breakup of the Standard Oil Company of New
Jersey in 1911. His position was controversial even within the Administration,
being strongly opposed by among others the Secretary of Defense, who rather
outranked him. But its benefits for consumers and for the competitiveness of
the US telecommunications industry have been widely praised by economists, and
in 1996 he was a co-recipient of the John Sherman Award, for his "vision and
courage".

Russell

For the Oregon folks, Senator Smith is on the committee. 

If you send a note (the links did not work for me), make sure you edit
the companies involved.

-----Forwarded Message-----

From: Marianne Granoff <granoff at zianet.com>
To: nmisp at nmisp.net, uswisp at lists.nm.org, nmipa at nmipa.org, aww-discuss at egroups.com, checs at checs.net, forum at lists.nm.org
Subject: (uswisp) Senate Bill 905 needs to be amended
Date: 03 May 2003 09:40:32 -0600

S.905 : A bill to amend the Internal Revenue Code of
1986 to provide a broadband Internet access tax
credit. Sponsor: Sen Rockefeller, Jay [WV] (introduced
4/11/2003), Senate, 5/2/2003,
http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d108:s.00905:

This bill does NOT extend the tax credits to ISPs.  The language in the 
bill currently limits those eligible for the tax credit to:

  (A) cable operator,
  (B) commercial mobile service carrier,
  (C) open video system operator,
  (F) other wireless carrier,

  providing current generation broadband services or
  next generation broadband services to subscribers
  through such qualified equipment."

This essentially means that Internet Service Providers (ISPs) are NOT 
eligible for the tax credit unless they are also "carriers" or cable 
companies.  The word "carrier" is specifically defined under federal law 
and NM state law to mean a business certified under the FCC or state Public 
Regulation Commission.  In other words, a phone company, whether a regular 
phone company such as Qwest or Valor, or a wireless phone company such as 
Verizon or Alltel.

ISPs who provide their own DSL, wireless services, or other broadband 
services will not get the tax credits.

The bill is currently in the Senate Finance Committee.

The members of the Senate Finance Committee are:

Republicans:

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Mon May  5 07:31:02 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Mon May  5 07:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs shortcuts?
References: <mailman.1052142127.30963.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86he89bh67.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   I am surprised to learn that there is apparently no keyboard
Rich> shortcut in emacs to moved to a specific line number. When I
Rich> type 'c-h w' for 'goto-' I see that it's only on the edit menu,
Rich> and two levels down. Doesn't seem very efficient to me.

Rich>   What have you emacs experts done to bind this command to a keystroke?

Why are you going to a line number?  Are you looking at error
messages?  If so, run that same command under M-x compile CR, and the
line numbers are automatically located for you!  See "running compilations
under emacs" in the info file for details.

But when I do something outside that, I have just learned to type M-x
got TAB CR to get to "goto-line" quickly.

Rich>   Also, is there a way to automate line wrapping in a text file when it's
Rich> been exported (in my case by OO.o) with each paragraph as a single line?
Rich> Again, it's not very efficient to go through the equivalent of a 60-page
Rich> book by hand separating paragraphs so they properly import into LyX.

Set the region around the whole thing, then M-x indent-region CR.  Usually
works.

From ali at axian.com  Mon May  5 08:30:02 2003
From: ali at axian.com (Alice Corbin)
Date: Mon May  5 08:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Emacs shortcuts?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305050637430.20530-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>; from rshepard@appl-ecosys.com on Mon, May 05, 2003 at 06:41:20AM -0700
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305050637430.20530-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20030505082910.B5030@zaphod.axian.com>

I have:

(global-set-key [f5]   'goto-line)

(To give credit where it's due, I sort of remember stealing this from
Terry Griffin eons ago.)

And if you're working through compile errors, well then, there's:

(global-set-key [f6]   'next-error)

From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

On Mon, 5 May 2003, Michael Robinson wrote:

> So quickly, is emacs better than vim?

  No. They are different.

> I've learned some tricks such as multiple windows and have seen versions
> of vim that syntax highlight C code so I'm really starting to wonder just
> how different these two editors are.  Are the colors used for syntax
> highlighting under the editors the same as the ls colors?  I want to
> change the black background and colorization choices for the terminal and
> ls becuase the color don't show up well to my liking. Blue does not come
> out on black.

 AFAIK, both can be used for just about any editing/writing/coding task. In
my -- admittedly limited -- experience, vi(m) tends to be the editor of
choice of SysAdmins because it's small and fast (because of a gazillion
keyboard shortcuts for _everything_). Emacs has been described as the editor
with everything -- including the kitchen sink. As a result, it is quite
large (emacs == Eight Megs And Counting Still) but it can be used as the
shell for your console sessions.

  Both support color and syntax highlighting.

  My copy of emacs used to come up with a white background and black/colored
text on it. I find that too contrasty for comfortable viewing so I changed
everything in ~/.emacs to produce a black background with the colors I want
on it.

  Works for me.

Rich

> terminal and ls becuase the color don't show up well to my liking.

Try 

set background=dark

in vi (you can put this line in your ~/.vimrc if you want it to always
do that).

For emacs, the options menu offers a good interface to changing your
font colors (and all other emacs settings). In emacs-speak, fonts are
called faces, iirc.

  become like the amish, or maybe even the luddites.  They like vi,
  for reasons that are still not clear to me.

honest description of an emacs-vim flamewar. Which seemed so nice of
someone as intelligent as Mr. Schwartz to shortcut the actual flamewar
and provide.

the flamewar, Mr. Schwartz was rather beginning it.

So with the first volley on his side, let me answer with this:

I can load Vim in less than ~2 seconds on my very very old machines. It
takes about, oh, 30 minutes for emacs.

And then, when I make a simple mistake and close emacs instead of the
window I was working on, I curse and scream.

> :-)

And while we're on the subject of flamewars, let me restate your email
with regards to another common flamewar:

Perl vs. Python summary:

* There'd be lots of posts. Terrifying numbers of posts, mostly
pro-perl, but the perl ones would be short and ugly, while the python
ones would be long, clean, well-written theses regarding the worth of a
language in terms of its elegance.

* Two camps. 

* One camp loves the fact that they can write clean, easily readable and
maintainable code that they can come back to a month later and still
know what it does. They are constantly surprised by how elegant and
natural the language is. For them, Python is the way to go, and dirty
hacks and ugliness are always the resort of the weak-minded.

* The other camp are neanderthals who grunt in short, semi-intelligible
spurts of random symbols. They like perl, for reasons that are entirely
unclear to me, and proudly show off its illegibility.

Jeff

(all in good fun, I swear...=)

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Mon May  5 16:23:02 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Mon May  5 16:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking Of Emacs
In-Reply-To: <20030505132815.3b5c4ea2.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305051607520.8863-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

On Mon, 5 May 2003, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> I'm curious about emacs as an IDE, but I don't know a thing about it.
> Is emacs just text-mode, and if so, does xemacs run in text mode as well
> as graphical?  Also, does xemacs use gnome, gtk, or what exactly?
>

GNU-emacs runs in either text-mode or "x-mode".  At one point, GNU-emacs
had fallen behind the times and the x-mode was very functional, but
lacked features and was boring.  However, this has changed.
Thanks to competition from the xemacs people, the GNU-emacs people
got there act together and have greatly improved the x-mode.
As a result, GNU-emacs runs well in text-mode and in x-mode, and it
runs in these modes on most any Unix like OS and on most any MS Windows
OS.

xemacs runs in either text-mode or "x-mode".  At one point, xemacs
didn't run on Windows or barely worked on Windows.  However, this
has changed.  Current versions run well on any Unix like OS and on
most any MS Windows OS.

So, which is better GNU-Emacs or xemacs?  I don't know.  I generally
use GNU-Emacs, but this is simply because I started with GNU-Emacs
years and years ago.  I think GNU-Emacs may have a slight edge over
xemacs for high end sophisticated tasks, and xemacs may be a bit
easier to learn; but these differences are minor.  Internally, they
have some significant differences, but these don't really affect
most of us.  Indeed, I'm told that much of the emacs code I wrote
once upon a time works in xemacs, so ....

amalgamation of the local syntax with its own.

And let's just template them so that we can skip all the email
messages,  kind of like the old prison joke:

A man (not a Trail Blazer) is convicted of multiple assault and car
theft and sent to prison.  On the evening of his first day in, he hears
someone call out "37!".  The rest of the prison block just busts out
laughing.  Several more numbers are said with the same results, and
this continues for several minutes until the lights are turned off.

The next day he asks someone at lunch what the deal was with the
numbers last night.  The other inmate says, "Most of us have been in
here so long that we've just given each joke a number.  It saves the
time of actually telling it."

So the man figures out he'll give it a try tonight.  After they're
locked back in their cells after dinner he calls out, "45".  Dead
silence.  He tries another number, "71!".  Again, dead silence.
Baffled, he goes to sleep that night.

The next morning, he sits next to the same inmate who told him
about the joke/number system, "Hey, what happened last night with
my jokes?"

The other inmate says, "Hey, some people just can't tell a joke."

Colin



From stevea at nwtechops.com  Mon May  5 17:46:02 2003

Subject: [PLUG] GCC-3.3 --> kernel compilation crashes!?
In-Reply-To: <200305051747.h45Hl3j22560@gate.daniloff.com>

On Mon, 2003-05-05 at 10:47, Alex Daniloff wrote:

> warnings.
> Is there any chance to downgrade or upgrade
> gcc-3.3 to more stable version without sacrifying
> system integrity?
> Or could somebody please give me a hint what patch,
> option or other thing should be done to the plain
> vanilla kernel 2.4.20 in order to compile it correctly
> with existing gcc-3.3?
> 
> Thank you in advance for any help.
> 
> Alex
> 

Hey Alex,
Are you getting a "segmentation fault" error during 2.4.20 compile and
actually doing a core dump, or is gcc failing on compile errors? 

The warnings that you mention earlier are probably fine, they usually
mean that a comparison is being done on a sub-routine return that might
be of type int instead of unsigned int. Normally looks something like

if (!someroutine(int somearg)){ do something fun; }

where somerouting() is of type int. This forces the compiler to complain
that, since ! is likely to be of type unsigned integer (in C this is the
case, C++ it's type bool) 0 or 1 and the return can be a negative
number. Really only possibly devastating to the programs operation in
this case but the compiler still complains but does not stop.

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Mon May  5 18:11:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Mon May  5 18:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Speaking Of Emacs
In-Reply-To: <20030505132815.3b5c4ea2.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20030505132815.3b5c4ea2.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <20030506011028.GA1593@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Mon, May 05, 2003 at 01:28:15PM -0500, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> I'm curious about emacs as an IDE, but I don't know a thing about it. 
> Is emacs just text-mode, and if so, does xemacs run in text mode as well
> as graphical?  Also, does xemacs use gnome, gtk, or what exactly?

It's best just to try it, but before you do, know these things:

Emacs has a _LOT_ of commands, so many of them are bound to multiple
keystrokes.

To exit: C-xC-c (this means pres Control-x, let up on the keys, then
press Control-c)

To save: C-xC-s (the case _does_ matter, C-xC-S saves all files currently open)

Meta(M) is usually Alt, or you can press Esc, let up on it, then type
the next character. ie: M-x can be run by pressing Esc, releasing it,
then pressing x. Because of this, you will often see Meta written as
Esc in documentation.

-Rogan

You might not need to recompile the kernel. Is module support enabled
for your current kernel? If so all you probably need to do is get the
module that you received from DLink in the right spot and make a change
to modules.conf. Also take a look at the insmod (and associated)
man-pages.

xemacs has the advantage that it can include a "package" even if that
package's copyright has not been signed over to the FSF.  RMS refuses
to allow such a package into GNU Emacs.  While I understand RMS's
reason, it does tend to keep xemacs a bit more package-ful and
bleeding edge.  Not that you can't take most of the
non-GNU-Emacs-distro packages and try to run them on GNU Emacs anyway.
Most will work. :)

Just another guy who has written .el files that are in the core
of both versions of [x]emacs...

I don't use the redhat version of apt, so I can't answer this in
specific, but I can say that I've gotten signature errors before, and
they've never been because I got spoofed packages. I have to say, though
it's a huge security violation in theory, it's generally easiest and
perfectly safe to turn these checks off for the duration of the problem,
provided the same errors occur over the course of several days. It's
usually just a build error, that I've seen.

the message is supposed to tell you that the package failed to download,
was spoofed, or was overwritten at the source with a bad package. It's
probably a good security measure to keep in place, but it's never
happened in my memory.

Jeff

their hat into the AMD ring.

>> Linux kernel that includes a new driver?
>>
>> I had to build a new kernel to enable multi-LUN support for my tape
>> library.  I've discovered that my Dlink DGE-550T NIC locks up under high
>> load and I've downloaded the latest Linux driver from the Dlink website.

> man-pages.

Yes, thank you.  But what if I wanted to build a kernel without module
support, for security reasons, etc.?  How would I include that driver in a
static kernel?
Thanks,
~M

You may want to see if your particular Fujistu is listed at 
http://www.linux-on-laptops.com

Other than that, what Bill wrote is good advice.  I'm not too keen to 
use Knoppix other than for diagnostics most of the time.  Going with a 
more current version is a good idea.  According to the publisher, Corel 
Linux for Dummies game out Jan 2000.  Meaning that if your laptop is 
newer than that (or even newer than '99) it probably wouldn't be a good 
Linux to try out due to HW issues.

Go with something newer.  You may be able to get through to Redhat now 
to download 9.  It makes a decent starter set.

OK, I found a newer version of the dl2k.c (version 1.17) distributed with
the RH 9 2.4.20-9 kernel-source.  I copied the .c and .h files to their
correct location in the kernel source tree, built a new kernel with that
driver, and now I no longer have the lockups when transferring large
amounts of data over the network.  I'm still curious as to how you would
include a new driver that wasn't already listed in the "make menuconfig"
screens.  I assume there's a config file somewhere that you can point to
the new driver and add a description, etc.

> with the RH 9 2.4.20-9 kernel-source.  I copied the .c and .h files to

I haven't done this myself, but, at a minimum, you would have to:

Copy your source code to the appropriate directory.  In this case 
drivers/net/

Modify the Makefile in said directory.

Modify the Documentation/Configure.help file.

This may or may not be complete.  Why not try it and tell us how it goes.

about reducing costs, but when push comes to shove they ignore an easy

the pressure will come from.

start doing some grassroots work.  All the ideology and bantering back
and forth will mean nothing without political backing.  There are simple
things you can do if you have about a dozen people to start with --
phone calls, letter writing to voters, and door to door canvasing.  I am
afraid that unless you are willing to put in the work at the ground
level there will be no reason for her to change her mind.

From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Tue May  6 14:22:14 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeffrey L. Schwaber)
Date: Tue May  6 14:22:14 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Trying to jump feet first into the linux.
In-Reply-To: <20030506164145.GA26027@edge>
References: <1e2.85abacd.2be92928@cs.com> <20030506164145.GA26027@edge>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.53.0305061717460.21681@student1.wesleyan.edu>

It should be noted that Knoppix does not attempt to support your video
card for most video cards--rather, it uses the kernel framebuffer (vesa)
and makes it look good, but is not in fact recognizing the video card.
You can do what Knoppix does with corel by going to the command line and
typing

dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xfree86

and using VESA and making sure you have your BUS:nn:nn:nn correct--look in
/proc/pci for the video card and read the numbers off there.

(yes, Corel is a debian distro--redhat configures X differently =)

But the Knoppix thing might be easier if you have no desire to play.

Jeff

On Tue, 6 May 2003, Bill Barry wrote:

> On Tue, May 06, 2003 at 10:04:27AM -0700, Michael Montagne wrote:
>
> > How do you install Knoppix permanently?
>
> Essentially it is a matter of copying the cd to the hard disk.
> It is described in the Knoppix FAQ
> http://download.linuxtag.org/knoppix/KNOPPIX-FAQ-EN.txt
>
> I haven't tried this and therefore could not say whether
> or not it is a good idea.

I have and can say that in general, it works. It does, however, take up
about 2.2 gigs of space and loads the machine with tons of stuff, which
isn't great for older machines, but is fine for newer ones.

basically here are the commands:

boot knoppix
ctrl-alt-f1 to get to the first virtual terminal
hit return a few times to get a command prompt
knx-hdinstall
follow directions
reboot
change the default language setting to english--it's
kontrolzentrum->personalische->land und sprache if I recall correctly,
check the Knoppix faq.

a notes: the installer is very beta--make a mistake, and you have to
cancel out and start over. It's also a bit funky on the keystrokes, but
not too bad.

Jeff




From sandbox at pacifier.com  Tue May  6 14:44:03 2003
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Tue May  6 14:44:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using RedHat's Up2Date to update my kernel

Jon Jacob wrote:
> Maybe I am being paranoid, but what exactly happens when I use up2date
> to update my kernel, should I choose to do that?  Do I still need to go
> through all the steps of building the kernel (I assume I do) or does it
> do it automatically somehow?
> 
> I am a little leary of doing it this way and wanted to know what I
> should expect.

I believe that kernel packages are skipped by default in up2date.  You can 
override this, but unless up2date can 'i'nstall instead of just 'f'reshen, 
don't do it this way.

Normally, I install the new kernel and reboot to make sure it works.  After 
you're sure the new kernel is okay, your can 'e'rase the previous one.  I 
haven't built a kernel in over a year and just use the binary rpm.  When I 
was building them, I used tarballs, so I can't advise on building RH's 
kernel-source rpm.

--
Kyle Accardi




From shahms at shahms.com  Tue May  6 14:51:02 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Tue May  6 14:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using RedHat's Up2Date to update my kernel
In-Reply-To: <3EB82C79.1020309@pacifier.com>
References: <1052256104.15796.833.camel@lana>
	 <3EB82C79.1020309@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <1052257496.29657.8.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

up2date has no problem updating kernel RPMs (it installs them, leaving
the old one(s) present and the old default is usually still the default
kernel).  yum also updates kernels automatically (and correctly), only
apt-get will not do it for you unless you remove the line from the
configuration file, and even then I'm not sure it will.  Usually you
have to tell apt the specific version you want to install with
# apt-get install kernel#<version-number>

Maybe the fear is that state government would be in a different environment
than everyone else.  A lot of monopolies are fueled by fear of not having
an environment, program, etc. that a customer has.  That environment doesn't
have to be appropriate for the job for this fear to be real.  I would like to 
see problems with Internet proprietorization for example addressed.  It's 
ridiculous that theoretically there is some web site that can crash any web 
browser out there.  Open data standards on public networks would help 
immensely.  The other thing that would help is to require proprietary data, 
etc. to be transmitted across public networks via methods that are non 
interfering with public data, etc.  Ultimately, do agencies need to be 
required to look at open source or do there need to be rigorous software 
testing and friendly neighbor laws?  Access is a major issue driving 
Microsoft to places it otherwise wouldn't reach because of bugs and 
cost.  The real issue seems to be data and application access whether
inolving web based services or not.  I may want to use open source
Excel replacement for example, but I'm afraid that my customer won't
use the same substitute so in the end I'm stuck with Excel.  The open
source community can try to hack Excel but it shouldn't have to do this
where it is easier to write quality software that isn't burdened by the issues
Excel has in it's design.  Excel was written before the Internet and before
many technologies developed, etc.

I see a lot of people get Microsoft anything because it's at work and they 
don't even think about because of the fear that that's what the customer
has and that's my only way to work with that customer.  I would like to
see schools required to design their software use to provide equal
access to users of any operating system, especially open source ones.
An experiment with the schools is probably the place to start.



From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Tue May  6 15:53:03 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Tue May  6 15:53:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Trying to jump feet first into the linux.
In-Reply-To: <1052258149.656.8.camel@farm-libranet>

Message-ID: <1052261531.577.35.camel@zadie>

On Tue, 2003-05-06 at 17:55, Marvin J. Kosmal wrote:

> I can't find any numbers that look like that.
> 
> Or is that
> 
> Bus 0, device #, Function #
> 
> Mine does not show my AGP card.
> 
> Should it???

> 
> TIA
> 
> Marvin

It is indeed bus, device, function

if you type

less /proc/pci

you should find a section with the words VGA in it. Mine, for an AGP
video card (a Matrox G400), says this:

  Bus  1, device   0, function  0:
    VGA compatible controller: Matrox Graphics, Inc. MGA G400 AGP (rev
3).
      IRQ 10.
      Master Capable.  Latency=32.  Min Gnt=16.Max Lat=32.
      Prefetchable 32 bit memory at 0xe4000000 [0xe5ffffff].
      Non-prefetchable 32 bit memory at 0xe6000000 [0xe6003fff].
      Non-prefetchable 32 bit memory at 0xe7000000 [0xe77fffff].

In this case, I put in:

PCI:1:0:0

(I believe all AGP cards are found on the PCI bus, for some strange
reason. That may just be some of them, though.)

If that doesn't have it, you might check in /proc/bus and see if there's
an agp directory which might have that type of information.

Jeff

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Tue May  6 18:12:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Tue May  6 18:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Compiling the kernel with new drivers
In-Reply-To: <39246.12.47.207.251.1052237995.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <46092.12.47.207.251.1052182882.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
	 <1052183818.13143.279.camel@main>
	 <39246.12.47.207.251.1052237995.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <1052269923.1436.15.camel@main>

On Tue, 2003-05-06 at 09:19, m at pdxlug.org wrote:
> >
> > You might not need to recompile the kernel. Is module support enabled
> > for your current kernel? If so all you probably need to do is get the
> > module that you received from DLink in the right spot and make a change
> > to modules.conf. Also take a look at the insmod (and associated)
> > man-pages.
> 
> Yes, thank you.  But what if I wanted to build a kernel without module
> support, for security reasons, etc.?  How would I include that driver in a
> static kernel?
> Thanks,
> ~M

here's a good place to start:

 http://linuxdocs.org/HOWTOs/Kernel-HOWTO-4.html#ss4.3

Plus there's a lot more docs and howtos out there. Surf around on
linuxdocs.org, it should yield what your looking for (or at least a link
to it). 

You'll also do well getting the source and going through "make config"
or "make menuconfig", reading through the comments and taking some
notes. Chances are the source has modules for your NIC but in case they
are not the driver source that you want you could backup the original,
in the source tree, and copy the new ones to <source tree>/drivers/net.
This driver should come with a .h and one or more .c files. Of course,
after all of this, you'll need to redo the make config and the
recompile.

Steve

--

So far I've seen no teeth to the argument for passing this bill. Speaker
Minnis raised the challenge; when she made the public claim that the
bill is "a solution looking for a problem" she stated that a problem
does not exist. Your response should be to counter her claim with
evidence that a problem actually does exist and to do so with factual
proof instead of flying mud. All of the proposals and contracts that the
state enters into are public documents, search them and see if there is
any evidence of a problem and, if evidence does exist, make a case based
on this evidence - you know, put up or shut up.

By the way, I'm a huge advocate of OSS and work really hard to
legitimize it in the data center. Unfortunately it's becoming very
apparent, and not just to me, that HB2892 is not about OSS, it's a kill
M$ crusade. Your crusade is beginning to make my efforts to legitimize
OSS increasing difficult - we're starting to get a label here folks, and
it's not a pretty one. 

Enough said, I'll go back to the technical now.

Message-ID: <001301c31152$09401150$1400a8c0@gamma>

All in all Folks...

If you experience a "Shortened life" on your battery with a laptop, go
back to the manufacturer and see if they have a "Battery Reconditioning"
Program.

Dell has them, Gateway has them, Toshiba has them, and I imagine several
other laptop manufacturers DO have them. They're free programs to
download.

(If you think it's a HOAX then don't download the programs!!)
(Yes, its MS based... Ugggh!!)

Piet

P.S. Yes, I have used the program... and yes I did get quite a bit more
"Battery Usage" out of one charge.

On Wed, 7 May 2003, David Pool wrote:

> David Mandel made the editorial page today.
> 
> http://www.oregonlive.com/letters/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/editorial/1052309336198981.xml
 
  Just a thought: what if someone tracked software RFPs (Requests for Proposals)
and assembled a group to bid on each one using open source software? There
_are_ costs associated with the acquisition: installation, training, support
and others of which I am ignorant.

  Those in the Un/Under-employed SIG could bid on the specifications. As the
software itself has no direct cost, the total package price should be at the
low end of the bid range. As long as the experience and skills of the team
can fulfill the department's/agency's needs, why not go for it and generate
some income at the same time -- if you're successful?

  If you have the time in your job search to do the initial footwork, get to
know the IT purchase decision makers starting _now_. You're not selling them
anything at this point but getting to know their needs and idiosyncracies
and they're getting to know you. If you have established a solid rapport in
advance you'll find that you get a fair and considered look at your
proposal. If it just lands on someone's desk and they don't know you from an
old keyboard you don't stand a chance.

  Think of it as a part-time job or enhancing your marketable skills.

:-)

>  
>   Just a thought: what if someone tracked software RFPs (Requests for Proposals)
> and assembled a group to bid on each one using open source software? There
> _are_ costs associated with the acquisition: installation, training, support
> and others of which I am ignorant.


This is not an easy task.  I do bid on RFP's and they are a heinous
process.  Often the responses are well over 100 pages and most of that
is busy work.  Sometime I put more work into the RFPs than the contract
length.

Tracking RFPs is a bit of an art as well.

Also there is a fair amount of paperwork involved, not the least of
which is to be preregistered with the state often.

Also most RFPs I see are for work, not product.  Often the products *are
already chosen*.  Thus one of the reasons for the Bill.

Having said that, if people see an RFP they would like to Bid on, I can
review it and see if we could Bid on it using my companies' resources.

>

Actually, this AEA guy is on our side on another issue: The Super DMCA
bill (SB 655).

I took a look at the link that someone posted yesterday to the AEA site
and found:

"Earlier this year, in at least a dozen states across the country, the
Motion Picture Association of America introduced legislation designed to
crack down on those who pilfer intellectual property over cable and other
communication services. Problem with the model bill as introduced was that
it unintentionally had the potential to criminalize the manufacture of any
and all devices and software used for prohibited purposes, even if they
were never meant for prohibited purposes. AeA and many other trade groups
assembled two weeks ago in Washington, DC, with the MPAA to discuss the
fears and draft amendments that ensure the bill only applies to equipment
intended primarily for stealing service, not all computers and software
"capable of" such theft.

The Oregon bill is SB 655, which has only had a brief hearing so far in
the Senate Judiciary Committee. The MPAA lobbyist in Oregon has agreed to
the AeA amendments and the bill is being redrafted. It's still not clear
whether it will make it through the process, even in the amended form."

from: http://www.aeanet.org/PressRoom/oras_govtaffairs_update_week14.asp

...so maybe the AEA isn't all bad...

Phil

Jim Craven, Oregon lobbyist for the American Electronics Association, said
his clients' chief concerns were addressed by two provisions in the House

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed May  7 16:47:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed May  7 16:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Usage of pidof vs killall5
In-Reply-To: <E19DXyC-0001f0-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <E19DXyC-0001f0-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <1052351200.1161.26.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Wed, 2003-05-07 at 16:05, Russell Evans wrote:
> pidof is a link to killall5 on my box. The man page for pidof says this is how
> it's supposed to be.
> 
> If I do pidof process; I get a pid number returned, if that process is running.
> Doing a `killall5 process` returns an error message; killall5: only one
> argument, a signal number, allowed. 
> 
> So a link is a link, correct? So why does killall5 act differently than pidof? 

Because a program can check the name it is called with and behave
differently given the name.  For example, /bin/gzip and /bin/gunzip are
links (they're hard-links on my system, but that doesn't change their
process name; they can just as easily be symlinks).

killall5 simulates the killall command of SysV UNIX; it sends the given
signal to all processes owned by the calling UID.  When does it root, it
can do very bad things.  BE VERY CAREFUL with the killall command on
!(Linux || BSD) systems!

Wil
--

Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Wed May  7 16:53:03 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Wed May  7 16:53:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Usage of pidof vs killall5
In-Reply-To: <E19DXyC-0001f0-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <E19DXyC-0001f0-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <1052351494.576.39.camel@zadie>

On Wed, 2003-05-07 at 19:05, Russell Evans wrote:
> pidof is a link to killall5 on my box. The man page for pidof says this is how
> it's supposed to be.
> 
> If I do pidof process; I get a pid number returned, if that process is running.
> Doing a `killall5 process` returns an error message; killall5: only one
> argument, a signal number, allowed. 
> 
> So a link is a link, correct? So why does killall5 act differently than pidof? 

not exactly. While I admit I don't know a thing about pidof vs.
killall5, I can tell you a link is not exactly a link:

in most linux distributions, /bin/sh is a link to /bin/bash. However,
bash checks to see if it's been called as /bin/sh, and if so, dumps some
of its bash functionality so as to be perfectly sh compatible (or very
close).

In MacOSX, the same thing, but with /bin/csh is a link to /bin/tcsh.

Jeff

> Thank you
> Russell

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed May  7 17:44:02 2003
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)

On Wed, 7 May 2003, Steve Bonds 1s7k8uhcd001-at-sneakemail.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Strange things can happen when browsers try to guess what you meant to
> say.  Malformed HTML somewhere else in the document could have caused
> a rendering error in the list, even if the list was fine.
> 
> What page was broken?  What does http://validator.w3.org/ say about
> the page?

I found the page (http://www.jonjacob.org/).  My guess is that this HTML
probably confused IE:

-----
<p><font size="+1" face="Helvetica">
   <b>My Positions in a nutshell:</b></p></font>
-----

The <font> tag is opened after the <p>, but <p> is closed before </font>.  
Many browsers get real confused by this "crossing" of HTML tags.

Also, the <b> before <li> might be confusing IE.  Put the <b> inside the
<li> item.

Your best bet is to run this (and any other public-facing document)
through the w3.org validator.  It's a pain, but you can be reasonably
assured that if it doesn't render right, it's someone else's problem.  
;-)

Overall, your HTML looks very good.  Much better than the usual
export-from-MS-Word crap out there.  The attached HTML file should look
the same, and is squeaky-clean 4.01 Transitional HTML.

  -- Steve

In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCOEBMCKAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
