Hey Billy,
If you have perl 5.8 than I don't think that you'll need to reinstall
perl. The modules that your talking about are perl modules and they can
be installed from CPAN. You can get them by running perl -MCPAN -e shell
as root and doing install <modulename> from the cpan prompt. If for some
reason you want to install perl you can do that from here as well. The
modules that it is probably wanting are DBD and DBI for MySQL.

Steve

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu May  8 08:27:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu May  8 08:27:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Perl Modules Problem
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCOEBMCKAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305080816280.21037-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 8 May 2003, Billy Dimaculangan wrote:

> I'm installing request tracker and it require perl,perl modules and
> mysql. I'm having problems with the perl modules that is currently
> installed. How do I reinstall perl and automatically include all
> thos perl modules?  How do I do it?

Dude, I feel your pain.

Building RT is an exercise in what can only be called the Perl analog
to DLL hell. In addition to installing a ton of Red Hat's prebuilt
perl-* packages, I ended up building over 40 home-brewed rpms.

If you're on an rpm-based system (Red Hat, SuSE, Mandrake), cpan2rpm 
can be a life saver:

  http://sourceforge.net/projects/cpan2rpm/

If, on the other hand, you're not concerned about being able to 
reinstall all those modules on another host, I think RT includes a 
perl script (the name escapes me) that will bring your system up to 
date.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

* Billy Dimaculangan <bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph> [2003-05-07 19:32]:
> I?m installing request tracker and it require perl,perl modules and mysql.
> I?m having problems with the perl modules that is currently installed. How
> do I reinstall perl and automatically include all thos perl modules?  How do
> I do it?

In addition to the excellent advice you received earlier, I would
recommend joining the rt-users mailing list. I'm a member of that one,
and it is very active and helps folks get RT up and running all the
time. 

Make sure you are very specific about the problem. Give as much
information as you can. i.e. What module you are installing that's
having a problem, what the error is, and so forth. 

Including the version of RT, perl, apache, and mySQL that you're using
are good too. 

The RT mailing list is listed here:
http://www.bestpractical.com/rt/lists.html

You may be able to find the answer to your question in the mailing list
archives, which are also available on that page. 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Thu May  8 23:23:01 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Thu May  8 23:23:01 2003
Subject: xtricks Re: [PLUG] XF86Config with 2 monitors?
In-Reply-To: <32955.192.168.1.243.1052453371.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com>
References: <32955.192.168.1.243.1052453371.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com>
Message-ID: <20030509062256.GA5397@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Thu, May 08, 2003 at 09:09:31PM -0700, Robby Russell wrote:
> I am trying to get my dual video cards and dual monitors to work.
> Can anyone give me any tips? it's possible that the PCI info for the 128
> isn't right.
> 


Once you do get it working (I cant offer any more advice than has been
given..) you may not be able to load dri and xinerama at the same
time, or if you just want to play with X..

You can set up multiple ServerLayout sections, with different
identifiers and choose your layout when you run startx,

$ startx -- -layout "single-head" 
for example.

You can alse start up additional xservers with --:n where n increments
with the number of xservers (starting at 0). 

so, if you want to run xinerama and a single-head (or just, not
xinerama) simeotaneously you can start the second server with:

$ startx --:1 -layout "single-head"

where single-head is the identifier of the layout you want (it
defaults to the first layout in your xconfig file.

Here are two layouts from my box, if anyone wants to see syntax.


Section "ServerLayout"
        Identifier      "xinerama"
        Screen          "Screen 0" LeftOf "Screen 1"
        Screen          "Screen 1" 0 0
        InputDevice     "Generic Keyboard"
        InputDevice     "Configured Mouse"
        Option          "xinerama"
EndSection


Section "ServerLayout"
        Identifier      "single-head"
        Screen "Screen 0"
        InputDevice     "Generic Keyboard"
        InputDevice     "Configured Mouse"
EndSection



On a related note.. does anyone know if it is possible to have dri and
xinerama with a G400? (I also hear AA fonts are better behaved in
X4.3... :)

-Rogan

From paul at lankow.net  Fri May  9 07:13:02 2003
From: paul at lankow.net (Paul)
Date: Fri May  9 07:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] True Type fonts in RH9
Message-ID: <4572.192.168.1.252.1052489516.squirrel@localhost>

Has anyone else had trouble getting True Type fonts to register in Red
Hat 9.0? With 7 and 8 I could do the following, and boom, it's done:

chkfontpath --add /directory/fonts/are/in
ttmkfdir -o fonts.scale
mkfontdir

In RH9, the fonts don't list in Mozilla. They DO list in Galeon, but if
you select them, a different font is substituted. Anyone figured this
out? I've search the Red Hat site, and can only find instructions for 7.

Thanks!
Paul

---
email: paul at lankow.net
http://paul.lankow.net



From stever at woo-hoo.com  Fri May  9 09:12:02 2003
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Fri May  9 09:12:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] True Type fonts in RH9
In-Reply-To: <4572.192.168.1.252.1052489516.squirrel@localhost>
References: <4572.192.168.1.252.1052489516.squirrel@localhost>
Message-ID: <46346.207.173.0.68.1052496696.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

Try this procedure, it works for me on RH9:

1) Become root

2) follow directions:

host# mkdir /usr/share/fonts/ttf
host# cd /usr/share/fonts/ttf
host# cp <ttf_font_locale>/*.ttf ./
host# mkfontdir
host# ttmkfdir -o fonts.scale
host# cd ..
host# fc-cache .

3) restart X-server

4) all done.

Regards!

> Has anyone else had trouble getting True Type fonts to register in Red
> Hat 9.0? With 7 and 8 I could do the following, and boom, it's done:
>
> chkfontpath --add /directory/fonts/are/in
> ttmkfdir -o fonts.scale
> mkfontdir

Subject: [PLUG] CSS question (scripting?)

I've been doing some work with CSS styles; and it seems that the best way to do
it, in general, is to link webpages to external stylesheets. I'm trying to get
some consistency on my home site, and it's "inconvenient" to search and replace
for 5 instances of the same color to replace it with another color. Here it's a
link color, there it's a border. 

 If I associate *.css files with php in apache (in the .htaccess file, for
instance), I could use variables within them, right? Then I could modify the
variable at the top and have it replaced all through out the stylesheet. Is that
the best way to do it? 

Or would it be better to write a "stylesheet.inc" file that I'd use like
"include("stylesheet.inc")" and it'd show up as inline- it'd wind up being the
same, functionally, wouldn't it? 

And is there someone I should talk to about bringing my PC to the meeting on the
17th to get some help upgrading my old slackware to shiny clean debian? I have
some CDs. 
-Russ



From shahms at shahms.com  Fri May  9 10:18:01 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Fri May  9 10:18:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CSS question (scripting?)
In-Reply-To: <E19EBOo-0008Em-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <E19EBOo-0008Em-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <1052500597.4545.12.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Fri, 2003-05-09 at 10:10, gilmanhunt at attbi.com wrote:
> I've been doing some work with CSS styles; and it seems that the best way to do
> it, in general, is to link webpages to external stylesheets. I'm trying to get
> some consistency on my home site, and it's "inconvenient" to search and replace
> for 5 instances of the same color to replace it with another color. Here it's a
> link color, there it's a border. 
> 
>  If I associate *.css files with php in apache (in the .htaccess file, for
> instance), I could use variables within them, right? Then I could modify the
> variable at the top and have it replaced all through out the stylesheet. Is that
> the best way to do it? 

Yes, however, if you're going to go this route I *highly* recommend just
naming your css files .css.php instead.  Also, if you do this, you'll
need to remember to set the Content-Type header to text/css in the PHP
code. (header("Content-Type","text/css"), I believe).

> Or would it be better to write a "stylesheet.inc" file that I'd use like
> "include("stylesheet.inc")" and it'd show up as inline- it'd wind up being the
> same, functionally, wouldn't it? 

This is the other alternative, and is probably better than having PHP
process all of your CSS files.  Additionally, this allows you to set up
the actual style in an external stylesheet and only specify colors
inline.

> 
> And is there someone I should talk to about bringing my PC to the meeting on the
> 17th to get some help upgrading my old slackware to shiny clean debian? I have
> some CDs. 
> -Russ

From linux at chrisroberts.org  Fri May  9 10:23:02 2003
From: linux at chrisroberts.org (chris)
Date: Fri May  9 10:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CSS question (scripting?)
In-Reply-To: <E19EBOo-0008Em-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <E19EBOo-0008Em-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200305091024.29355.linux@chrisroberts.org>

well, you can use if you just dynamically add your css to the top of every 
page, then you can set up a very simple template for your css. just put 
%color% in place of where the color should go in your css file and read the 
file into a variable. then take that string and run str_replace to replace 
all instances of %color% with the color you would like. then shove it into 
your page. you could also have a template stored to read in, change the do 
the replacement, then write it back out to the location of the actual css 
file.

chris

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri May  9 11:20:02 2003
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri May  9 11:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CSS question (scripting?)

Message-ID: <1052504374.14231.1250.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Fri, 2003-05-09 at 10:15, Rob Hudson wrote:
> Once I tried setting up a stylesheet that was a PHP script.  So I had
> this:
> <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.php" type="text/css">
> 
> And my style.php would print CSS stuff, to do things similar to what
> you're talking about.  But for some reason it wouldn't work correctly.
> I never did investigate to find out why.

Depending on how long ago it was, it might have been because browsers
had lousy support for CSS.  Netscape 4 and older versions of IE make it
nearly impossible.  These days, CSS works pretty well with Mozilla and
derivatives, Opera, and to a limited extent, IE.  (For example, IE seems
to ignore width: but will use max-width:.)

It might have also been that your MIME-type wasn't being set in the HTTP
header; I'm not sure how the type attribute from the link element
affects it.

Wil

From shahms at shahms.com  Fri May  9 11:24:02 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Fri May  9 11:24:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CSS question (scripting?)
In-Reply-To: <1052504374.14231.1250.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <E19EBOo-0008Em-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
	 <20030509101535.D29838@cogit8.org>
	 <1052504374.14231.1250.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1052504576.4545.17.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

> It might have also been that your MIME-type wasn't being set in the HTTP
> header; I'm not sure how the type attribute from the link element
> affects it.
> 
> Wil

At this point, it's mostly a "hint" to the browser, which it largely
ignores.  Mozilla will print a warning in the JavaScript console if the
type attribute and the Content-Type header of a file don't match, but it
will pretend that the type attribute has the correct information and
proceed.

-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

I've been using Nola from Noguska, its an Apache-MySQL-PHP application. 
It is open source (OSI certified - GNU license, but check the licenses
of dependant libraries), and Noguska is willing to customize - help (for
a fee, of course).  I haven't been using it long enough to give a true
evaluation; and I've never used quickbooks, so I really can't compare,
but it is a full featured - easily modifiable accounting package.

BTW, I'm running it in User-mode linux, let me know if you want a copy
of the base system.

From pundit at teleport.com  Fri May  9 13:06:02 2003
From: pundit at teleport.com (Ken Barber)
Date: Fri May  9 13:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Texas' open source hearing
Message-ID: <200305091303.49268.pundit@teleport.com>

The Great State of Texas held hearings yesterday on their open 
source bill, SB 1579.

Texas legislators have a little more backbone than the ones in the 
committee that heard the Oregon bill.  Here's an exchange between 
Sen. John Carona (R-Dallas), the bill's sponsor, and Mario Correa 
(who also travelled to Oregon to testify against our bill) of the 
Business Software Alliance.

In his testimony, Correa was wasting the committee's time 
objecting to portions of the bill that had been removed in 
amendments (which Texas refers to as a "substitute"), when Sen. 
Carona interrupted him:

---------------------------------------------------------
Correa:  As I was saying, essentially what we're doing in this 
bill is to single out one particular type of development for 
further study, review and effectively promotion.  Now I also, as 
some of the earlier witnesses mentioned, think that studying 
these issues can be a perfectly positive thing but that's not the 
intent of this legislation.  The intent is to presuppose cost 
savings by one particular model of software development.  Now, in 
some cases open source software can save money; in other cases it 
doesn't.  As the witnesses mentioned the cost of software is 
primarily in its upkeep and maintenance and training.  It's not 
in the actual initial costs of acquisition.  So in acquiring 
software for free at the inception this does not mean that 
software will over the long term will be less costly. Now, folks 
at the Department of Information Resources know that as well as 
they know many other information technology issues that arise 
before them and that's why they currently have the ability to 
procure the kinds of software that makes sense to them and to 
conduct the kinds of investigations that they think makes sense 
in terms of their resources.  I don't think that this bill gives 
them a power that they don't currently have but rather seeks to 
set one model above others.  I don't...

[Sen. Carona signals the Chair]  

Chair:  Senator Carona?

Carona:  Sir, have you read the five lines of this committee 
substitute?  

Correa:  I believe I have sir, in fact...

Carona:  Do you know that all it says is, "Shall publish 
guidelines relating to the information a state agency must 
consider in determining whether the agency should acquire open 
source software products in addition to proprietary software."  
Now, what are you threatened by?

Correa:  Well, I understand, Senator, that you left out a previous 
section in the latest iteration.  The previous section talked 
about how the report must include the department's 
recommendations that effectively...

Carona:  That's not...

Correa:  That's no longer... that's correct.  But the point that 
I'm trying to make is, essentially what you've done is to isolate 
one particular development of software for further investigation, 
assuming that there isn't something already being considered or 
the State has already undertaken.  What makes our industry 
nervous is not that you study any particular type but rather that 
you select one under a presupposition of cost savings or not cost 
savings for that matter.

Carona:  Well, if you'll read the language again, we have already 
presupposed that proprietary software will exist and will be 
what's purchased.  This simply says shall we consider any other 
alternatives?  That means specifically... 

I don't...  Again, I don't understand why you all are so 
threatened by this, but from a careful look at the lobbyists in 
this room that are representing Microsoft, and all of you here 
representing proprietary software companies which -- let's face 
it, that's where the big money is, it's not in Open Source it's 
in proprietary -- it's rather transparent as to why you all feel 
so threatened by this language.  And I'll tell you, this [bill] 
is innocuous, but next session I'll be on a crusade.  

Correa:  Thank you.

Carona:  Any further testimony, Mr. Correa?

Correa:  Uh, that's all right.

Carona:  Thank you for being here today.

And that was the end of of the BSA's BS in the Texas State 
Legislature.  My opinion of Texans has just increased by an order 
of magnitude.

A recording of this can be heard at 
http://www.Senate.state.tx.us/ram/archive/2003/may/050803StAffpm.ram

This exchange occurred about one hour and 28 minutes into the 
recording.

Ken

From dpool at hevanet.com  Fri May  9 14:01:02 2003
From: dpool at hevanet.com (David Pool)
Date: Fri May  9 14:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Minnis answers questions at City Club
Message-ID: <3EBC1722.8000700@hevanet.com>

Karen Minnis gave a speech at the Portland City Club today. The first question 
following her talk was about measure 2892. It went roughly like this:

"I appreciate your addressing themes of fiscal reponsibility and doing more with 
the money we send to Salem. My question concerns HB 2892 which would require 
state agencies to consider Open Source software potentially saving tens of 
millions of dollars.

In Tuesday's Oregonian you called this bill a solution searching for a problem. 
Meanwhile, Oregon's "Perfect Storm" is cutting days from our school year, 
cutting people off of medical benefits and is cutting felons loose from our 
jails. In the sense that this bill would save tens of millions of dollars, it is 
a solution that has found a problem.

My question is Please, for the sake of all Oregonians, will you bring this bill 
to the floor of the house for an open debate?"

Her response talked about agencies already being able to choose open source and 
how the bill had missed some kind of procedural deadline.

My follow-up question was roughly "With all due respect, I understand that 
they're allowed to save us money, i'm suggesting that we should pass a law that 
makes them actively consider doing so, especially if we are looking under every 
rock to find money like you say"

Her response shifted the debate by claiming that the money savings weren't clear 
and that this had been debated in the committee.

I closed with the comment that I'd really like to see that debate take place on 
the floor of the house.

I believe this will be aired on Oregon Public Radio 91.5 FM Tuesday at Noon.

d

-----Original Message-----
From: owner-lug at peak.org [mailto:owner-lug at peak.org]On Behalf Of David
Pool
Sent: Friday, May 09, 2003 2:01 PM
To: PLUG Mailing List; Eugene Lug; pdx pm
Subject: [lug] Minnis answers questions at City Club


Karen Minnis gave a speech at the Portland City Club today. The first
question
following her talk was about measure 2892. It went roughly like this:

"I appreciate your addressing themes of fiscal reponsibility and doing more
with
the money we send to Salem. My question concerns HB 2892 which would require
state agencies to consider Open Source software potentially saving tens of
millions of dollars.

In Tuesday's Oregonian you called this bill a solution searching for a
problem.
Meanwhile, Oregon's "Perfect Storm" is cutting days from our school year,
cutting people off of medical benefits and is cutting felons loose from our
jails. In the sense that this bill would save tens of millions of dollars,
it is
a solution that has found a problem.

My question is Please, for the sake of all Oregonians, will you bring this
bill
to the floor of the house for an open debate?"

Her response talked about agencies already being able to choose open source
and
how the bill had missed some kind of procedural deadline.

My follow-up question was roughly "With all due respect, I understand that
they're allowed to save us money, i'm suggesting that we should pass a law
that
makes them actively consider doing so, especially if we are looking under
every
rock to find money like you say"

Her response shifted the debate by claiming that the money savings weren't
clear
and that this had been debated in the committee.

I closed with the comment that I'd really like to see that debate take place
on
the floor of the house.

I believe this will be aired on Oregon Public Radio 91.5 FM Tuesday at Noon.

d

>>>>> "djp" == Petcher, Danielx J <danielx.j.petcher at intel.com> writes:

djp> SUGGESTION: Either SCSI or Serial is the way to go, but either
djp> way will require an odd-ball cable.

djp> SCSI: There is a SCSI connector on the back of the laptop with a
djp> bunch of high-density pins in a rectangular array. Back when
djp> PowerBook 180c was a current machine, there were third party
djp> vendors who made an adapter that would convert this to a DB-25
djp> (SCSI 1) connector. Particularly clever third party vendors made
djp> an adapter with a little switch on it. When you leave the switch
djp> in normal position, the PowerBook could communicate with SCSI
djp> peripherals. In the other position, the PowerBook would boot into
djp> a mode where it acted as a plain-old Macintosh SCSI disk drive. I
djp> don't know where you can find this adapter today, but I'll check
djp> my personal tool-box to see if I still have mine. There were also
djp> a few folks who sold SCSI drive boxes and power bricks that would
djp> enclose a PowerBook drive and give it a standard 50-pin Amphenol
djp> (SCSI 1) connector or two. I used to have one of these, but I
djp> sold it to a neighbor. She has upgraded her system a few times
djp> since then and I don't know where the enclosure has gone.

Digging around in my junk drawer, I discovered that I actually have
one of these SCSI connectors, and a 25-pin to 50-pin SCSI cable.  I
don't quite understand the significance of the switch, but with it
"off" it seems to "work".  Says:

   "SCSI  DOCK"
    off    on

I have an external SCSI disk connected, which isn't going to give me
networking, but at least it'll give me a way to get large files onto
it.

I actually have it _almost_ working.  Just trying to find a kernel
that works right now.  With the prebuilt ones on the sourceforge site:

  <http://sourceforge.net/project/showfiles.php?group_id=11666>

and a debian root.bin, with their 2.2.25 kernel, I can boot to a
"System Installation" screen, but the keyboard is dead.  With their
2.4.1 kernel, I get happier looking boot messages, but it doesn't seem
to get past:

   [...bunch of stuff...]
   RAMDISK: Compressed images found at block 0
   [...scrolls too fast...]
   scsi0:
     Vendor: QUANTUM   Model: GO160S            Rev: 2.86
     Type:   Direct-Access                      ANSI SCSI revision: 02
     Vendor: SEAGATE   Model: ST15150N          Rev: 0017
     Type:   Direct-Access                      ANSI SCSI revision: 02
   Detected scsi disk sda at scsi0, channel 0, id 0, lun 0
   Detected scsi disk sdb at scsi0, channel 0, id 5, lun 0
   SCSI decice sda: 329896 512-byte hdwr sectors (169 MG)
   Partition check:
    sda: [mac] sda1 sda2 sda3 sda4
   SCSI device sdb: 8388315 512-byte hdwr sectors (4295 MB)
    sdb: unknown partition table
   adb: PMU 68K driver v0.8 for Unified ADB.
   ADB keyboard at 2, handler 1
   ADB mouse at 3, handler set to 2
   NET4: Linux TCP/IP 1.0 for NET4.0
   IP Protocols: ICMP, UDP, TCP, IGMP
   kmem_create: Forcing size word alignment - ip_dst_cache
   IP: routing cache hash table of 512 buckets, 4Kbytes
   TCP: Hash tables configured (established 512 bind 512)
   NET4: Unix domain sockets 1.0/SMP for Linux NET4.0
   kmem_create: Forcing size word alignment - nfs_write_data
   kmem_create: Forcing size word alignment - nfs_read_data
   VFS: Mounted root (ext2 filesystem).
   [blinking cursor]

I don't understand what the ADB is.  Maybe I'll need to try
cross-compiling my own kernel.

On Tue, May 06, 2003 at 12:03:28PM -0700, Bill Barry wrote:
> 
> > How do you install Knoppix permanently?
> 
> Essentially it is a matter of copying the cd to the hard disk.
> It is described in the Knoppix FAQ
> http://download.linuxtag.org/knoppix/KNOPPIX-FAQ-EN.txt
> 
> I haven't tried this and therefore could not say whether
> or not it is a good idea.

As a previous poster mentioned, there's a script included on the Knoppix
ISO that makes it a pretty simple matter to copy the image onto your
local hard drive. You'll need to know a few basic things about Linux,
such as how to partition your drive. Other than that, it's pretty much
auto-pilot. It was by far the easiest OS install I've ever done, and
I've done many (including Windoze and MacOS).

The only issues I had with Knoppix after copying it to a local drive
were with KDE user settings. Stuff like language preferences, and a few
Open Office path settings had to be modified.


Paul

From pem at nellump.net  Sat May 10 13:49:02 2003
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Sat May 10 13:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] data transfer to a ethernet-less Mac powerbook 180c?
In-Reply-To: <8665ojgh70.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C06A9D77A@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com> <8665ojgh70.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <20030510204751.GC466@nellump.net>

On Sat, May 10, 2003 at 04:43:47AM -0700, Russell Senior wrote:
> 
> Digging around in my junk drawer, I discovered that I actually have
> one of these SCSI connectors, and a 25-pin to 50-pin SCSI cable.  I
> don't quite understand the significance of the switch, but with it
> "off" it seems to "work".  Says:

Well, the guy you quoted explains it pretty well. Old SCSI-based
PowerBooks had an extra pin on their odd-ball SCSI port. If the cable
you used had that pin present, then the PowerBook would enter "SCSI
target" mode and act as an external SCSI device to whatever it was
plugged into. Without the pin, it was the host and whatever was on the
other end would be, well, itself.

> I actually have it _almost_ working.  Just trying to find a kernel
> that works right now.  With the prebuilt ones on the sourceforge site:

I can't offer much help with kernel issues. I've only installed Linux on
PPC Macs, and didn't even know someone was still attempting a 68k port
(beyond the all-but-dead MkLinux project). NetBSD is supposed to work
pretty well on 68k hardware, though. :-)

> I don't understand what the ADB is.  Maybe I'll need to try
> cross-compiling my own kernel.

ADB is the "Apple Desktop Bus." It's what Apple used for HID stuff
(keyboards, mice, etc.) for many years. Looking at your kernel messages,
it's not immediately apparent what's causing it to freeze. 


Paul




From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Sat May 10 14:59:02 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Sat May 10 14:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] data transfer to a ethernet-less Mac powerbook 180c?
Message-ID: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C06A9D77A@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com>

Ahhh.... Finally here is something to which I can apply my old Mac
experience. The Powerbook 180c is an ancient laptop with some nice
engineering and some serious headaches for the Linux enthusiast.

SUMMARY:
Russell Senior [mailto:seniorr at aracnet.com] wants to move data onto it and
he's gotten part-way through booting Linux, but the kernel panics when it
can't find a filesystem.

Steve Bonds [1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com] suggested a parallel port IP link,
but the machine lacks a parallel port. He also suggested tar/gzip + split +
a couple of floppies, but this seems painful.

Rogan Creswick creswick at cs.orst.edu suggested pcmcia or a hard drive
transplant, but Russell responded that the machine lacks pcmcia.

The hard drive is SCSI and it can be removed with appropriate tools. It's
got a funny sort of SCSI connector that may make things difficult to connect
to a desktop machine. If the hard drive is still in a Macintosh format, you
may have further difficulty mounting the HFS filesystem. Other items in your
post make it appear as though this is not the problem.

Rich Shepard [rshepard at appl-ecosys.com] suggested building SLIP into the
kernel, but that would require a Macintosh high-speed modem cable to change
from the Din-8 RS-449 serial connector on the Mac to some DB25 or DB9 Serial
RS-232 connection used by the rest of the civilized world.

SUGGESTION:
Either SCSI or Serial is the way to go, but either way will require an
odd-ball cable.

SCSI: There is a SCSI connector on the back of the laptop with a bunch of
high-density pins in a rectangular array. Back when PowerBook 180c was a
current machine, there were third party vendors who made an adapter that
would convert this to a DB-25 (SCSI 1) connector. Particularly clever third
party vendors made an adapter with a little switch on it. When you leave the
switch in normal position, the PowerBook could communicate with SCSI
peripherals. In the other position, the PowerBook would boot into a mode
where it acted as a plain-old Macintosh SCSI disk drive. I don't know where
you can find this adapter today, but I'll check my personal tool-box to see
if I still have mine. There were also a few folks who sold  SCSI drive boxes
and power bricks that would enclose a PowerBook drive and give it a standard
50-pin Amphenol (SCSI 1) connector or two. I used to have one of these, but
I sold it to a neighbor. She has upgraded her system a few times since then
and I don't know where the enclosure has gone.

Serial:
Traveling Software made a product called LapLink Mac for transferring data
over the serial cable between a Macintosh and a DOS- or Windows-based PC.
The required cable was included with the software. I don't know if they are
still in business or not, nor do I know if they still sell this product. I
have kept my copy of this software, but it requires the Macintosh OS
(probably 6.x or 7.x) on the Mac side and DOS or Windows on the PC side.
Still, the cable may be valuable for serial-port redirection.

FreeGeek.org may have either or both of these adapters in its junk-drawer,
since they often receive odd-ball stuff. They also have contact with some
other organization that refurbishes/recycles used Macintoshes. This other
group may have some clues for you. If nobody else has a magic bullet, let me
know and I can arrange a face-to-face so that you may borrow one or more of
these adapters.

-djp
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

Well, I haven't solved the booting problem, but I have prepared an
external SCSI disk, which is "ready to go".  Also, I managed to cobble
together a null-modem cable out of what must have been an external
modem cable and an old laplink cable, the kind with both 9-pin and
25-pin connectors at each end, which allowed me to connect to the
25-pin cable end and the 9-pin connection at the other computer.  I am
currently using zmodem to move the 6meg macinstall.tar.gz file over.
With this rig, though, I don't seem to have hardware handshaking
(turned on XON/XOFF instead), and line noise is killing me at 57600,
so I had to drop back to 38400, and even there I was getting periodic
CRC errors.  Getting about 3kbytes/second.

Can someone suggest a source for Mac-to-9-pin null-modem cables,
preferably that will support hardware handshaking?  

I think I'll end up connecting the box with PPP over a null-modem to
my router.  The null-modem will be slower than I'm used to, but faster
than over a phone line.  The router box already got 4 IP interfaces
(not counting "lo"), so why not a fifth, right?

From hapibeli at attbi.com  Sun May 11 07:50:03 2003

Subject: [PLUG] /etc/grub.conf dual boot
Message-ID: <1052664567.1177.16.camel@localhost.localdomain>

My /boot/grub/device.map = 

(fd0)     /dev/fd0
(hd0)     /dev/hda
(hd1)     /dev/hdb

To dual boot RH9[hda] and Win98[hdb], my current /boot/grub.conf looks
like;
#boot=/dev/hda
default=0
timeout=10
splashimage=(hd0,0)/grub/splash.xpm.gz
title Red Hat Linux (2.4.20-9)
        root (hd0,0)
        kernel /vmlinuz-2.4.20-9 ro root=LABEL=/ hdc=ide-scsi
        initrd /initrd-2.4.20-9.img
title DOS
        rootnoverify (hd1,0)
        chainloader +1



Should title DOS look like? ;

        map (hd0,0) (hd1,0)
	map (hd1,0) (hd0,0)
	setup (hd0)
	rootnoverify (hd1,0)
	chainloader +

"It was much better to imagine men in some smoky room somewhere, made
mad and cynical by privilege and power, plotting over the brandy. You
had to cling to this sort of image because if you didn't you would have
to face the fact that ordinary people, the kind who brushed the dog and
told their children bed time stories, were capable of then going out and
doing horrible things to other ordinary people. It was so much easier to
blame it on "them." It was bleakly depressing to think that they were
"us." If it was "them" then nothing was anyone's fault. If it was "us"
then what did that make "me?"  After all, I am one of "us." I have
certainly never thought of myself as one of "them." No one ever thinks
of themselves as one of "them." We are always one of "us." It's always
"them" that does the bad things." - from "Jingo" by Terry Pratchett

As one who as been called "off-topic" on more than one occasion, I think I
can help you understand why this is off topic.

This list is for getting help, and helping other to use, run, configure,
any of the different *nix type OSes. This includes, but is not limited to,
Linux, HP-UX, AIX, Solaris, *BSD, Tru64, and Irix.

It is not a political list. It is not a vi vs emacs list.

I've also heard it said that when people start complaining about any
particular topic, that topic is automatically off-topic. Sort of like
invoking Godwin's Law, without the Nazi/Hitler part.
(http://info.astrian.net/jargon/terms/g/Godwin_s_Law.html)

Plug has a list for "off-topic" discussions. plug-talk at pdxlinux.org. It's
very quiet right now.

If I'm incorrect, I'm sure I'll be corrected within seconds of this
posting. :)

Russ Johnson
http://www.dimstar.net

Fry's has a decent selection of RJ45-to-[your_favorite_connector_here]

Subject: another Oregon issue

Not about open source ... do you know anybody in Oregon that is
 interested in fighting the Super DMCA there?  You may have read
 about it ... the MPAA is going state-by-state trying to get this
 really nasty law against doing anything your network service
 provider doesn't expressly allow.

We (EFF-Austin) are making some progress here in Texas.  If there
 are some people in Oregon who are interested in doing the same,
 we can pass along some of what we learned.

From montagne at boora.com  Mon May 12 10:32:01 2003
From: montagne at boora.com (Michael Montagne)
Date: Mon May 12 10:32:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] smtp multiple recipient problem
Message-ID: <20030512173143.GA31119@boora.com>

I use smtpd to receive mail, hand it off to a python app that runs it
through spamassasin and then sends it to our Exchange server.  I have a
problem with some emails that have multiple reipients within our domain.
The sending server times out waiting for a response to the RCPT TO: on
the second recipient, and nobody gets the mail.  I've removed the
filtering that smtpd can do to no avail.  When we send all mail directly

From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Mon May 12 10:38:02 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Mon May 12 10:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Java programmers?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305120849040.28138-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305120849040.28138-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1052760802.8941.20.camel@zadie>

On Mon, 2003-05-12 at 11:53, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Are there any java application (not applet or Web) developers here? I'm
> starting to learn the language and will be porting a C program to java but I
> have several questions about assembling the final package for distribution
> or use.
> 
>   For example, since paths are included in .jar files, what allows the
> program to be installed and run on a completely different system? 

the jar is a zip file, with the bytecode compiled classes included. If
you include the jar in your classpath and run the class in it with a
main routine, it'll work fine on a different system. There are ways to
make executing the jar find and execute java and stuff. 


> If
> applications consist of "hundreds or thousands of classes" (according to the
> ORA "Learning Java" authors), and each class has to be compiled separately,
> how the heck does one manage the project? 

Applications _can_ consist of hundreds or thousands of classes. They can
also be one or two calsses. There's no rule.

For managing huge projects, I recommend: ant, IBM Eclipse (free beer),
or your favorite Java-enabled IDE (CodeWarrior, etc). They will manage
the compilation of the projects, and turn them into jar files at your
wish. ant is open source, built by the Apache project, and works wonders
(is similar to makefiles, but cleaner).


> And, since java has
> easy-to-implement threads, can an application be built to run on
> multi-processor machines or Beowulf clusters with appropriate processes
> running in parallel?

multiprocessor machines are easy--threads are fairly good, and will run
in parallel. Beowulf clusters are harder and depend on how the cluster
is set up--if it's invisible to the program and just looks like a
multiprocessor machine, threading it should do it. If it's the standard
cheap, ssh-based beowulf cluster, then you have some work to do.

Jeff

What's the proper way to add an MX record for a subdomain?

For example:

$ttl 2D
;
@       IN      SOA     ns1.mydomain.com. hostmaster.mydomain.com. (
                2003051201      ; Serial
                21600           ; Refresh 6 hours
                900             ; Retry 15 minutes
                3600000         ; Expire
                43200           ; Default 12 hours
)

                        IN      NS      ns1.mydomain.com.
                        IN      NS      ns2.mydomain.com.

                        IN      MX      10 mail.mydomain.com.
sub1                    IN      MX      10 mail2.mydomain.com.

                        IN      A       10.10.10.1
sub1                    IN      A       10.10.10.2
sub2                    IN      A       10.10.10.3
mail                    IN      A       10.10.10.4



This, unfortunately, seems to break everything that follows the MX record
for sub1.  Do I have the syntax wrong?

From bergie at bergie.net  Mon May 12 14:53:01 2003
From: bergie at bergie.net (Jason Bergstrom)
Date: Mon May 12 14:53:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS for Dummies question
In-Reply-To: <no.id> from "m@pdxlug.org" at May 12, 2003 01:55:20 PM
Message-ID: <E19FLDE-00075K-00@bergie.net>

> >
> >>                         IN      MX      10 mail.mydomain.com.
> >> sub1                    IN      MX      10 mail2.mydomain.com.
> >
> >   Can both servers have the same rank?
> 
> They're for different sites...  mail.mydomain.com is for mydomain.com and
> mail2.mydomain.com is for sub1.mydomain.com.
> 
Yes, both servers could have the same precedence even if they were for
the same domain.

I think you want to either start the MX record for the top level
domain with an @ or mydomain.com. to indicate it is the MX for the domain
or move them near the NS records (which would require an @ if they were
moved elsewhere in the zone file).

Jason,
bergie at bergie.net

After you  set the NLS support to M, did you run 
make modules; make modules_install
to install the nls modules?
Before you do that, turn the smp back on in menuconfig. This will keep your
modules consistent with the kernel without having to recompile the kernel.

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Mon May 12 16:35:03 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Mon May 12 16:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] data transfer to a ethernet-less Mac powerbook 180c?
Message-ID: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C06A9D787@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com>

Russel Senior wrote:
> Digging around in my junk drawer, I discovered that I actually have
> one of these SCSI connectors, and a 25-pin to 50-pin SCSI cable.  I
> don't quite understand the significance of the switch, but with it
> "off" it seems to "work".  Says:
> 
>    "SCSI  DOCK"
>     off    on
> 
> I have an external SCSI disk connected, which isn't going to give me
> networking, but at least it'll give me a way to get large files onto
> it.


If you were to shut the machine down and then switch-on the SCSI Dock
switch, you would be able to connect the PowerBook to another computer as if
it were a plain-old external SCSI hard drive. It would remain in this mode
until you shut it down. This is probably the fastest way to load-up your
drive with a big file, as long as you are able to mount the filesystem.

I can't really help you any more than others already have with regard to
finding an M68k-based kernel. Others have already noted that ADB stands for
Apple Desktop Bus; it's their old (pre-USB) system for daisy-chaining
low-speed serial input devices such as mice, keyboards, and low-res
digitizing tablets.

-djp

From bergie at bergie.net  Mon May 12 17:37:01 2003
From: bergie at bergie.net (Jason Bergstrom)
Date: Mon May 12 17:37:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS for Dummies question
In-Reply-To: <no.id> from "m@pdxlug.org" at May 12, 2003 05:14:33 PM
Message-ID: <E19FNmD-0007Ct-00@bergie.net>

> OK...  this is getting really frustrating...  If I add the MX record for
> the subdomain, even if I have the @ or mydomain.com in front of the other
> MX record, I still can't resolve any of the following subdomains.  So if I
> also had foo as a subdomain, it won't show up when querying from other DNS
> servers.  Once I remove the second MX record, foo shows up (when querying
> another DNS server that hasn't already cached the previous lookup). 
> Where's Ed the DNS guy when you need him...
> So again, to review, I just want to add an MX record for one of the
> subdomains in my zone file.  Shouldn't be this difficult...
> Thanks,
> ~M

Technically you should monkey with $ORIGIN when ever you play with
subdomains.

$ORIGIN mydomain.com.

@	IN	SOA	dns.mydomain.com. hostmaster.mailserver.mydomain.com. (
		... serial/refresh/etc)
	IN	NS	dns.mydomain.com.
	IN	MX	10 mailserver.mydomain.com.
$ORIGIN subdomain.mydomain.com.
	IN	MX	10 mailserver.mydomain.com.
$ORIGIN mydomain.com.

And always watch the dots (think everything needs to be fully qualified
whether with a trailing . or by the $ORIGIN).

Jason,
bergie at bergie.net



From russj at dimstar.net  Mon May 12 18:57:01 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon May 12 18:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS for Dummies question
In-Reply-To: <14194.12.47.207.251.1052784873.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
References: <E19FLDE-00075K-00@bergie.net> <14194.12.47.207.251.1052784873.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>
Message-ID: <20030513015601.GB9153@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* m at pdxlug.org <m at pdxlug.org> [2003-05-12 17:15]:
> OK...  this is getting really frustrating...  If I add the MX record for
> the subdomain, even if I have the @ or mydomain.com in front of the other
> MX record, I still can't resolve any of the following subdomains.

I believe the subdomains MX record should be in it's own file. When you
specify an MX record, aren't you listing mail exchangers for the domain
as a whole?

Delegate that domain to it's own file, and move that domains MX record
to that file.

OR, you could do what I do. I have postfix set up to receive all the
mail for my domain and subdomains. Postfix then knows to forward mail to
certain subdomains to a different mail server.

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Mon May 12 20:10:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Mon May 12 20:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How rcpthosts under qmail works...
In-Reply-To: <1052761220.2318.49.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
References: <1052761220.2318.49.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1052795409.1438.180.camel@main>

On Mon, 2003-05-12 at 10:40, Michael C. Robinson wrote:
> I'm getting the impression that any domain that isn't under rcpthosts is
> denied, but this is awfully restrictive where I want to allow my trusted
> users to send to anywhere and anyone to be able to send to me.  Short of
> being an open relay, what option is there to make the latter happen
> transparently?
> 
> I'm guessing with smtp protocol that it doesn't know the difference
> between inbound and outbound traffic.   
> 
> I would think all you'd want to block is email not going to or coming
> from your local network plus spam/malicious email.  Wouldn't the latter
> protect against blacklisting due to being an open relay?

this is the rcpthosts files sole purpose, to control what domain(s) can
access the smtp daemon. Incoming mail is destined for users that are on
the domains listed in rcpthosts and messages that are destined for
foreign hosts originate from a domain that is listed in rcpthosts or
they are not processed by qmails smtp daemon. If your using tcpserver
you'll also need to add the trusted network segment addresses to the
active cdb by appending those addresses to /etc/tcp.smtp (or whatever
your cdb text file name and path is) and running
<qmail_bin_path>/qmailctl cdb.

> 
> Hopefully moving from kmail under Redhat 7.2 to evolution under 7.3 will
> help security wise.  I've gotten Maildir boxes going for the first time
> also :-)
> 
> I wonder if evolution reads rcpthosts where kmail seemingly didn't or
> does this file merely affect qmail?  

only qmail. The pop/imap client probably should not have access to that
file since removing the entries or deleting the file will turn your mail
server into an open relay.

> This is the first time I've ever
> removed the mail and the procmail programs.  Has anyone experimented
> with creating two home areas for their users and modifying the user
> account creation scripts to place the maildir in one area while 
> setting a user's home to the other?  Using UW-IMAP before I guess
> creating a non-login user for the imap accounts will help seperate 
> the imap files from other files.  Trouble is, I want the normal 
> account name to be the email name also.  I would like the user's
> home directory to be free of their email stuff although the .qmail
> should stay there as should any home directory stuff for qconfirm, etc.

try putting your maildirs where you would like them and use ln -s to
link from the users home.

-snip-

On Mon, 12 May 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
> > Applications _can_ consist of hundreds or thousands of classes. They can
> > also be one or two calsses. There's no rule.
>
>   True. But the jar file then becomes quite large, no?

Yes, they certainly can, but they don't have to be - you can make several
smaller jars as well.

> > For managing huge projects, I recommend: ant, IBM Eclipse (free beer),
> > or your favorite Java-enabled IDE (CodeWarrior, etc). They will manage
> > the compilation of the projects, and turn them into jar files at your
> > wish. ant is open source, built by the Apache project, and works wonders
> > (is similar to makefiles, but cleaner).
>
>   So one of these would be a better choice than emacs?

Well, personally I think pulling out my fingernails with pliers would be a
better choice than emacs, but that's just me.  Yes, eclipse/ant/etc will
keep track of class dependancies and handle all the rebuilding/rejarring
and so forth.  Ant seems to be on its way to becoming the de facto
standard make equivalent for Java projects, and eclipse can use Ant for
builds.  Ant has its own idiosyncracies - it helps to have a good
understanding of XML, and personally I find it just as annoying as
makefiles, just in different ways.

dcf at aracnet.com

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Mon May 12 23:54:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] tcl question

I'm diving headfirst into tcl with someone else's code.  Since his code 
works (just want to better it) and the books I have aren't that good, it 
makes sense to learn off this app.

Figured the breadth of knowlege here might give a quick response.

Has to do with the 'binary format' bit below.  I can't figure out why it is 
necessary & how it even works.  (I did read 'man binary' a few times).  The 
idea is to send commands to a serial attached device.  The command set is 
analogous to the Hayes AT set.

Why does 'puts' yield nothing?  And why would a device that is expecting a 
packet of hex values need a binary conversion?

#!/bin/sh
# the next line restarts using wish \
exec wish "$0" "$@"

set bin_cmd [ binary format "H2H2" 11 00 ]
puts stderr bin_cmd=$bin_cmd

exit


Cheers,
Kyle Accardi




From sandbox at pacifier.com  Tue May 13 00:45:02 2003

Kyle Accardi wrote:

> 
> Has to do with the 'binary format' bit below.  I can't figure out why it 
> is necessary & how it even works.  (I did read 'man binary' a few 
> times).  The idea is to send commands to a serial attached device.  The 
> command set is analogous to the Hayes AT set.
> 
> Why does 'puts' yield nothing?  And why would a device that is expecting 
> a packet of hex values need a binary conversion?
> 
> #!/bin/sh
> # the next line restarts using wish \
> exec wish "$0" "$@"
> 
> set bin_cmd [ binary format "H2H2" 11 00 ]
> puts stderr bin_cmd=$bin_cmd
> 
> exit


I think it's sinking in, everything is a string.  The device doesn't want to 
see ascii, it wants binary.  And $bin_cmd just doesn't make sense to the 
terminal window.

To interogate the variable,

	binary scan $bin_cmd "H*" s
	puts s=$s

cool.

The idea is to define "11 00" as a global var.  Brute for trial-and-error I 
guess.  Have a list of recommended Tcl books, but Powell's has none of them. 
  BTW, any pointer to what "$0" and "$@" mean in the wish invocation?  Same 
as bash?

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Tue May 13 03:11:02 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Tue May 13 03:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] REMOTE_USER
References: <mailman.1052792408.12039.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86bry7f9fe.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Billy" == Billy Dimaculangan <bmdimaculangan at bhpi.com.ph> writes:

Billy> We?re running our intranet on Linux web server, I was task
Billy> to monitor the users that are accessing the page.  I already
Billy> got the IP add, and the url the client is browsing but not the
Billy> REMOTE_USER.  I used perl cgi to this, but the REMOTE_USER
Billy> variable always ends up empty.  The remote client OS is
Billy> windows, how do I capture the windows user via perl?  Is this
Billy> possible
.

REMOTE_USER will be empty unless the script is protected by some
authentication step.  Have you protected the script with something
like "BasicAuth"?

And, it has nothing to do with the "remote" "user".  It's just the
name of the user as authenticated to the webserver.  If you've visited
a web site, gotten a pop-up box that described a "realm" and wanted a
"username" and "password", it's like that.

If you're creating a new application, "BasicAuth" while being simple,
basically sucks.  Since you're hacking Perl, look at my article at
<http://www.stonehenge.com/merlyn/WebTechniques/col61.html> on how to
do proper login/logout with simple cookies.

--

From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Tue May 13 10:39:02 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Tue May 13 10:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Java programmers?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305121412500.28804-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305121412500.28804-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1052847472.8941.27.camel@zadie>

On Mon, 2003-05-12 at 17:17, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On 12 May 2003, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> 
> > the jar is a zip file, with the bytecode compiled classes included. If
> > you include the jar in your classpath and run the class in it with a
> > main routine, it'll work fine on a different system. There are ways to
> > make executing the jar find and execute java and stuff. 
> 
>   Thanks, Jeff. The jar file I understood. I'm trying to understand how a
> complete java application is bundled and distributed as compared, for
> example, to the binary executable file that results when a C program is
> compiled and linked.

the Jar is usually the equivalent, but remember that the jar cannot be
run without a Java interpreter present (and in the path) on the target
machine. To compile to native bytecode, you'd have to use gcj, which is
rather alpha in development and may or may not compile your code.
 
> > Applications _can_ consist of hundreds or thousands of classes. They can
> > also be one or two calsses. There's no rule.
> 
>   True. But the jar file then becomes quite large, no?

How big is the application? How much code are you personally writing?
That determines how big the jar file is. If you write a little
application that primarily uses classes built into the standard Java
distribution, you don't have to include a lot in the jar. If you write
lots of stuff, it all goes in the jar, and the jar is quite big. You can
use multiple jars but then that becomes difficult to deal with on the
client machine where paths must be set up correctly.
 
> > For managing huge projects, I recommend: ant, IBM Eclipse (free beer),
> > or your favorite Java-enabled IDE (CodeWarrior, etc). They will manage
> > the compilation of the projects, and turn them into jar files at your
> > wish. ant is open source, built by the Apache project, and works wonders
> > (is similar to makefiles, but cleaner).
> 
>   There's also netbeans that I'm trying to understand. It's open source and
> apparently the equivalant of Sun's proprietary IDE.

netBeans works, but is very very very slow. I gave up on it because it
took way too long to load on even my newest machines. But it does work
just as well as any of the others.

>   So one of these would be a better choice than emacs?

Emacs is great for writing code, and it compiles stuff, and I might be
entirely wrong when I say this (ask Randal, as he probably knows a lot
more on this subject than I do), but emacs has little in the way of
project management stuff. The really nice thing about a good IDE is that
it can keep track of what files have changed and recompile them and only
them when you tell it to build the project, or it can clean all the
files and rebuild the whole thing.

open question: can emacs do that trivially?
 
> > multiprocessor machines are easy--threads are fairly good, and will run
> > in parallel. Beowulf clusters are harder and depend on how the cluster
> > is set up--if it's invisible to the program and just looks like a
> > multiprocessor machine, threading it should do it. If it's the standard
> > cheap, ssh-based beowulf cluster, then you have some work to do.
> 
>   Ah! So, no high performance, parallelizing compiler ($$$) is needed then.
> That's certainly a major benefit of java apps. 

Yes, because there aren't really any.

On the other hand, you will _never_ get the performance on a java app
that you would on a high-performanced compiled C/C++ app. Not even the
percentage increase for adding multiple processors that you would. Java
is no longer the lumbering beast of old days, but it's still no cheetah.

>   Many thanks! I'll be back for more -- I'm sure -- when I've read more and
> start on this immediate need project.
> 
> Rich
>

>

From holger at selover.net  Tue May 13 11:49:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Tue May 13 11:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Java programmers?
In-Reply-To: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0305131053350.31883-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305131053350.31883-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1052851755.1225.230.camel@halo>

Rich, for the standalone application you plan Eclipse is a very good
IDE. 

If you're concerned about the sizes of the bytecode, maybe Java is not
the way to go. 

The path problem is really not that complicated. Either your classes are
in the classpath or in any of the .jars that you added to your
classpath. Using Ant makes a lot of sense for more complex web
applications with templating, pattern stuff and deployment tasks. For
your standalone it would add unnecessary complexity. Just add all
referenced jars (if any) to the project's classpath in Eclipse (or a
shell script call of javac) and you're good to go. 

For me using an IDE like Eclipse is not a matter of taste or personal
opinion. I can code considerably faster with it and that is what counts.
There is also no programmer using objects and classes who wouldn't be
faster with a system that lists attributes and methods of used objects
while coding. 

For Rich's need IDEA could be an even better IDE, but this one is not
free.

Holger

> MySQL-client-3.23.55-1
> MySQL-devel-3.23.55-1
> MySQL-3.23.55-1

When you say 'rpm -e..' does nothing, what do you mean? 

What command line are you using, and what does it return? Show us what
you see on the screen. 

Try the following:

rpm -qa | grep MySQL

This should return the packages you listed above, nothing more, nothing
less.

If that is the case, then do this to remove all four packages:

rpm -e `rpm -qa | grep MySQL`

Note that those are backticks (usually a non-shifted tilde).

Let us know how it goes.

From marcm at dsl-only.net  Wed May 14 01:14:02 2003
From: marcm at dsl-only.net (Marc)
Date: Wed May 14 01:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] tcl question
In-Reply-To: <3EC0A25D.6000208@pacifier.com>
References: <3EC09683.1050107@pacifier.com> <3EC0A25D.6000208@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <20030514081326.GA30634@mentorg.com>

On Tue 05/13/03  0:44, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> Kyle Accardi wrote:
> 
> BTW, any pointer to what "$0" and "$@" mean in the wish invocation?  
>  Same as bash?

IIRC, the $0 and $@ syntax *IS* bash; the "exec" is performed by the shell, and
it simply calls the "wish" interpreter on the current script ($0) with the same
arguments ($@) you used.  The backslash on the previous line means nothing to
bash, but is understood by the TCL interpreter in wish as a line continuation,
and thus prevents it from reinvoking itself.

Marc

If it's sending you just plain text it's most likely that the server is
getting the mime-type wrong, and defaulting to "text/plain", in which
case there is very little that you can do about it, save for right
clicking and saying save-as, and sending the server admin an email
telling him he has his mime-types wrong.

On Wed, 14 May 2003, Russ Johnson wrote:

> 
> What command line are you using, and what does it return? Show us
> what you see on the screen.

If you're using rpm 4.1 (try "rpm --version"), you may have some stale
lockfiles. As root, do

  rm /var/lib/rpm/__db.*

> Try the following:
> 
> rpm -qa | grep MySQL

I'd change that just a bit:

  rpm -qa | grep -i mysql

The case-insensitive grep will pick up packages like php-mysql, 
mod_auth_mysql, etc. that might be dependent on the base MySQL rpms.

  I have a similar problem with some junky servers I'm using.  The default RH versions 7.2 (ES), 8.0, and 9.0 video drivers don't recognize the on-board video chip in graphics mode.  They would only run in text mode.  I've installed old PCI S3 Virge boards to work around the problem.

  I also needed to configure the BIOS to initialize the PCI video first *and* custom select the SVGA driver during the RH installation.  

  Try selecting the SVGA driver.  The default RH installation was picking the wrong driver for the PCI card when I tried it.  

Steve D...




From jason at oes.co.th  Wed May 14 10:33:02 2003
From: jason at oes.co.th (Jason H. Smith)
Date: Wed May 14 10:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Multihosting using linux
In-Reply-To: <1052778317.3ec01f4d88f8e@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
References: <1052778317.3ec01f4d88f8e@webmail.fiddlers-green.info>
Message-ID: <200305150018.20302.jason@oes.co.th>

(First reply never hit the list, so I'm re-replying..)

On Tuesday 13 May 2003 05:25 am, Daniel B. Herrington wrote:
> I figured this was probably not normal practice for linux hosting,
> though I haven't worked for a hosting company. I have to go back and
> argue for greater access to the server, i.e. a user not setup in a
> jail. Other than normal user and group priveleges I was wondering if

I wouldn't hold your breath.  I'm currently trying to implement a LAMP 
system on a standard 20-bucks-a-year hosting service, and it's a total 
pain.  I had assumed that I would have development libraries and all that 
to compile against; but actually all I got was chroot and a gig of quota.  
And I got zero in the way of tools.  And although it's chroot, our user 
accounts cannot access the system directories -- only /home and /tmp.

So I ended up having to compile my own gcc, binutils, and glibc and upload 
it to the site just to get something workable so I can e.g. install 
imagemagick and some Perl modules.  This included manually modifying the 
gcc source code so that its output binaries would not link against 
/lib/ld-linux.so.2, but instead /home/blah/blah/lib/ld-linux.so.2.  Big 
PITA.

But it's doable, if you have enough disk space, I guess.

If you really need your very own system, you might want to consider one of 
the user-mode Linux hosting companies out there.  That way, you are root 
on your own (virtual) machine, but you don't have to pay for rack space 
and all that.

HTH.

Is the OS trying to start the X-server?  I see two possibilities here,
the first is that the RH installer changed kernels (or kernel settings)
and is implementing the frame buffers on the reboot.  The other
possibility is that the card is choking when the X-server loads.  More
information about the exact boot messages you can see would help narrow
it down.

Can you boot the RH rescue disk (use the old version)?  This might get
you back into a usable system, the fix though is going to be dependant
on what is causing the problem.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed May 14 14:36:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed May 14 14:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] When tmpfs==good and ext3==bad :-)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305141434500.1426-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

I've been tasked with scraping data from some off-site directories
and consolidating them in a locally accessible LDAP directory.

Lots of bash and perl later, I've got a 4.5MB LDIF file containing 
about 16,000 records that's ready for slurping.

Using ldapadd is painfully slow for a record set of that size, so I 
decided to use slapadd instead.

All my local filesystems are ext3 partitions. What became apparent
really quickly was that ext3 is ill-equipped to deal with the sort of
quick transactional writes done by the db libraries. It was almost
painful to watch.

tmpfs to the rescue!

  mount -t tmpfs -o defaults tmpfs /mnt/tmp

I used slapadd to transform the LDIF file into what became about 30MB 
of db data and indices.

  System 1: Red Hat 9, P3 550MHz, 128 MB RAM, IDE HD
  System 2: Red Hat 8, dual P3 1.2GHz, 512MB RAM, UltraSCSI 160 HD

Writing to a tmpfs partition:

  System 1           System 2
  -----------------  -----------------
  real    2m52.418s  real    0m50.038s
  user    1m50.330s  user    0m24.914s
  sys     1m1.960s   sys     0m25.119s

Writing to an ext3 partition:

  System 1            System 2
  ------------------  -----------------
  real    21m28.784s  real    2m33.932s
  user    1m55.440s   user    0m26.014s
  sys     1m26.860s   sys     0m32.426s

Obviously, a filesystem living in RAM is going to outperform one on 
disk, but I don't think that explains a 5x to 7x speed difference.

It seems to me that the journaling overhead becomes unbearable on all
those little atomic db updates.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at cse.ogi.edu>

there is no AGP device, then the kernel won't try to send information to
it.  My theory is that the kernel is putting the console into a mode
that your video card doesn't support, this was confirmed when you
successfully installed the old version of RH.  If this is the case, the
kernel is probably booting, and the OS is probably running; just not

On Wed, 2003-05-14 at 15:08, max murphy wrote:
> Hello,
> I'm currently running debian unstable and have got almost all of my system configured except my usb wireless nic (prism2_usb module for a dwl-120 from dlink) and my soundcard (built into my MSI kt266pro2 motherboard).
> 
> So far I have my wireless adapter working as far as loading the modules and getting the hardware working,  my only problem is configuring it, I have it joined to my wlan and showing up in ifconfig as wlan0 with the correct ip address through dhcp but it just will not work correctly, if anyone can help me with a startup script for this device so that it will start at boot I would really appreciate it.
> 

You need to be more specific about what doesn't work, since it is
getting an address from your access point, something is working.

What does ifconfig show for wlan0?

What does iwconfig show?

What are the settings of your access point?

Are you trying to use WEP?

The setup for the wireless card is done in two places, /etc/modules
needs a line for the wireless card module (these get modprobe'd during
start up) and /etc/network/interfaces needs information about the wlan0
settings; man iwconfig for more information.

> My second problem is with a via82cxxx_audio module. Whenever I modprobe the module for the device it says that it is not present, I'm trying to configure it with alsa. I apt installed alsaconf and it doesn't recognize the sound device either. If anyone has input on how to fix this, once again I would greatly appreciate it.
> 

Try the AC97 module, it just might work (but might not - it doesn't hurt
to try though).

Good Luck

Derek Loree

From dholcombe at hotmail.com  Wed May 14 19:26:02 2003
From: dholcombe at hotmail.com (Devon Holcombe)

I have an msi 266 pro-r, the previous revision of this board with raid. It
has the original via 266 chipset rather than the 266a or the raid. I
currently have slackware 9.0 installed, with no sound and no gui. I have
previously used the alsa sound driver on this board with both slackware 8.1
and 9.0. I however have always downloaded alsa directly from the alsa
project page and configured it according to the directions there. The
onboard sound under linux the last time I tried the alsa driver sounds
pretty crappy though and you can actually hear the em interference when
other data is passing through the chipset and interfering with the sound
processing...such as when you move the mouse, transfer data on the pci
bus(such as through a nic) etc. The interference issue was never a problem
when I used the board under windows so it appears the linux driver has some
type of filtering issue and still needs some work to be done, but the sound
is usable and it does work using alsa. No need to purchase oss.

From dholcombe at hotmail.com  Wed May 14 20:20:03 2003
From: dholcombe at hotmail.com (Devon Holcombe)
Date: Wed May 14 20:20:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] two pieces of hardware and debian
Message-ID: <BAY2-DAV28voXM7e0C900000cbc@hotmail.com>

Additionally I forgot to mention you need to use the via 82xx module (for
the 8233, 8235,etc on these boards based on revision) in also NOT the 82cxxx
module you are attempting to use. The 82c is for things like the older via
686a, 686b, etc chipsets, not the newer 266, 266a, 333, etc. So your sound
probably isn't working because you are using the wrong module.

From heinlein at cse.ogi.edu  Wed May 14 21:22:02 2003
From: heinlein at cse.ogi.edu (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed May 14 21:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] When tmpfs==good and ext3==bad :-)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305141306140.1426-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

I've been tasked with scraping data from some off-site directories
and consolidating them in a locally accessible LDAP directory.

Lots of bash and perl later, I've got a 4.5MB LDIF file containing 
about 16,000 records that's ready for slurping.

Using ldapadd is painfully slow for a record set of that size, so I 
decided to use slapadd instead.

All my local filesystems are ext3 partitions. What became apparent
really quickly was that ext3 is ill-equipped to deal with the sort of
quick transactional writes done by the db libraries. It was almost
painful to watch.

tmpfs to the rescue!

  mount -t tmpfs -o defaults tmpfs /mnt/tmp

I used slapadd to transform the LDIF file into what became about 30MB 
of db data and indices.

  System 1: Red Hat 9, P3 550MHz, 128 MB RAM, IDE HD
  System 2: Red Hat 8, dual P3 1.2GHz, 512MB RAM, UltraSCSI 160 HD

Writing to a tmpfs partition:

  System 1           System 2
  -----------------  -----------------
  real    2m52.418s  real    0m50.038s
  user    1m50.330s  user    0m24.914s
  sys     1m1.960s   sys     0m25.119s

Writing to an ext3 partition:

  System 1            System 2
  ------------------  -----------------
  real    21m28.784s  real    2m33.932s
  user    1m55.440s   user    0m26.014s
  sys     1m26.860s   sys     0m32.426s

Obviously, a filesystem living in RAM is going to outperform one on 
disk, but I don't think that explains a 5x to 7x speed difference.

It seems to me that the journaling overhead becomes unbearable on all
those little atomic db updates.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at cse.ogi.edu>

From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Wed May 14 22:06:02 2003
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Wed May 14 22:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] When tmpfs==good and ext3==bad :-)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305141306140.1426-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305142153200.26118-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Wed, 14 May 2003, Paul Heinlein wrote:

>I've been tasked with scraping data from some off-site directories
>and consolidating them in a locally accessible LDAP directory.
>
>Lots of bash and perl later, I've got a 4.5MB LDIF file containing 
>about 16,000 records that's ready for slurping.
>
>Using ldapadd is painfully slow for a record set of that size, so I 
>decided to use slapadd instead.

You may just to do a little tuning ;-)

The problem you run into with ldapadd is that by default slapd calls
sync after each and every write.

If that is too paranoid for your needs, you can tell slapd only sync
every so often. I have mine configured to wait at least 2 seconds between
syncs and the write performance is several magnitudes faster. Here's the
magic in the database definition in slapd.conf:

	dbsync 2


>All my local filesystems are ext3 partitions. What became apparent
>really quickly was that ext3 is ill-equipped to deal with the sort of
>quick transactional writes done by the db libraries. It was almost
>painful to watch.

I'm in the middle of something so I can't verify this, but if I remember
correctly slapadd calls sync fairly often as well. It may very well be
a disk subsystem issue rather than a file system issue.

Again from memory, I'm pretty sure it only takes a few minutes for me
to _ldapadd_ ~15,000 entries on my main box (1G PIII, 1G ram, U160SCSI)
which is formated with ext3.

I'll do some benchmarking later if I'm not too burned out after I finish
my current project ;-)

-Eric

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed May 14 22:44:01 2003
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed May 14 22:44:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] When tmpfs==good and ext3==bad :-) 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Wed, 14 May 2003 21:38:44 PDT."
             <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305142129350.2080-100000@dan.parkrose.k12.or.us> 
Message-ID: <20030515054315.BA5CB8EE7@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> 
> > Obviously, a filesystem living in RAM is going to outperform one on 
> > disk, but I don't think that explains a 5x to 7x speed difference.
> 
> I always thought RAM was an order of magnitude faster than disks. Is that 
> a bad assumption?
>  

DDR @ 266 MHz peak bandwidth = 266 MHz * 8 bytes = 2.1 GB/s
Ultra 160 SCSI peak bandwidth = 80 MHz * 2 bytes = 160 MB/s

As a first approximation, I'd say your assumption is correct.  BTW, there's
no way a single disk could saturate an Ultra 160 bus unless the data
is coming from the disk's own cache.  The max transfer rate for a 15k rpm
disk is ~100 MB/s when actually reading data from the disk.

galen

Subject: [PLUG] gawking a file
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305150657170.14271-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  As all of you are aware, I do not know perl, python or ruby. But, I have
been able to meet my modest needs over the past couple of decades using awk
and sed. Now I'm asking for some sage advice about framing a gawk program to
extract specific fields from a text file.

  Background: I extract certain records from jpilot as a
comma-separated-value (.csv) file. I want only a subset (name, title,
company, address) from the 24 fields there. My one-line gawk program works
just dandy if and only if there is no newline in a jpilot record. When there
is, the extracted file has a record distributed over two or more lines and
that screws up the gawk field extraction.

  There's a valid reason for the newline: some records have a mailing
address that differs from the street address. I use a slash and a newline in
jpilot for readability. I suppose I could use only the slash if I had to.
However, in the notes field, each contact has its own line and there's no
way I can concatenate those and still extract data properly for contact
information.

  So, my question to you more knowledgeble folks is this: Is there a way in
the gawk syntax to specify the field that begins a new record? That is, I
want to match a certain pattern before proceeding to the field extraction.
Would a BEGIN section be the way to go on this?

TIA,

Rich

>my current project ;-)
>
>-Eric
>
>
>>tmpfs to the rescue!
>>
>>  mount -t tmpfs -o defaults tmpfs /mnt/tmp
>>
>>I used slapadd to transform the LDIF file into what became about 30MB 
>>of db data and indices.
>>
>>  System 1: Red Hat 9, P3 550MHz, 128 MB RAM, IDE HD
>>  System 2: Red Hat 8, dual P3 1.2GHz, 512MB RAM, UltraSCSI 160 HD
>>
>>Writing to a tmpfs partition:
>>
>>  System 1           System 2
>>  -----------------  -----------------
>>  real    2m52.418s  real    0m50.038s
>>  user    1m50.330s  user    0m24.914s
>>  sys     1m1.960s   sys     0m25.119s
>>
>>Writing to an ext3 partition:
>>
>>  System 1            System 2
>>  ------------------  -----------------
>>  real    21m28.784s  real    2m33.932s
>>  user    1m55.440s   user    0m26.014s
>>  sys     1m26.860s   sys     0m32.426s
>>
>>Obviously, a filesystem living in RAM is going to outperform one on 
>>disk, but I don't think that explains a 5x to 7x speed difference.
>>
>>It seems to me that the journaling overhead becomes unbearable on all
>>those little atomic db updates.
>>
>>--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at cse.ogi.edu>

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Thu May 15 09:39:02 2003
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Thu May 15 09:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] gawking a file
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305150657170.14271-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305150657170.14271-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20030515163726.GA10395@dalsemi.com>

On Thu, May 15, 2003 at 07:05:55AM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   As all of you are aware, I do not know perl, python or ruby. But, I have
> been able to meet my modest needs over the past couple of decades using awk
> and sed. Now I'm asking for some sage advice about framing a gawk program to
> extract specific fields from a text file.

I don't know gawk, but I have a very old posting (1995) from Randal
Schwartz about a simple line continuation technique that you can
probably extend to your problem.

This is some pseudo code:

Get line from STDIN
Does line meet the end of line condition?
  No: Get another line and check again
  Yes: Process the line and then get another.

Here's some perl code:

LOOP: while (<>) {
  redo LOOP if s/\\$// and $_ .= <>;
}

that handles the standard Unix line continuation using \

I'm guessing that the gawk code may look similar, since it and perl
are cousins.  Siblings?

>   So, my question to you more knowledgeble folks is this: Is there a way in
> the gawk syntax to specify the field that begins a new record? That is, I
> want to match a certain pattern before proceeding to the field extraction.
> Would a BEGIN section be the way to go on this?

The gawk manpage says:

       RS          The input record separator, by default a  new?
                   line.

Good luck, and holler if you'd like some perl code to do it.

Colin
