From jeme at brelin.net  Tue May 20 00:59:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue May 20 00:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] UML users?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305191241360.19634-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305191241360.19634-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305200044170.11891@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 19 May 2003, Phil Tomson wrote:
> No, I'm not trying to trash it.  I'm trying to find out why people use it.
>
> For me it seems like a step in the wrong direction, but if I can
> understand why people choose to use it maybe I can understand why people
> want to go that way and then offer them alternatives ;-)  I really do
> think there might be better methodologies....

I think Rich's point is valid despite the "shove off" language.

You say that it seems like a step in the wrong direction before really
knowing much at all about it.  You assert counter-points to the individual
statements of those who use the system but you fail to take those
statements in aggregate appreciate the way the tool is used regadless of
how you might use it yourself.  You can't learn the usefulness of
something if you're just trying to find out how useless it is.

Now, I have never personally worked with UML and so I really have no
comment on its usefulness as tool for the programmer.  However, I have
seen PLENTY of bad code badly documented and I welcome anything that will
help describe the design of a program for future maintainers and
modifiers.  I think this is really a difference in philosophy more than a
difference in technology.  To me, the social aspects of how a thing is
done far supercede the efficiency or expedience of how a thing is done.
I personally believe that the purpose of work is to make the world a more
pleasant place.  The inconvenience of using a cumbersome tool (if, indeed,
that's what we've got here) in the design phase seems to be a way of
paying a small cost in pain up front for alleviating the long pains of
future developers who must work from your code.  Bad code never dies and a
little inconvenience today could prevent a lot of inconvenience in all of
our tomorrows.

J.

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Tue May 20 02:31:02 2003
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: Tue May 20 02:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] "reverse" ssh?
References: <1053393063.30311.8180.camel@obelisk.spek.org> <mailman.1053401592.30008.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86u1bqc6jm.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Sean" == Sean Whitney <sean at fork.com> writes:

I didn't see the original on this.  Is the news server borked again?

Sean> On Monday 19 May 2003 06:11 pm, Brent Rieck wrote:
>> Hello,
>> I have a friend, who's also a business partner, with an OSX machine
>> that I have set up to download backups remotely from a web server.  I've
>> changed the location of the backup files and now his cron'd download is
>> failing.  It's something that would take me 30 seconds to fix if I could
>> only SSH into his box but his ISP (peskily) blocks all incoming
>> traffic.  Is there a way he can initiate the SSH connection to my
>> machine which I can then use to login to his machine?

Sure.  He can start outbound:

$ ssh -f -N remotebox -R22000:localhost:22
Password: (enter password)
$

That will stay alive as long as the connection doesn't fry or the
boxes don't reboot.  You then ssh to remotebox, then type

$ ssh -p 22000 localhost
Password:

And you're in on his box.  Even X-forward will work. :)

If you're really smart, you can even set up a VPN over this.

I won't tell you how I know all this, or how often I've "tested" it.

From raanders at acm.org  Tue May 20 07:41:01 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Tue May 20 07:41:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DNS interest...
In-Reply-To: <1053370832.23384.20.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0305200730440.6256-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On 19 May 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

A very interesting topic and one I haven't quite got my brain wrapped
around ... yet so I don't feel I'm up to addressing this but ... I suggest
attending if you can Ed Sawicki's (alcpress.com) most excellant DNS Boot
Camp.  Last Saturday we got Ed come to Spokane and do his class.  Those
that had almost no clue came away with a much stronger understanding and
those that had a clue (or at least had been doing DNS for awhile) are now
implementing lots of new and interesting stuff.

And the short answer, if I understand your question correctly, is you
_can_ use one nameserver as an internal authority and as a cache
nameserver for external lookups.  I do this for my home network
(anderson.home) but since I set it up using Linuxconf and accepted the
defaults I can't provide the particulars as to how to do it.
   I also suggest looking at using djbdns (TinyDNS and dnscache) instead
of bind.  So far I have dnscache running on one nameserver (class was
Saturday and I didn't do computers Sunday - all on Monday while taking
calls and dealing with the normal Monday morning c**p) and ready to go on
several others.  TinyDNS will take a few more days since it will affect a
lot more of our operations (hundreds of domains) and is just different
enough that the transition won't be trivial.

Again I _strongly_ suggest Ed's class.


Best,
Rod

From heinlein at attbi.com  Tue May 20 08:31:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue May 20 08:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Canopus ADV-1394 under Linux
In-Reply-To: <1053402162.29793.3.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305200814340.13584-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 20 May 2003, Alan wrote:

> I went and purchased a Canopus ADV-1394 video capture card.
> 
> I can get Kino to capture video, but I am seeing noise/distortion on
> the row of bottom five pixels. I am also seeing a bit of color noise
> on the left hand side of the image.
> 
> Anyone familiar with this card?  Have any idea what is wrong or does
> it always do that?

I follow the discussions on the linux1394-user mailing list, and all I
can say is that Linux firewire support is still pretty much hit and
miss. That said, it's a pretty low-traffic list, and Stefan Richter 
and Ben Collins are usually very good about answering questions like 
this.

What they will want to know is

* kernel version
* version of the various ieee1394 drivers (see dmesg)
* output of /proc/bus/ieee1394/devices

And any of the following that apply:

* libraw1394 version
* libavc1394 version
* libdv version

If you're using a stock distro kernel, they'll probably tell you to 
grab the latest subversion sources (for 2.5 or 2.4, the branches are 
separate) and try another compile.

If you've already done that, then it might be a case of sitting around 
and waiting for the kernel-level ieee1394 to catch up with your 
technology.

If it looks like the libdv stuff is part of the chain, you might try 
pinging Buck Krasic (see the AUTHORS file in the libdv source 
tarball). Buck's out here at OGI and is a decent guy.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Tue May 20 10:35:03 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Tue May 20 10:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] UML users?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305200044170.11891@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305201005410.4476-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>


On Tue, 20 May 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>
> On Mon, 19 May 2003, Phil Tomson wrote:
> > No, I'm not trying to trash it.  I'm trying to find out why people use it.
> >
> > For me it seems like a step in the wrong direction, but if I can
> > understand why people choose to use it maybe I can understand why people
> > want to go that way and then offer them alternatives ;-)  I really do
> > think there might be better methodologies....
>
> I think Rich's point is valid despite the "shove off" language.
>
> You say that it seems like a step in the wrong direction before really
> knowing much at all about it.  You assert counter-points to the individual
> statements of those who use the system but you fail to take those
> statements in aggregate appreciate the way the tool is used regadless of
> how you might use it yourself.  You can't learn the usefulness of
> something if you're just trying to find out how useless it is.

Oh, my!  Email is such an imprecise communication medium, eh?  It seems
I've come across as some sort of very closed minded person.

Actually, I've read some of the articles on UML by Booch (several years
back, I admit).  Recently we had some discussion about UML on another
list I'm on and we had a bit of a debate - I guess there were a couple
of other old hardware engineers on that list because I found I had some
agreement about not wanting schematics for software.

I've actually considered learning UML, but time is limited so I need to be
choosy about what I invest in.  That's why I try to find out what is
motivating people to move in that direction.  I'm coming from a different
industry where I witnessed the reverse happen: there was a movement away
from graphical design descriptions toward textual ones, and at the time
this was a rather radical shift.  I witnessed this shift first-hand
during my career.  When I graduated in the mid-80s we drew schematics
exclusively - very few people had even heard of HDLs or any kind of
textual description of circuits.  By the mid-90s HDLs were making inroads
and mixed schematic (graphical) and HDL (text) designs were being done.
Now in the ASIC and FPGA world it's very rare to find schematics being
used at all - the paradigm has completely shifted and hardware engineers
are definitely more productive because of it.  There is no way that the
types of chips being designed now could be done in a timely fashion using
schematics.

So please don't think of my criticism as merely taking potshots at
something I know nothing about; I'm merely offering my observations based
on what I've seen happen in the world of chip design over that last
fifteen years.  You can take those observations as instructive as related
to software design, or you can write them off as totally unrelated, that's
up to you.

>
> Now, I have never personally worked with UML and so I really have no
> comment on its usefulness as tool for the programmer.  However, I have
> seen PLENTY of bad code badly documented and I welcome anything that will
> help describe the design of a program for future maintainers and
> modifiers.  I think this is really a difference in philosophy more than a
> difference in technology.  To me, the social aspects of how a thing is
> done far supercede the efficiency or expedience of how a thing is done.
> I personally believe that the purpose of work is to make the world a more
> pleasant place.  The inconvenience of using a cumbersome tool (if, indeed,
> that's what we've got here) in the design phase seems to be a way of
> paying a small cost in pain up front for alleviating the long pains of
> future developers who must work from your code.  Bad code never dies and a
> little inconvenience today could prevent a lot of inconvenience in all of
> our tomorrows.
>

Schematics were fine for documenting small circuits.  If you only needed
two or three pages of schematics it was a reasonable way to understand how
the circuit worked.  But for large systems it was extremely awkward.  I
recall that in my first job out of school they handed us a huge three-ring
binder full of hundreds of pages of schematics for a very complex chip
tester and we were supposed to go off and study them.  I'd take them home
and read them trying to figure the thing out.  You'd be chasing one signal
and then it would get to the end of the page and there would be a little
note about the other pages the signal went to... oh, the pain, I'm trying
to forget it. ;-)

Anyway, please excuse what seemed to be a viceral reaction against UML; it
just seems as though we hardware engineers have been there and done that
and I'm not really sure I want to go back there.

Phil

From danielx.j.petcher at intel.com  Tue May 20 11:56:02 2003
From: danielx.j.petcher at intel.com (Petcher, Danielx J)
Date: Tue May 20 11:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Setting Up A Mail List
Message-ID: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C06A9D7AA@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com>

Your privacy concerns are indeed legitimate and I do think Yahoo has changed
their privacy policy more than once. I subscribe to the BLUE (Beaverton
Linux Users Education) list via Topica.Com and I haven't gotten spammed yet.
Your mileage may vary.

Of course, if you're REALLY worried about privacy and SPAM, you can set-up a
bulletin board like vBulletin or phBB. The advantage here is that none of
the discussion goes over the SMTP-based Email protocol; it's all on your
server. The disadvantage is that all of the discussion and reading traffic
hits your server. Some of your user community will appreciate the privacy
benefit of not having to list a legitimate Internet Email address on every
message they post. Some of your user community may resent having to look
outside their Email box to see message traffic on your BBS.

-djp
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

From holger at selover.net  Tue May 20 13:22:02 2003
From: holger at selover.net (Holger Stephan)
Date: Tue May 20 13:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] UML users?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305201005410.4476-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305201005410.4476-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <1053462086.2561.123.camel@halo>

With regard to UML and version control, it is indeed a problem, but not
a show stopper. The greatest benefit with UML is to create a model for a
developer team and verify it against the requirements, which involves
people outside the development team. In this scenario the model is the
more and less fixed frame for the subsequent implementation. IOW,
changes are kept to a minimum and documented because they affect the
team and possibly require communication with outsiders (i.e. when
business rules or a RDBMS structure is affected). 

In some cases, i.e. a Java enterprise application where business objects
and rules are implemented as beans (classes) in a distributed
environment UML is an integral part of the development with the finished
model representing a major development effort and component. 

Personally I also use it for smaller one-man projects, because it saves
me from typing code.

Lastly, a diff is possible on the XMI file that an UML tool should be
able to create. This XML file contains the entire model and is text.

Hope that didn't upset anyone now...

Holger

On Tue, 2003-05-20 at 10:34, Phil Tomson wrote:
    On Tue, 20 May 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
    
    >
    > On Mon, 19 May 2003, Phil Tomson wrote:
    > > No, I'm not trying to trash it.  I'm trying to find out why people use it.
    > >
    > > For me it seems like a step in the wrong direction, but if I can
    > > understand why people choose to use it maybe I can understand why people
    > > want to go that way and then offer them alternatives ;-)  I really do
    > > think there might be better methodologies....
    >
    > I think Rich's point is valid despite the "shove off" language.
    >
    > You say that it seems like a step in the wrong direction before really
    > knowing much at all about it.  You assert counter-points to the individual
    > statements of those who use the system but you fail to take those
    > statements in aggregate appreciate the way the tool is used regadless of
    > how you might use it yourself.  You can't learn the usefulness of
    > something if you're just trying to find out how useless it is.
    
    Oh, my!  Email is such an imprecise communication medium, eh?  It seems
    I've come across as some sort of very closed minded person.
    
    Actually, I've read some of the articles on UML by Booch (several years
    back, I admit).  Recently we had some discussion about UML on another
    list I'm on and we had a bit of a debate - I guess there were a couple
    of other old hardware engineers on that list because I found I had some
    agreement about not wanting schematics for software.
    
    I've actually considered learning UML, but time is limited so I need to be
    choosy about what I invest in.  That's why I try to find out what is
    motivating people to move in that direction.  I'm coming from a different
    industry where I witnessed the reverse happen: there was a movement away
    from graphical design descriptions toward textual ones, and at the time
    this was a rather radical shift.  I witnessed this shift first-hand
    during my career.  When I graduated in the mid-80s we drew schematics
    exclusively - very few people had even heard of HDLs or any kind of
    textual description of circuits.  By the mid-90s HDLs were making inroads
    and mixed schematic (graphical) and HDL (text) designs were being done.
    Now in the ASIC and FPGA world it's very rare to find schematics being
    used at all - the paradigm has completely shifted and hardware engineers
    are definitely more productive because of it.  There is no way that the
    types of chips being designed now could be done in a timely fashion using
    schematics.
    
    So please don't think of my criticism as merely taking potshots at
    something I know nothing about; I'm merely offering my observations based
    on what I've seen happen in the world of chip design over that last
    fifteen years.  You can take those observations as instructive as related
    to software design, or you can write them off as totally unrelated, that's
    up to you.
    
    >
    > Now, I have never personally worked with UML and so I really have no
    > comment on its usefulness as tool for the programmer.  However, I have
    > seen PLENTY of bad code badly documented and I welcome anything that will
    > help describe the design of a program for future maintainers and
    > modifiers.  I think this is really a difference in philosophy more than a
    > difference in technology.  To me, the social aspects of how a thing is
    > done far supercede the efficiency or expedience of how a thing is done.
    > I personally believe that the purpose of work is to make the world a more
    > pleasant place.  The inconvenience of using a cumbersome tool (if, indeed,
    > that's what we've got here) in the design phase seems to be a way of
    > paying a small cost in pain up front for alleviating the long pains of
    > future developers who must work from your code.  Bad code never dies and a
    > little inconvenience today could prevent a lot of inconvenience in all of
    > our tomorrows.
    >
    
    Schematics were fine for documenting small circuits.  If you only needed
    two or three pages of schematics it was a reasonable way to understand how
    the circuit worked.  But for large systems it was extremely awkward.  I
    recall that in my first job out of school they handed us a huge three-ring
    binder full of hundreds of pages of schematics for a very complex chip
    tester and we were supposed to go off and study them.  I'd take them home
    and read them trying to figure the thing out.  You'd be chasing one signal
    and then it would get to the end of the page and there would be a little
    note about the other pages the signal went to... oh, the pain, I'm trying
    to forget it. ;-)
    
    Anyway, please excuse what seemed to be a viceral reaction against UML; it
    just seems as though we hardware engineers have been there and done that
    and I'm not really sure I want to go back there.
    
    Phil

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Tue May 20 16:59:01 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Tue May 20 16:59:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Setting Up A Mail List
In-Reply-To: <1053436181.1511.122.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305201631140.2410-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

On 20 May 2003, Jon Jacob wrote:

> I am looking to set up a mail list, and wanted to know if anyone had any
> suggestions.

I have looked at a number of mail list handlers.
They all have their good points and bad points.

I use to use majordomo a lot.
It is actually a decent list handler.
I don't recall much difficulty setting it up, altho there are a few picky
details.
I moved away from majordomo, because it didn't seem to be keeping up with
the times.  Upgrades were coming slowly, and it seemed to me that
spammers could send mail to a list without subscribing to the list if
they knew enough about majordomo.  Moreover, majordomo doesn't have a web
interface, and my clients needed a web interface.

Lately, I have been using mailman.  I think it is more spam resistant
than majordomo, but it has it's own problems.  It is too dependent
on the web interface.  It does accept commands via mail, but only
very basic commands.  The documentation says it supports majordomo
style commands, but it only supports a few of the majordomo commands.
I also don't really care for the way mailman stores the mail.  mailman
uses it's own format, so you have to rebuild the data base after making
manual changes.  majordomo uses normal mail format which is easier
to work with.

I have also looked at a number of the services.
I don't really trust any of them.
Yahoo sucks, but putting a list on yahoo is a good way to advertise
it's existance.
Smartgroups.com is another option.
I like it better than Yahoo, but lists on smartgroups don't get much
exposure.

Some people worry a bit about the privacy of mail addresses on lists
on yahoo, smartgroups, etc.  I don't think this is much of a concern,
because people can and should sign up to lists like this using free
mail accounts unless they want to be known.

From raanders at acm.org  Tue May 20 18:21:02 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Tue May 20 18:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Cron notification
In-Reply-To: <20030521010220.GA14866@boora.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0305201825360.15142-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Tue, 20 May 2003, Michael Montagne wrote:

> I just added a cron job that writes a file every half hour.  Each time
> it runs I get an email.  How do I make that stop?  I have another one
> running that doesn't send an email.

By default all output is mailed to root.  If your process doesn't create
output you may or may not get (depending on the quality of burnt offerings
you've made or even the distribution/version of Linux you're running) an
(semi-)empty message.  To insure you don't get anything place > /dev/null
after the command(s) you're running.  You'll still get errors in the mail 
but if you've been a good scripter these will be minimal.

EXAMPLE:

	chkspam.pl > /dev/null


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue May 20 21:07:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue May 20 21:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Cron notification
In-Reply-To: <20030521040415.GA12261@blain.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305202104400.16065-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 20 May 2003 jelque at feather.net wrote:

> ...and what does 2>&1 do exactly?

  Redirects STD_ERROR to STD_OUT.

  Three file handles are automatically assigned when you log in: STD_IN,
STD_OUT and STD_ERROR. The first is the keyboard, the second is the monitor
and the third varies. The redirection puts error messages on the monitor
where you can see them.

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Tue May 20 21:15:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue May 20 21:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Cron notification
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305202104400.16065-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <20030521040415.GA12261@blain.org> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305202104400.16065-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20030521041436.GA16714@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

On Tue, May 20, 2003 at 09:06:26PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Tue, 20 May 2003 jelque at feather.net wrote:
> 
> > ...and what does 2>&1 do exactly?
> 
>   Redirects STD_ERROR to STD_OUT.
> 
> and the third varies. The redirection puts error messages on the monitor
> where you can see them.

In the case quoted, it sends error messages to /dev/null. 2>&1 points
stderr (associated with file descriptor 2) to the same place as stdout
(fd 1). If you wanted to capture all output from some program and
write it to a file you could do the same thing.

$ myProgram > myProgram.out 2>&1

There is a slightly shorter syntax to do this, but it escapes me at
the moment. I'm sure a scan of the plug archives would turn it up.

-Rogan

am I missing something?

# named.conf

options {
        directory "/var/named";
            // where to put out pid file
            // absolute path since we don't want
            // it in /var/named
            pid-file "/var/run/named.pid";
};

//
// a caching only nameserver config
//

// Access Control List(s) ACL(s)


// Internal Views

view "internal" {
        match-clients { localnets; };
        recursion yes;
        zone "domainname.com" {
                type master;
                file "db.domainname.com.internal";
                allow-transfer { any; };
        };

};

// External Views

view "external" {
        match-clients { any; };
        recursion no;

        zone "domainname.com" {
                type master;
                file "db.domainname.com.external";
                allow-transfer { none; };
        };
};


#######################
# /var/named/domainname.com.internal
// domainname.com INTERNAL
$ttl 38400

domainname.com.              IN      SOA     dev.domainname.com. (
                                0520200301
                                10800
                                3600
                                604800
                                38400 )

; Name Server(s)
domainname.com.              IN      NS      dev.domainname.com.
;
domainname.com.              IN      A       192.168.1.65
www.domainname.com.          IN      CNAME   domainname.com.
dev.domainname.com.          IN      CNAME   domainname.com.
;
;


#######################
# /var/named/domainname.com.external

// domainname.com EXTERNAL
$ttl 38400

domainname.com.              IN      SOA     dev.domainname.com. (
                                0520200301
                                10800
                                3600
                                604800
                                38400 )

; Name Server(s)

;
domainname.com.              IN      A       66.100.100.100

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Wed May 21 13:09:02 2003
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Wed May 21 13:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] simple grep
Message-ID: <E19IZtQ-0006Is-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

I'm learning and I am now seeing that Bash provides ways to manipulate
variables without calling external programs and using pipes. I first noticed I
could replace the calls to cut and sed I was using with ${VAR//pattern/word}. I
have replaced a call to wc -c by using ${#VAR}. now I want a simple grep and
grep -v. I don't need it to be perfect but would like it to as workable as
possible. I would like to replace [A-Za-z0-9\ \       
\~\!\@\#\$\%\^\&\*\(\)\_\+\=\{\}\'\"\:\;\<\>\,\.\/] with classes;  [:alnum:]
.. but I can't get it to work. Any help appreciated.

Thank you
Russell

#!/bin/sh

VAR=$1
FILE=$2

while read LINE ; do
	PRE=${LINE//$VAR/??--??/}
	CAP=${PRE//[A-Za-z0-9\ \       
\~\!\@\#\$\%\^\&\*\(\)\_\+\=\{\}\'\"\:\;\<\>\,\.\/]}
	if [ "$CAP" = "??--??" ] ; then
		echo $LINE
	fi
done < $FILE

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed May 21 14:49:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed May 21 14:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Configuring Majordomo
In-Reply-To: <1053552623.1510.393.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305211445530.19230-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On 21 May 2003, Jon Jacob wrote:

> Now, how do I work it so that when people hit reply it goes back to the
> list and not to the person?  I know that the docs say to set the reply_to
> in the config, but I did that and it did not work.  Also, they warn not to
> do that because of possible loops.  Can anyone advise on this and tell me
> how to get to work (if that is indeed advisable)?

  The only loops I get are some of the subscribers. In
<maillist_name>.config set the reply-to as in my example below:

        # reply_to             [word] () <resend,digest>
        # Put a reply-to header with value <value> into the outgoing
        # message. If the token $SENDER is used, then the address of the
        # sender is used as the value of the reply-to header. This is the
        # value of the reply-to header for digest lists.
reply_to            = fa-photo

  So, for this list, all replies automatically go to
fa-photo at appl-ecosys.com. I've had absolutely no problems with this on the
three lists hosted here so I cannot tell you how to get it to work unless
you tell us what's different at your end.

Rich

                       Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
            2404 SW 22nd Street | Troutdale, OR 97060-1247 | U.S.A.
 + 1 503-667-4517 (voice) | + 1 503-667-8863 (fax) | rshepard&#64;appl-ecosys.com
                         http://www.appl-ecosys.com/

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 20 May 2003 15:52:20 -0700 (PDT)
From: Tyler F. Creelan <creelan at engr.orst.edu>
To: grads at cs.orst.edu, undergrad at cs.orst.edu, pre-cs at cs.orst.edu
Cc: osu-ieee at ieee.org, lug at peak.org, linux at lists.orst.edu
Subject: [lug] Mail Filtering Workshop, Thursday 5:00.

Hi everyone -

This week's ACM workshop is on mail filtering, and is hosted by Rogan
Creswick and I. The workshop is free and will be in Milne 130 from
5:00 to 7:00 pm on Thursday. See below for an outline of the workshop.
We should also have some pizza and other refreshments conducive to
programming, although as before they have to be eaten outside the lab.

Topic: Mail Filtering
Time: 5:00 pm, Thursday, 5/22
Place: Milne 130 (across street from Dearborn)


"Mail Filtering Workshop"

Filtering spam, sorting mail lists, and categorizing messages by
sender are essential skills when working with email. In this week's
ACM workshop, we'll create a basic mail filter using procmail, a
powerful unix mail utility. We'll also see how to create and use
whitelists, spamassassin, scoring of messages based on features like
the sender and subject, and automated handling of attachments.

Less powerful filters built into email clients (pine, outlook) will
also be examined.

Place:  Milne 130 (across street from Dearborn)
	Oregon State University, Corvallis
Maps:   http://eecs.oregonstate.edu/about/visitor.html
Cost:   free!

What is procmail?

 Procmail is used to sort incoming mail into separate folders,
 postprocess mail, start any programs upon mail arrival or selectively
 forward incoming mail automatically to someone. Procmail is
 often employed in filtering spam and prioritizing mail lists.

 The accompanying formail program enables you to generate autoreplies,
 split up digests and mailboxes into individual messages and easily
 alter email headers. Procmail and formail are free software,
 distributed under the GNU GPL.

More info on procmail:

Nancy McGough, "Processing Mail"
http://www.ii.com/internet/robots/procmail/qs/

"Procmail Learning Kit"
http://www.cs.orst.edu/~creelan/procmail-kit.tar.gz

That won't work. It cost me several points towards Linux Gurudom yesterday
when I tried to show a co-worker neat-o Linux tricks.

For some reason -- & I hope someone out there knows why -- you can either
have a mount point for your USB storage device, or an entry in /etc/fstab,
but not both at the same time. Maybe that's because the USB device is
also linked to /proc/bus/usb -- but that's just a guess.

FWIW, we were able to mount the USB storage device by refering to it as
/dev/sda1. I had a devil of a time trying to figure out which SCSI device
had been chosen to represent the USB device. Hopefully this note will save
someone much time & frustration.

Geoff

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Wed May 21 21:38:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Wed May 21 21:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] USB thumb drive
In-Reply-To: <20030522003558.GA1697@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0305212128140.22583-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

I have a laptop with RH8, and for some devices it creates directories and
mount and stuff, for others it does not. I haven't figured out what
activates the magic. I know how to do it manually. First of all, once you
connect a usb drive, module usb-storage should autoload. If it does not,
there is something wrong with your hotplug configuration, this part should
work. Do lsmod, see if usb-storage is there. usb-storage creates a new
scsi channel and the device appears as a scsi disk. So, you should have
/proc/scsi/usb-storage-0 directory. The disk will be /dev/sd[a-z], as for
which one, depends on how many you already have, it'll be the next one (so
if you have no scsi disks, including emulated scsi, it'll start with sda).
Partition table on the new disk can be arbitrary, but if it has only one
partition you need to mount /dev/sda1. If you want to know which one, tail
/var/log/messages or dmesg, it'll tell you when the disk is connected.

Now, I suspect that the magic works through hotplug scripts (after all,
they issue insmod usb-storage command, might as well do the other stuff),
so if you want it to happen, try downloading the latest hotplug and
reading the setup docs on http://linux-hotplug.sourceforge.net/

From michael at goose.robinson-west.com  Thu May 22 03:13:01 2003
From: michael at goose.robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Thu May 22 03:13:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Got around 2000 servers lack of scripting power...
Message-ID: <1053598011.27140.13.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

Well, I'm a C programmer so I took my copy of djgcc and used it.
It was a stupid problem, needed to help along a program converting
a doc file to a special machine, ex2, file.  The trouble with
the batch file written to launch a qbasic program to address this issue
was that the source file to be converted ended up being overwritten
by the result, no name change.  Trying to fix this in the batch file
lead to permission problems creating a new file and I found myself
trying tricks such as embedded commands like Linux's pwd only to find I
couldn't do that or anything like that.  Running into other issues such
as long filenames I finally said forget it and went to C.  Having the
batch file put the path of the source file into a text file I choose to
read part of this to an array, C program.  To finish creating the target
I added the proper extension to that array, strcat.  Finally I used C to
copy the temp output file created by the qbasic program to the file that
needed to be created all along.  Worked like a charm except that using
malloc I forget to use free, ughhh!  Guess I'll have to fix that one
tomorrow.

Awfully ridiculous that I had to write a C program to get the path for
the output file.  It's the first time I've ever seen C and basic work
together, very cool.

     --  Michael C. Robinson




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu May 22 06:35:03 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu May 22 06:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The latest on SCO vs. reality
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305220632410.21960-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

---------- Forwarded message ----------
                              SuitWatch--May 22nd

  Views on Linux in Business

  --by Doc Searls, Senior Editor of Linux Journal
     _________________________________________________________________

                          "The Going Gets Weirder"

   Thursday, May 22, 2003--My brother-in-law used to have a seafood
   restaurant in San Jose. Often he'd wear an amusing but cryptic t-shirt
   with a picture of hands extended upward toward a glowing fish. The
   copy on the shirt said, "Fish worship. Is it wrong?" Thinking about
   that shirt puts me in the surreal frame of mind that seems to be
   required for making any kind of sense out of what happened to SCO.

   A few months back, SCO seemed to be a resourceful survivor, quietly
   managing to combine the has-been (its UNIX business) with the won't-be
   (its Linux business) and looking at least somewhat credible in the
   process. Its revenues were sliding away:
   http://www.hoovers.com/quarterlies/9/0,2167,99709,00.html, from $17.9
   million in the quarter ending in January 2002 to $13.5 million the
   same quarter, one year later. More significantly, its cash had fallen
   from $26.1 million to $4.9 million. Dying, perhaps, but a long way
   from dead.

   Then, out of nowhere, they went batty over intellectual property, of
   all things. They sued IBM for $1 billion for violating something or
   other. Then they claimed to find hunks of orthodox UNIX code leveraged
   into Linux somehow, though at this writing they still haven't offered
   the evidence. Unwilling to sue themselves, they "suspended" their
   Linux business and warned Linux users about the "potential liability
   that could rest with them for using such software" while offering to
   "hold harmless" their own remaining Linux customers.

   As if all that stuff weren't wacky enough, Microsoft just licensed
   SCO's UNIX source code and patents--even though, when our own Don
   Marti went looking for SCO patents a couple months back, he couldn't
   find any:
   http://www.ssc.com/pipermail/atc/2003-March/000034.html.

   The best legal work:
   http://www.opensource.org/sco-vs-ibm.html so far on the case appears
   to have been done by Eric Raymond and Rob Landley of the Open Source
   Initiative. ESR's fighting spirit and gift for rhetoric are put to
   fine use in a position paper that takes apart SCO's case against IBM,
   almost phrase by phrase. Here's one of its withering statements:

     SCO's complaint is factually defective in that it implies claims
     about SCO's business and technical capabilities that are untrue. It
     is, indeed, very cleverly crafted to deceive a reader without
     intimate knowledge of the technology and history of Unix; it gives
     false impressions by both the suppression of relevant facts, the
     ambiguous suggestion of falsehoods, and in a few instances by
     outright lying.

   Meanwhile, IBM remains as solid and passive as Stonehenge, which maybe
   is the way it should be. Microsoft gets a few digs against Linux. SCO
   will lose. Life will go on.

From drl at drloree.com  Thu May 22 09:14:02 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Thu May 22 09:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] PCI/AGP Graphics Board Problem
In-Reply-To: <3ECCE6B9.3070103@ardware.net>
References: <20030521225253.16134.qmail@station173.com>
	 <1053580476.1008.20.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
	 <E19IiRk-00054y-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>  <3ECCE6B9.3070103@ardware.net>
Message-ID: <1053620096.1008.68.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Thu, 2003-05-22 at 08:03, Andrew Dennis wrote:
> When I add the vga=ask boot option, I get a choice.  When I
> choose scan, the monitor flickers and makes that switching sound,
> and then gives me the same choices.  No matter what I choose
> I get the same response.  As soon as it goes to boot, I get the
> black screen.

It didn't look to me like the vga mode has anything to do with the frame
buffer being on or not.

After a couple of intimate minutes with google, I think that the vga=ask
is used to configure the video mode that the frame buffer should use. 
The documents don't mention anything about booting without frame
buffers, but they do mention using vga=792 to boot to a sane mode.  I
don't know if that will work, but it looks easy enough to try.

If it still won't work, and you can't afford to try a different video
card, then I really think your only other option is to learn how to
compile your own kernel, with frame buffers disabled.  It really isn't
that difficult, especially if you can track down a working
configuration.  

A small word of advice, make sure that you can boot some sort of rescue
disk before taking on the kernel compilation.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

> This is a tough one for me to grasp.  I've already given up trying
> to get X to run over ssh but now I can't use vim as root, only as
> me.  I get this message:
>
> X11 connection rejected because of wrong authentication.
> X connection to localhost:10.0 broken (explicit kill or server
> shutdown).

Can you run through the entire process for us? E.g.,

1. Login into client under username whatever
2. Run startx
3. Open xterm
4. Run su (the exact invocation would be helpful)
5. ssh to server
6. try to run vim

The whole X authentication cookie scheme can be difficult, and how you 
get to root matters.

Also, could you post the results of

  grep -E 'X|Root' /etc/ssh/*config

when run on both the server and the client?

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

/etc/ssh/ssh_config:   ForwardX11 no
/etc/ssh/sshd_config:PermitRootLogin no 
/etc/ssh/sshd_config:X11Forwarding yes
/etc/ssh/sshd_config:X11DisplayOffset 10

/etc/ssh/ssh_config:   ForwardX11 yes
/etc/ssh/sshd_config:# This sshd was compiled with PATH=/bin:/usr/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/X11R6/bin
/etc/ssh/sshd_config:PermitRootLogin yes
/etc/ssh/sshd_config:#ForwardX11 yes
/etc/ssh/sshd_config:X11Forwarding yes

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Thu May 22 11:12:01 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Thu May 22 11:12:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] DISLIN
In-Reply-To: <20030522175057.32462.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030522175057.32462.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>

First thing to try is copying all of the .so.8 files you created through 
symlinking directly into the $DISLIN/lib folder.

If it does not, try removing the -L$DISLIN from the compile command (NOT the 
-ldislin). This is only needed if you did not create the symlinks. 

Wish I could help more, sorry.

Setting your XAUTHORITY environment variable (as root) to the full path of
your individual .Xauthority file also works.

This way SSH has the proper authentication info for the funky DISPLAY it
creates.

The right choice via vga=ask does the same.

default console will not have a frame buffer.

monitor after the kernel boots work?

From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Thu May 22 14:47:01 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Thu May 22 14:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The latest on SCO vs. reality
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305221326190.22322@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305220632410.21960-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305221326190.22322@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1053639907.25208.24.camel@zadie>

On Thu, 2003-05-22 at 16:32, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Thu, 22 May 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
> >    Then they claimed to find hunks of orthodox UNIX code leveraged
> >    into Linux somehow, though at this writing they still haven't offered
> >    the evidence. Unwilling to sue themselves, they "suspended" their
> >    Linux business and warned Linux users about the "potential liability
> >    that could rest with them for using such software" while offering to
> >    "hold harmless" their own remaining Linux customers.
> 
> It seems to me that if SCO owns the patents and copyrights it claims are
> implemented or copied in Linux code that the Linux distribution they
> created would be de facto licensing of those copyrights and patents under
> the GPL.
> 
> I know that if _I_ release code under the GPL that contains patents or
> copyrights that I own, I can't go around suing people who create or
> distribute derivitave work based on my patented or copyrighted code.
> 
> How is that not grounds for immediate dismissal of this suit?
> 
> J.

let's imagine, for a moment, that I wrote a linux driver for a piece of
hardware, and I released the binary under a free-to-distribute, but no
source, license. 

Now, let's imagine, that in a moment of drunken buffoonery, I gave away
access to my machine to, oh, _you_. 

Now, you can grab the source of my code, which I stupidly left in a
world-readable home directory, and distribute it.

We're all agreed that that's not legal, right?

So then let's imagine I didn't know about this totally illegal thing,
even though it made Slashdot and this mailing list and whatever, and I
decided I wanted to make a Bigger Better Linux Distribution whose big
goal was going to be how good the hardware support was.

So I went and got all the big distributions, and put together all their
drivers, and made it into a distribution, and sold it/gave it away
(under the gpl).

Whoops! Wait a minute! My driver was in there.

Under your statement, it's now GPL'd, and the fact that I didn't
actually gpl it, I just included a previously gpl'd copy in my
distribution, is irrelevant.

I dearly hope that's not what the law says, because if it is, EVERY
business in the world is going to hate and fear the gpl.

If SCO's lawsuit is shot down, it should, nay must be shot down because
they don't have the evidence to prove infringement. If IBM took UNIX
code and put it in Linux, they had better lose and they had better pay.

Software has gotten too big and too complex for it to be easy to keep
track of everything that went into it, especially something like a
distribution. It will be too easy for some programmer to grab a GPL'd
piece of code and use it in his code, assuming that since the final
project will be GPL it's okay. One of those programmers is going to
realize a week later that the code he just released to the world wasn't
GPL'd by its owners.

And that's the real trick: The argument you use says that somebody else
can GPL your code.

Jeff

Apparently it wants to see something like this in your
.bash_profile, or whatever your distribution uses:

DISLIN=/home/rtk/dislin
PATH=$PATH:$HOME/bin:$DISLIN/bin
LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$DISLIN:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
export PATH DISLIN LD_LIBRARY_PATH

I'm still not quite sure what it does, but it
definitely does something. Whether it is useful is
something you'll have to determine for yourself. As I
said earlier, I am seeking graphical capabilities for
languages that do not traditionally support them.

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu May 22 18:00:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu May 22 18:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The latest on SCO vs. reality
In-Reply-To: <1053639907.25208.24.camel@zadie>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305220632410.21960-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
  <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305221326190.22322@shaft.bitmine.net> <1053639907.25208.24.camel@zadie>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305221750550.25320@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 22 May 2003, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> And that's the real trick: The argument you use says that somebody else
> can GPL your code.

Not quite.  I'm arguing that SCO GPL'd their own code when they released
their distribution.

They may have done so by mistake, but (assuming they have a real claim to
any of the code in the Linux kernel, which is a HUGE assumption...) they
did, in fact, distribute it under the GPL.

Any distribution of copyrighted or use of patented material BEFORE the
time of SCO's distribution is fair game in the courts and they should
(under the law, not under any justifiable moral code) be able to sue for
whatever damages were incurred in that time.

Quite frankly, if you're going to print up some CDs and put your name on
them, you'd better darn well know what's on those discs.

Of course, we can all avoid messes like this by collecting explicit
copyright transfer in a central location for each project.  The Free
Software Foundation has done a great job for the GNU stuff, but Linus has
been notoriously lax in this regard.

If anything's going to kill the GPL, it's going to be that kind of lazy
selfishness.  Recall the hypothetical situation that caused Apple to ban
underage developers from the Darwin project.  If you don't (or can't)
enter into a legal contract and sign over your copyright to the maintainer
of the code, you might, at some point in the future, dispute the
maintainer's claim of copyright on the work and attempt to collect
royalties on the work.

Incidentally, this same failure to properly document and aggregate
copyrights on updates and patches is the only thing fuelling the schism
between GNU and XEmacs.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

From jschwaber at wesleyan.edu  Thu May 22 18:43:02 2003
From: jschwaber at wesleyan.edu (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Thu May 22 18:43:02 2003

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305221750550.25320@shaft.bitmine.net>

	 <1053639907.25208.24.camel@zadie>

Message-ID: <1053654110.25208.40.camel@zadie>

On Thu, 2003-05-22 at 20:59, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Thu, 22 May 2003, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> > And that's the real trick: The argument you use says that somebody else
> > can GPL your code.
> 
> Not quite.  I'm arguing that SCO GPL'd their own code when they released
> their distribution.
> 
> They may have done so by mistake, but (assuming they have a real claim to
> any of the code in the Linux kernel, which is a HUGE assumption...) they
> did, in fact, distribute it under the GPL.

See this is exactly the argument I'm afraid of--it means the default
corporate policy, for safety, must be no use of open source code or
projects. Because something like this might happen accidentally, and
then you're screwed.

I'm not convinced that their distribution of it is licensing it under
the GPL--the gpl is an explicit statement by the copyright owners of the
copyright. They never wrote their own statement entering the pieces into
the GPL--the GPL is, to some degree, a choice. The idea that they can de
facto GPL something by accident is grotesque.

> Any distribution of copyrighted or use of patented material BEFORE the
> time of SCO's distribution is fair game in the courts and they should
> (under the law, not under any justifiable moral code) be able to sue for
> whatever damages were incurred in that time.
> 
> Quite frankly, if you're going to print up some CDs and put your name on
> them, you'd better darn well know what's on those discs.

Hmm...quite frankly, if you're going to print up some chips at a fab,
you damn well better known how they run.

It's gotten to the point that complexity is overmatching those who
attempt to manage it, even with management techniques, simplification
strategies, code reuse, etc. Software projects can have hundreds of
developers on them, and projects can use dozens of libraries. No one
person could possibly know everything that goes into the largest of
projects.

> Of course, we can all avoid messes like this by collecting explicit
> copyright transfer in a central location for each project.  The Free
> Software Foundation has done a great job for the GNU stuff, but Linus has
> been notoriously lax in this regard.

The problem with this is that you are now giving up your copyright to a
third party that you have no control over. You've lost all of the rights
of copyright, even those left to you by the GPL. The FSF has taken them
over. If the FSF decides tomorrow to start selling Gnu projects for
money with no source code, they can. That cannot happen in Linux,
because too many people own the copyright to too many pieces of the
code. And in my mind, that's a good thing. Open Source is a community,
and the FSF has decided to be dictator over that community, and while
they did found it, that's rather presumptious.

Jeff

shell out (bash, naturally) $1,500 for the full convention's "early bird"
price, then ORA is right to charge that much. If ony a half-dozen folks show
up, then next year's price is guaranteed to be lower.

> somewhat complicated and may take awhile to achieve

It turns out that Dislin was the sort of thing I was
looking for. It stores the data points in arrays
before doing any plotting, though, so it is definitely
not interactive.

There are example programs on Dislin's Web site,
www.dislin.de. If you want the output to go to your
X-Window monitor, which is probably what you do want,
the following code, in the language you are using (in
this case, Fortran 77) should be inserted above CALL
DISINI and as close to it as possible:

CALL METAFL('XWIN')

In this case, it was worth the trouble to overcome the
obstacles to using a program. Fortran was the first
computer language I learned, but when I first learned
it such capabilities were not available, at least
where I was learning it.

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu May 22 20:59:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu May 22 20:59:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The latest on SCO vs. reality
In-Reply-To: <1053654110.25208.40.camel@zadie>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305220632410.21960-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
  <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305221326190.22322@shaft.bitmine.net>  <1053639907.25208.24.camel@zadie>
  <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305221750550.25320@shaft.bitmine.net> <1053654110.25208.40.camel@zadie>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305222043440.27288@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 22 May 2003, Jeff Schwaber wrote:
> See this is exactly the argument I'm afraid of--it means the default
> corporate policy, for safety, must be no use of open source code or
> projects. Because something like this might happen accidentally, and
> then you're screwed.

Huh?  You're only "screwed" when you distribute the stuff under the GPL.
That doesn't mean you can't use it.

> It's gotten to the point that complexity is overmatching those who
> attempt to manage it, even with management techniques, simplification
> strategies, code reuse, etc.

Well, score one for simplicity, then.

> The problem with this is that you are now giving up your copyright to a
> third party that you have no control over. You've lost all of the rights
> of copyright, even those left to you by the GPL. The FSF has taken them
> over. If the FSF decides tomorrow to start selling Gnu projects for
> money with no source code, they can.

No, they can't.  The GPL REQUIRES all derivative work to be released under
the GPL.

Remember, the GPL is a copyleft.  It turns copyright against itself.

This is exactly what Microsoft was talking about when they said it was the
opposite of intellectual property and "unamerican".

> That cannot happen in Linux, because too many people own the copyright
> to too many pieces of the code.

Just the opposite.  Linus cannot prove he holds the copyright to much of
the work and the various copyright holders could contest the inclusion of
that code in the kernel and hinder its development and distribution.  The
copyright holding author could claim that he did NOT give permission for
his code to be released under the GPL and everyone suffers.

> Open Source is a community, and the FSF has decided to be dictator over
> that community, and while they did found it, that's rather presumptious.

Again, just the opposite.  The FSF has offered to be caretaker of the one
thing of which we all agree must be taken care:  the freedom of the
source.

Personally, I don't mind if it's the FSF or IBM or Debian or Irene
Developer, esq..  What matters to me is that there is a discernable chain
of transfer of control of the copyrights into a GPL release.  With no
formal statement, the ambiguity can create a nightmare.

In the XEmacs versus GNU fiasco, the problem isn't that the FSF doesn't
have the copyright, it's that the copyrights are not clear AT ALL.  There
are patches that were submitted via email, for example, without any
document that might be construed as consent to include it in a GPL
application for public distribution.  When you are a sole developer, the
COPYING or LICENSE file you include is just such a statement.  "This
package is free software", etc.  And getting back to the original point,
SCO actively distributed Linux kernel source with just such a statement
attached.  That's pretty much the definition of releasing the code under
the GPL.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu May 22 21:18:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu May 22 21:18:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PLUG an O'Reilly User Group?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305221838230.26212-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305221838230.26212-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305222102580.27288@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 22 May 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Value, of course, is set by the consumer.

Of course?  Let's be a bit more open-minded, shall we?  This kind of dogma
is thrown around without even the slightest shred of justification.  Like
when people say, "Of course, the free market produces the best possible
solutions.", etc.

> If enough folks are willing to shell out (bash, naturally) $1,500 for
> the full convention's "early bird" price, then ORA is right to charge
> that much.

They're RIGHT to charge that much?

If I drilled a well at the edge of the desert and sold glasses of water
(which I received more or less for free from Mother Earth, minus some tiny
cost per gallon in upfront drilling and pumping), would I be RIGHT in
charging $10,000 a glass to the dessicated souls who crawl out of the
barren wastes dying of thirst?

Surely those people would be WILLING to pay for the life-giving fluid, but
is that really what it's worth to me?

I maintain that value is set by the possessor.  A thing is worth that
which would allow you to part with it without regrets.

For a glass of water to a man who controls a well, that would be just
about nothing.  For a seat in a convention hall with a prestigious
speaker, it would be a combination of what it is worth to the hall
maintainers to give up the use of their precious space and the speaker for
the trouble of coming out and speaking to those present.

There is usually a great difference between what CAN charge and what you
SHOULD ask.

And remember that putting the value in the mind of the purchaser, all good
and unique things go to the wealthiest people whether they can be used or
not.  There are people in this world that would part with their summer
villa in the south of France with as much regret as you or I part with a
stack of token ring NICs.

In a system where the purchaser sets the value, everything has the highest
possible price and having becomes indistinguishable from using.  In a
system where the possessor sets the value, those who need can more readily
obtain from those who do not.

J.
-- 
   -----------------
     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------
 [cc] counter-copyright
 http://www.openlaw.org

restitution.

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Fri May 23 01:38:01 2003
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Fri May 23 01:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The latest on SCO vs. reality
In-Reply-To: <88FA49DAE6B6D611AD740002A5072D3C06A9D7BF@orsmsx111.jf.intel.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0305222221140.3102-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Thu, 22 May 2003, Petcher, Danielx J wrote:

> I could have the situation confused, but I believe it is their (SCO's)
> opinion that some party or parties have appropriated their code without
> permission or license and included said code in a body of work that was
> released under GPL.
>
> SCO never published the alleged code under GPL; they merely accuse the
> plaintiffs of having re-published their code without permission.
>
The problem with this lawsuit is that the SCO Group's [*] claim is so
vague: at first they claimed IBM contributed intellectual property
stolen from them to Linux development, then it was contributions to the
Linux kernel, & now it appears that they are claiming that Linux
developers have been stealing from the codebase the SCO group now owns
for years.

(Frankly, as someone who has used SCO Unix several times over the years,
SCO is about the last flavor of UNIX I would want to steal ideas from,
let alone source code! And I know I am not alone in this regard.)

While Jeme's argument -- that the SCO Group nee Caldera should have known
their intellectual property was in the version of Linux they were selling --
is plausible, it only responds to one piece of the SCO Group's claims.
Likewise, although ESR's whitepaper plausibly argues that any of the
code SCO could be complaining about did not reach the Linux development
group thru IBM's involvement in the Monterey project, it does not respond
to the SCO Group's other claims.

Until the SCO Group's claims become more detailed, there is simply no
way for anyone to respond to them intelligently. I think what we Linux
enthusiasts have to keep in mind are some very simple facts:

* The SCO Group's revenues in the last year have fallen by 50%, & not only
are they hemmorrhaging losses in revenue, they have less than $5 million
in cash left.

* Darl MacBride's profile on the SCO Group's webpage talks much about his
ability to raise funding, but lacks anything concrete about his ability
as a manager or his vision for technology.

* The SCO Group has been signalling over the previous months that they
would be looking for ways to capitalize on their ``intellectual property
rights."

* Ignoring what Caldera had, & what assets SCO & Xenix UNIX gave
them, their jewel in the crown was ownership of the UNIX O/S source code.

Apparently MacBride couldn't figure out how to broker a new deal for
licensing the rights to UNIX, so he decided to sue somebody to provide
enough cash so The SCO Group could figure out their next move. And if the
judge laughs in MacBride's face next month over revoking IBM's license to
UNIX, this lawsuit will become even less worisome to everyone involved.

Geoff

[*] Please keep in mind The SCO Group & the Santa Cruz Organization (SCO)
are two different entities. Some of us have enough reason to hate SCO,
having used their operating system; launching a barratrous suit against
IBM is not one of them.

Print server (glide):

        :ml#0:\
        :mx#0:\
        :sd=/var/spool/lpd/epson:\
        :af=/var/spool/lpd/epson/epson.acct:\
        :sh:\
        :lp=/dev/lp0:\
        :lpd_bounce=true:\
        :if=/usr/share/printconf/util/mf_wrapper:

Workstation (halo):

epson_glide:\
        :ml#0:\
        :mx#0:\
        :sd=/var/spool/lpd/epson_glide:\
        :af=/var/spool/lpd/epson_glide/epson_glide.acct:\
        :sh:\
        :rm=glide:\
        :rp=epson:\
        :lpd_bounce=true:\
        :if=/usr/share/printconf/util/mf_wrapper:

From edasher at javelin.net  Fri May 23 18:29:02 2003
From: edasher at javelin.net (Erik)
Date: Fri May 23 18:29:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The latest on SCO vs. reality
In-Reply-To: <1053664220.991.620.camel@main>
Message-ID: <000501c32193$cc203dc0$651010ac@lemonhead>

Normally I'd agree with the idea that the big money will win the case
regardless of the facts, or as Steve says "the ridiculous against
reality is an even match."

This situation has important differences:
1. SCO (and perhaps Micro$oft) are suing IBM.  Even if Microsoft
acquires SCO and sues IBM directly, IBM still has the resources it needs
to defend its self.
2. IBM will vigorously defend its self, and the GPL to whatever extent
serves IBM's purposes.  IBM is deeply involved with the GPL and with
Linux, yes?
3. The government isn't directly involved in this case.  In the Milken,
Lay, Skilling and the M$ antitrust case, the government was the
plaintiff (I'm guessing that somehow Milken, Lay and Skilling have so
far dodged other lawsuits).

These differences mean that we have more reasons than usual to be
optimistic.

I'm still trying to figure out what the best possible outcome would be.
I'm pretty sure I don't want Microsoft purchasing SCO outright.  I
believe the Linux community would be better served if IBM acquired SCO,
but only after a successful counter suit.  Someone needs to make an
example of Blake Stowell, Chris Sontag, Darl McBride and the rest of
SCO's officers.  Otherwise this kind of thing will continue.

-EcD.

After lurking on this thread for a while it dawned on me that you all
have a really good grasp on what *needs* to happen in this case. So now
let's take a look at what reality is in this country:

http://www.forbes.com/finance/lists/setters/keywordSearchSetter.jhtml?pa
ssYear=2002&passListId=54&passListType=Person&passKeyword=Milken

For those of you that don't remember Mr. Milken, he did a couple of
years in club fed for something that really resembles the current tech
stock scams. The interesting thing about Milken is that he's still the
301st richest American with a personal wealth of 775M, even after his 2
year vacation - that's right, his assets remained intact when they
should have been seized and returned to his victims in an attempt at
restitution.

What does this have to do with SCO; Not a thing, but it has everything
to do with reality. If you don't believe me, just ask Jeff Skilling and
Ken Lay, I'm certain they would be happy to look you in the eye and
smile as they tell you that money wins.

I guess the moral here is that pitting the ridiculous against reality is
an even match.

I apologize for the digression, I couldn't resist.

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Fri May 23 20:10:03 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Fri May 23 20:10:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The latest on SCO vs. reality
In-Reply-To: <000501c32193$cc203dc0$651010ac@lemonhead>
References: <000501c32193$cc203dc0$651010ac@lemonhead>

As I said originally, my post was a digression, do with it what you will
but remember that it was never intended to have a clean fit into the SCO
vs. IBM saga.

Speaking of this saga; I'm sure most of you have heard that Microsoft
has licensed SCO's Unix source code and patents but are we all aware
that many in the IBM user communities are speculating that IBM will
settle this case out of court to save the defense costs? Think about the
impact that scenario would have.

On Fri, 2003-05-23 at 18:28, Erik wrote:
> Normally I'd agree with the idea that the big money will win the case
> regardless of the facts, or as Steve says "the ridiculous against
> reality is an even match."
> 
> This situation has important differences:
> 1. SCO (and perhaps Micro$oft) are suing IBM.  Even if Microsoft
> acquires SCO and sues IBM directly, IBM still has the resources it needs
> to defend its self.
> 2. IBM will vigorously defend its self, and the GPL to whatever extent
> serves IBM's purposes.  IBM is deeply involved with the GPL and with
> Linux, yes?
> 3. The government isn't directly involved in this case.  In the Milken,
> Lay, Skilling and the M$ antitrust case, the government was the
> plaintiff (I'm guessing that somehow Milken, Lay and Skilling have so
> far dodged other lawsuits).
> 
> These differences mean that we have more reasons than usual to be
> optimistic.
> 
> I'm still trying to figure out what the best possible outcome would be.
> I'm pretty sure I don't want Microsoft purchasing SCO outright.  I
> believe the Linux community would be better served if IBM acquired SCO,
> but only after a successful counter suit.  Someone needs to make an
> example of Blake Stowell, Chris Sontag, Darl McBride and the rest of
> SCO's officers.  Otherwise this kind of thing will continue.
> 
> -EcD.

> 
> Apaarently the processor in the TI-92 is just a Z80.

The TI-8x calculators were Z80-powered, with the exception of the '89.
The TI-89 and -92 were based on the Motorola 68000. Not shabby for a
hand calculator. Lots of folks have spent time hacking on these things,
too. You can even do your own assembly programming, if you're into that
sort of pain. :-)

<http://www.ticalc.org/>

Hi Geoff, LTNS!

Software to run SNMP server and client software is at
http://www.net-snmp.org/ . This is the rewrite of the ucd-snmp. The
current rev, 5.0.8, is the best one they've released since 4.2.3.

We use snmx from http://www.snmx.com/ to poke around the MIBs. It lets
you navigate them as if they were a UNIX FS (cd, ls, etc.).

From pundit at teleport.com  Sun May 25 12:09:01 2003
From: pundit at teleport.com (Ken Barber)
Date: Sun May 25 12:09:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The issue that just won't go away
Message-ID: <200305251207.08121.pundit@teleport.com>

Folks,

Now the antics of open source's opponents has caught the
 attention of Steve Duin:

http://www.oregonlive.com/news/oregonian/steve_duin/index.ssf?/base/news/105377817415280.xml

For those of you who live outside the Portland, OR area, you might 
say that Duin (pronounced "dean") is the dean of political 
columnists in Oregon -- he's been writing for years and is 
probably the state's most-respected and most-widely-read local
pundit.  He's the one who broke the story last year about
Microsoft threatening software audits of cash-strapped public
schools at a time of year when they had neither the time nor the
personnel to prepare for it -- and then offered a way out via a
new licensing scheme that would have cost dozens of teaching
positions.

When I got a call from Duin the other day, I knew that the lid
 was about to blow off of the whole stinking mess that Oregon's
 open source bill has turned into.  Though all observers now
 agree that HB 2892 is "probably" dead, the issue just will not
 go away and it's turning into a political liability for Oregon
 Speaker of the House Karen Minis, who ordered the bill killed
 last month.

Duin's column appears in today's Sunday Oregonian, which (for 
those of you outside the Portland area) is the most widely-read 
newspaper in Oregon and southwest Washington.  Earlier this month 
a guest editorial that I wrote* appeared in the same paper, after 
which insiders in the State Capitol reported that Minnis was 
"tearing her hair as we speak."

It looks like Karen Minnis is about to have another bad hair day.

Ken Barber

* That column can be viewed at:
http://www.oregonlive.com/commentary/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/editorial/1051876782142831.xml 
--
"Government is a health hazard.  Governments have killed many
 more people than cigarettes or unbuckled seat belts ever have."
 --P.J. O'Rourke

> 
> It's probably a nessus scan ( www.nessus.org ). Everything in the logs

Steve,

Thanks for the nessus pointer. I wasn't aware of this tool (looks
interesting). However, the scan didn't come from the LAN side of my
firewall, it came from Taiwan - which leads me to believe that either:

(1) the originating host was infected with a worm, or
(2) if it was nessus at work, they had misconfigured it, since (quoting the
nessus FAQ)...

1.5.5. What kind of a hole must I punch in my firewall to let nessus do it's
  job?

  To be honest: If you put any kind of firewall on the nessus server or
  between the nessus server and the host you are trying to test you will get
  a distorted result. You will not be able to rely on the results from your
  scan.

  Putting a firewall on the nessus server to secure the nessus server is an
  incorrect approach. (Or at least an incomplete approach.) Harden the
  server instead.

  If you have a firewall between the host you are about to test and the
  nessus server then you will get a result that is not similar to that of
  testing the host directly. This may be the desired result. If you want to
  be 100% sure you have hardened you host you should not rely on a firewall
  in front of it.

cheers,
Sandy

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Mon May 26 07:15:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Mon May 26 07:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Good grief, Charlie Brown (massive worm assault)
In-Reply-To: <20030525222934.GA6461@kippered.herring.org>
References: <20030525222934.GA6461@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <200305252306.46475.matt@legalizefreedom.org>

My 2 cents:

I run a web server here at home (apache!).. I use Comcast cable service. I 
get, on average, at LEAST 10 of these "hack" scans a day from different 
addresses in the Comcast world.  In my case 99.99% of these scans are other 
Comcast subscribers.... There are 4 or 5 regular offenders (10 scans a day, 
everyday, for weeks) that I have forwarded on to abuse at comcast.. Script 
kiddies at home testing out their scripts on the "broadband lan". It's 
amazing too - some of these people will run the scan for minutes on end, 
sucking up a TON of bandwidth and being a general nuissance. (I just checked 
- this month ~ 75%, or 3000 of 3900 of my hits (according to webalizer) have 
resulted in 404s.)

I have taken to doing reverse scans on the heavy abusers.. You would be 
surprised how many of these morons have NO firewall and NO security.. I have 
yet to see one scan report any of these would-be hackers running anything 
other than the standard M$ fare.. ;-)

I have NEVER had anyone from overseas yet running that type of scan (they tend 
to portscan). If you run Comcast, I can GUARANTEE you are getting these 
scans. 

Matt

> RewriteRule ^.*$ /duzintwash.html [R=301,L]
> RewriteCond %{HTTP_REFERER} NULL [NC]
> RewriteCond %{HTTP_USER_AGENT} NULL [NC]
> RewriteRule ^.*$ /duzintwash.html [R=301,L]
>

From buchholz at easystreet.com  Mon May 26 09:06:02 2003
From: buchholz at easystreet.com (Don Buchholz)
Date: Mon May 26 09:06:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SNMP Browser?
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0305242147120.3102-100000@joan.burling.com>
Message-ID: <3ED23B3B.7080501@easystreet.com>

no browser suggestions, but SNMP is not dead ...

One extremely practical tool which utilizes SNMP -- MRTG 
(http://www.mrtg.org).

You may also want to check out the Simple Times: 
 http://www.simple-times.org

SNMP is used by a lot of remotely-managed devices (e.g. 802.11 access 
points, Brocode
SAN switches, IBM (LSI) SAN servers, to name a few) which require you to 
load
a "management application", and then control/manage the device from a remote
workstation.

From drl at drloree.com  Mon May 26 09:10:03 2003
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon May 26 09:10:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Mandrake 9.1 Virtual server problem
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSU.4.21.0305260337410.19159-100000@garcia.efn.org>
References: <Pine.GSU.4.21.0305260337410.19159-100000@garcia.efn.org>
Message-ID: <1053965464.2439.21.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Mon, 2003-05-26 at 03:39, James wrote:
> I know this isn't the Apache mail list, but in fact, I can't find an
> Apache mail list.. if someone knows of a good one, please direct me to it.
> 
> To start off, it might be best to point out the fact that I have a web
> server running Mandrake 7.1 without any problems.. including virtual
> domain serving.  I'm not sure why I am having problems with Mandrake 9.1
> and virtual servers, but I am.
> 
> When I connect Mandrake 9.1 to the Internet, I can access the Apache
> server through any other computer connected to the Internet by using the
> IP address, but when I try to access a virtual server on Mandrake 9.1 via
> name (for example, http://www.powwowdance.com), the web browser cannot
> find any such server.  
> 
> Question #1:
> How long should I wait before the virtual server (assuming it is set up
> correctly) is accessible to everyone on the Internet?  I've waited at
> least 2 hours to see if it has propagated, but it still doesn't connect.
> 
These are more DNS questions than apache questions.  The apache server
becomes aware of any and all changes as soon as you restart the server,
and it successfully loads the new configuration.  No waiting.  Changes
to DNS are the ones that take time to propagate.
 
> Question #2:
> I have a server running Mandrake 7.1 that works just fine.  Its virtual
> servers all work well, and its ip address is 63.224.195.57 with a virtual
> web server name set at www.vivid-eye.com.  I am installing Mandrake 9.1 on
> a completely different  computer, which I can also connect to the Internet
> at the same time.  If I number the Mandrake 9.1 server to 63.224.195.56 in
> order to keep the 9.1 server online at the same time as the 7.1 server,
> will giving the 9.1 server the vivid-eye.com name conflict with the
> current 7.1 server name?  I'd like to run the new 9.1 server all the time
> to see if it's just a propagation problem, but I don't want it to conflict
> with the 7.1 server.  What can I do?

This won't test the "propagation" problem, it will just create on.  If
you change the ip address in your DNS zone, then it will take time to
propagate, if both servers are up and running, and serving out the same
content, then your clients will never know the difference.  However, if
one of your servers is broken, then your clients will be migrated to a
broken server and will notice the change.

> 
> Question #3:
> This is my current setup for the new 9.1 server, does it look correct?  If
> it does look correct, then I don't know why I can't access the new 9.1
> server (P.S. http://www.powwowdance.com will probably work fine if you
> check it now, because I will have connected the working server by the time
> you read this):
> 
No, you need to specify a unique server name for each virtual host.  You
have only specified your domain name for the server name of each virtual
host, not a unique server name.

> I am using the latest Apache version, whichever one was shipped with
> Mandrake 9.1
> 
> ----------------------------------------------------------------
> httpd2.conf:
> 
> <VirtualHost 63.224.195.57>
> DocumentRoot /var/www/html/powwowdance
> ServerName powwowdance.com
            ^^^^
Here is where you need to have a machine name (like www.powwowdance.com
or dance.powwowdance.com or pow.powwowdance.com).

> </VirtualHost>
> ----------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> vhosts:
> 
> <VirtualHost 63.224.195.57>
> DocumentRoot /var/www/html/powwowdance
> ServerName powwowdance.com

I don't understand why you want two virtual hosts pointing to the same
directory with the same virtual host name.  Something needs to be unique
about this entry to make it useful.
> </VirtualHost>
> ----------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> named.conf:
> 
> zone "powwowdance.com" {
>         type master;
>         file "/var/named/pz/powwowdance.com";
> };
> 
> ---------------------------------------------------
> 
> var/named/pz/powwowdance.com:
> 
> 
> @       IN      SOA     powwowdance.com. james.vivid-eye.com. (
>                         200305231       ; Serial
>                         1H              ; Refresh
>                         1H              ; Retry
>                         1W              ; expire
>                         1H)             ; Minimum
> ;
>         NS              ns              ;Inet Address of name server
> ;
> localhost       A       127.0.0.1
> 
> 
> ns              A       63.224.195.57
> ns2             IN A    63.224.195.60    
> 
> 
> @       IN      A       63.224.195.57
> 
> 
> www     CNAME   ns       
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> Does the above look ok?  And if so, why can't I access that
> virtual domain from the Internet?

These should be ok, from what I've read, you might want to change the
www entry from CNAME to an A record (with the ip specified).

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

Robby Russell wrote:
> What is a proper method of downgrading? (running mdk 9)


You'll want to test this on something other than glibc first, but the man 
page says something like,

# rpm -Uvh --oldpackage glibc-<old.version-here>.rpm

should do it.  If rpm chokes during this, you're likely to be spending the 
rest of the day reinstalling the OS--so cross all your fingers.

Kyle Accardi




From stevea at nwtechops.com  Mon May 26 09:48:02 2003
