Subject: [PLUG] Good grief, Charlie Brown (massive worm assault)
In-Reply-To: <20030526035649.GA9133@kippered.herring.org>
References: <20030525222934.GA6461@kippered.herring.org>
	 <1053912505.906.38.camel@main> <20030526035649.GA9133@kippered.herring.org>
Message-ID: <1053967618.906.81.camel@main>

On Sun, 2003-05-25 at 20:56, Sandy Herring wrote:
> Steve,
> 
> Thanks for the nessus pointer. I wasn't aware of this tool (looks
> interesting). However, the scan didn't come from the LAN side of my
> firewall, it came from Taiwan - which leads me to believe that either:
> 
> (1) the originating host was infected with a worm, or
> (2) if it was nessus at work, they had misconfigured it, since (quoting the
> nessus FAQ)...
> 
> 1.5.5. What kind of a hole must I punch in my firewall to let nessus do it's
>   job?
> 
>   To be honest: If you put any kind of firewall on the nessus server or
>   between the nessus server and the host you are trying to test you will get
>   a distorted result. You will not be able to rely on the results from your
>   scan.
> 
>   Putting a firewall on the nessus server to secure the nessus server is an
>   incorrect approach. (Or at least an incomplete approach.) Harden the
>   server instead.
> 
>   If you have a firewall between the host you are about to test and the
>   nessus server then you will get a result that is not similar to that of
>   testing the host directly. This may be the desired result. If you want to
>   be 100% sure you have hardened you host you should not rely on a firewall
>   in front of it.

Well Sandy,
>From the look and feel of the logs that you sent in your earlier post,
the attacker is testing for many IIS vulnerabilities. Normally worms are
not that diverse, they'll check for a few at most ( over and over and
over in the case of sqlslammer ) due to the need to keep the code small.
The logs that you referenced earlier really look like an advance
scanning system of some sort since they touch on a large number of
possibilities. Just out of curiosity, have you looked at cert.org or
securityfocus.com to see what they have to say?

The faq that you quote above speaks to placing a firewall on the nessus
server (scan source) side, not on the destination side. Your machine
would be the destination. Also, some tools like this will allow you to
enter a number of valid addresses to use as the source address ( a form
of spoofing - nmap does this quite well ) so there is no guarantee that
these requests are really coming from Taiwan. Besides, if you are
listening for requests from the Internet on your machine and not using a
firewall capable of verifying packets then your effectively not
filtering those listening ports through a firewall.

to work with another OS as opposed to hitting the unemployment lines
only to have their position taken by someone else. It's a matter of
learning to master yet another tool - a lot like the difference between
using a hand saw and a chop saw.


> IT needs don't stop at the OS, they begin there. The idea is to shift

cost and removing all accountability )?

> >May you live in interesting times, is

I haven't seen anything different or interesting about this so far. It
looks like the typical argument that we see every time that the nation
slips into a recession. It's a good argument but, in reality, it picks
apart areas that have very little impact on budget or jobs.

On Mon, 2003-05-26 at 14:21, david pool wrote:
> I was accepting the argument that Linux maintenance consumes fewer 
> resources than Windows maintenance. My point was to shift those 
> additional resources. But, yes in some cases I believe it's good to 
> outsource IT. I don't buy the extra cost argument and as for 
> accoutability, we can always hire a local consultant who has a strong 
> reputation in the community for quality worksmanship. I'd wager he's 
> more accountable because his reputation is on the line.
> 

I firmly believe that Linux consumes far less platform resources but
when looking at Linux at the desktop I think that it's a wash with
windows - in some cases it will require more human resources. In fact,
at least for the short term, the resources to do the initial migration
will be far greater due to the training requirements of users and
administrators. The biggest selling factor that I see is the simple
dollars saved in license fees. These savings can be easily consumed when
the cost of contractors are added to the migration and I do see that as
being a budget road block.

I would love to believe that a contractor would be more accountable due
to reputation issues that you cite above but I've seen too many times
where the contractor just points a finger and goes back to work. In all
cases hiring a contractor to augment existing staff is cheaper than
adding head count to staff. Short term contractors are a budget blessing
but the nature of this thread is staff elimination and you can't
contract perm staff and expect that to save money.

By the way, this has been stimulating conversation but retooling ODOT IT
is not going to help the states budget woes. ODOT and it's agencies are
not funded by the general fund, they are funded by gasoline tax, license
and registration fees, federal highway funds and other sources.

> david pool

I'd like to reaffirm Steve's arguments and throw in a short rant of my
own for good measure.

As Steve keeps noting, playing any game without a full understanding of
the rules and strategies is a losing proposition. I have heard very few
arguments that have any consideration what-so-ever of the rules and
strategies of the game of government.

I keep hearing from the opposition from HB2892 that it is a "a solution
in search of a problem". I keep hearing on this list that HB2892 is a
solution to this problem or that problem.

I don't see HB2892 as a solution to anything. I see it as refining the
laws already on the state's books. Even if HB2892 eventually dies a
complete death, I hope you have learned much. I hope you learned that
there are already laws on the books that require the state to seek
vendor-neutral "open" systems. I hope you all learned the process by
which a bill becomes a law, and hence are more effective at helping
kill bad bills. I hope you all learned that agencies like DAS hold
public hearings where we can express our interest in keeping tax
dollars within the state rather than subsidizing out-of-state mega-
corporations.

I hope you all will learn that bickering over how many people can
be fired in any particular state department is probably not the best
argument we can be making at this point in time ;-)

-Eric

to keep a 'doze enterprise going?  I have, and I could never keep 
up with the work.  Ever had to keep a *nix environment going?  I 
have, and they took FAR less time to maintain.  And this is the

friends and taking care of personal business.  One even had his 
wife bring the dog into work every day, where he spent

say that in a typcal day most of us only did maybe three or four 
hours of real work.

far-away places 2-3 times per week to fix some stupid Windoze 
problem that could have been handled remotely if ODOT had been a 
'nix shop.  And in many cases, we were fixing the same problem 
we'd already fixed a week or two earlier.

And THAT, sir, is why I approached Rep. Barnhart with the proposal 
to write HB 2892.  I've worked at ODOT, I've seen the waste, and 
I figured that what I saw was only the tip of the State 
government iceberg.

From stevea at nwtechops.com  Mon May 26 20:31:02 2003
From: stevea at nwtechops.com (Steven A. Adams)
Date: Mon May 26 20:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Requium for HB 2802
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305261837470.6298-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305261837470.6298-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1054006183.906.271.camel@main>

On Mon, 2003-05-26 at 18:41, Rich Shepard wrote:
> Steve,
> 
>   You might be someone who can address a concern raised by Ballmer and the
> other Microserfs: that the training and support costs of linux are greater
> than those of Windoze so what appears to be "free software" costs much more
> in the end.
> 
>   No matter how I turn this around and look from different sides I cannot
> see what they claim is there. I run a _very_ small linux network. Over the
> past six years I've spent less time with the system than I did with the few
> months on NT-4 and the years before with DOS.
> 
>   I don't understand what 'training and support' costs are with linux that
> are so high. Can you explain it?
> 

Hey Rich,
The cost is not long term but it does exist. Training end-users to work
with Linux after years in Windows is going to require time and funds.
Success of said training will depend on the users tolerance for change.
Now granted, this will be a one (in some cases 2) time shot but it will
be a significant price for this states budget to fork out in a short
amount of time. Phased in with roll-outs of the operating system and
applications will ease the pain but only if the phase-in is planned over
a 4~6 year span.

Beyond end-user training there is a real problem meeting business
requirements for the current desktop applications that just don't exist
in the Linux world yet (e.g. Visio, Project). This issue will dictate
that some Windows desktop installations will not be able to be upgraded
to a real OS, thus the need to support multiple desktop platforms will
be necessary. Once desktop applications mature on gnome and/or kde then
this need for support will diminish.

In the infrastructure applications realm, things like enterprise
authentication and security, file and print services, enterprise
groupware and system management will need to come to life. Training
existing support staff will be time consuming and costly. Again, there
will be a period of time where both platforms will need to exist.

On the data center side of things, rewriting the current Windows
applications and retraining existing support staff will be costly and
time consuming as well. Again, these are very short term costs and when
all is said and done, it will result in server systems that are stable,
low cost and at least 35% faster than the same Windows application
server.

As for Balmer, he's been spending too much time in the marketing
department. The cost savings from eliminating the need for torturous
license fees, eliminating the mass quantities of software to keep a
Windows machine clean and virus free and eliminating the cost of
continued support for proprietary data transport and storage mechanisms 
make it about even with the scale tipping toward Linux. This is
primarily due to the obvious long term benefits of moving to an
open-source platform. Besides, Balmer's selling off his shares of MSFT
as we speak - I don't think he even believes in his own rhetoric.

http://money.cnn.com/2003/05/23/news/companies/msft_ballmer.reut/

In no way do I see that eliminating state positions will help the cause
for Linux or even be seen as a benefit of changing to Linux - those
positions will be needed to support the additional OS. I do see that
there can be significant savings in migrating services and servers to
Linux while supporting these services and servers with the current
staff. ODOT is currently, as well we should be, jumping all over these
savings where it's feasible to do so.

Hope this perspective helps,

Steve

> Beyond end-user training there is a real problem meeting business
> requirements for the current desktop applications that just don't exist

  I understand that dia (among other options) is a viable replacement for
Visio and MrProject is getting better all the time.

  More than a decade ago I was working for another consulting company. They
used to do things like org charts by hand. I started doing them on my
computer. And the office manager's response was, "Can you move this box to
the other side? Company policy is to have it on the left."

  "No", I responded.

  "Why not?"

  "Because that's how the programmers made the application. Does it really
matter on which side the administrative support box is placed?"

  "No, I guess not. Can you change this color here?"

  And so it went.

  Here's a thought: take a lesson from the clerks at Fourbucks Coffee who
started the concept of placing tip jars on the counter. Put a jar on your
desk with a sign, "If you don't like change, please remove it from your
pocket or purse and place it in this container." You might have a nice
salary supplement that way. :-)

> applications and retraining existing support staff will be costly and
> time consuming as well.

  I wonder ... I read that often Microsoft makes changes in their latest and
greatest releases that are not backwards compatible. Aren't there equivalent
costs just sticking with the Redmond religion?
 
> As for Balmer, he's been spending too much time in the marketing
> department.

  Well, duh! That's what Microsoft is: a marketing company. Just like IBM in
their heyday: no technological innovator but the finest marketing company

From stever at woo-hoo.com  Tue May 27 15:15:02 2003
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Tue May 27 15:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix whitelist?
In-Reply-To: <1047316170.24520.845.camel@red>
References: <34583.207.173.0.68.1047314414.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
        <1047316170.24520.845.camel@red>
Message-ID: <38169.207.173.0.68.1054073674.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

> On Mon, 2003-03-10 at 08:40, Steven Raymond wrote:
>> Is there an easy way to make a Postfix whitelist which says "accept
>> mail from so-and-so regardless of the other filters"?
>
> Yes, of course. Just create a map file with the IP address(es)
> of the remote mail server(s) you always want to receive mail
> from and refer to it in your smtpd_recipient_restrictions
> sections before the maps that block the mail.
> For example:
>
> smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
>       check_client_access = hash:/etc/postfix/goodip,
>       ...,
>       [your black lists]
>       ...,
>       permit mynetworks
>
> In the goodip file:
>
> 1.2.3.4   OK
> Don't forget to use the postmap program

I simply could not get this to work.  No errors, it just simply was
ineffective.  I created /etc/postfix/permit-domains, which consisted of:
domainname.com    OK
ipaddr^^^^        OK
(used both domain name and ip addr of the mail server just to be sure)

Added the line in main.cf:
smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
       check_client_access = hash:/etc/postfix/permit-domains,
....

Ran "postmap /etc/postfix/permit-domains" which generates a
permit-domain.db file.    (should main.cf say instead check_client_access
= hash:/etc/postfix/permit-domains.db?)

Then nothing else happened, still rejected the good emails based upon helo
checks.


Have gotten it to accept mail by domains by adding the following to
/etc/postfix/access, then postmap access:
domainname.com     OK
ipaddr^^^^         OK

I observe the following references to /etc/postfix/access in various parts
of main.cf:
smtpd_client_restrictions =
        permit_mynetworks,
...
        check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
        permit
smtpd_helo_required = yes
smtpd_helo_restrictions =
        permit_mynetworks,
...
        check_helo_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
...
        permit

smtpd_sender_restrictions =
...
        check_sender_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,
...
        permit

smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
        permit_mynetworks,
        check_recipient_access hash:/etc/postfix/access,


What's the functional difference between:
check_client_access
check_helo_access
check_sender_access
check_recipient_access
?

I'd prefer to have the stand-alone file per Ed's suggestion, rather than
mucking around in /etc/postfix/access, but that didn't work for reasons I
don't understand.  Any input is appreciated.
Thanks

On Tue, 27 May 2003, Steven Raymond wrote:

> Added the line in main.cf:
> smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
>        check_client_access = hash:/etc/postfix/permit-domains,
> ....
> 
> Ran "postmap /etc/postfix/permit-domains" which generates a
> permit-domain.db file.    (should main.cf say instead check_client_access
> = hash:/etc/postfix/permit-domains.db?)
> 
> Then nothing else happened, still rejected the good emails based upon helo
> checks.

  I have two files in addition to /etc/postfix/access. One is called
'badaddr' and contains the domain names I want to reject; the other is
'badip' and it contains the IP addresses I want to reject. In each file the
first entries are my white list.

  I'll have, for example,
this.domainisok.com	OK

and
123.45.678		OK

  Then I run /usr/sbin/postmap <badaddr|badip>

and they work.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue May 27 17:13:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue May 27 17:13:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix whitelist?
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305271711210.10308-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 27 May 2003, Steven Raymond wrote:

> What does your entry in main.cf look like which refers to the
> "badaddr|badip" files?

smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
        permit_mynetworks,
        reject_unauth_destination,
        check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/badip,
        check_client_access hash:/etc/postfix/badaddr,
        check_helo_access hash:/etc/postfix/helo_checks,
        check_sender_access hash:/etc/postfix/badaddr,
        check_recipient_access hash:/etc/postfix/recipients,
        reject_rbl_client relays.ordb.org,
        reject_rbl_client china.blackholes.us,
        reject_rbl_client taiwan.blackholes.us,
        reject_rbl_client japan.blackholes.us,
        reject_rbl_client korea.blackholes.us,
        reject_rbl_client n-i-g-e-r-i-a.blackholes.us, // without the hyphens!
        reject_rbl_client argentina.blackholes.us,
        reject_rbl_client brazil.blackholes.us,
        reject_rbl_client thailand.blackholes.us,
        reject_rbl_client russia.blackholes.us,
        reject_rbl_client bl.spamcop.net,
        reject_rbl_client list.dsbl.org,
        reject_rhsbl_sender    dsn.rfc-ignorant.org
 
> Do you know if _both_ files are necessary?  Would it still work if you did
> one or the other?  Or could you specify both the domain name and ip
> address in the same file, or are both files needed?

  AFAIK, you could combine them in a single file. I find it easier to have
the divided among two files (one with names the other IP addresses).

  It may appear aggressive, but I'm down to 2-3 spam per day that slip
through. I can live with that. 

> Do you also use header_checks and body_checks files?

  Yup! Sure do. Right after the above I have:

header_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/header_checks
body_checks = regexp:/etc/postfix/body_checks

HTH,

Rich

  Did Mandrake give any reason for non-compatibility?  I suspect that 95% of the hardware is supported by Linux.  It must have a weird BIOS, an unsupported video chip, a broken USB, or some such nonsense.  It may even be something that you don't need.  

  I'd recommend booting up a Knoppix CD as a starting point then snoop around a bit.  Check the boot logs and /proc for hardware information.  Then google for installation info.  The Red Hat site has a hardware compatibility list.  The kernel developers mailing list is a great source of information about new hardware support.  

Steve Daggett

I guess you could shorten that to "change is a hard sell".

>> The very first thing that was cut out of the amended bill was the
>> justification clause.
>
>Interesting, I haven't seen the final product and wasn't aware that
>those cuts were made.

I had the benefit of sitting at the bargaining table.

I can't get to the Mid-Willamette Valley Linux User's Group page right
now, but Google tells me that the proposed admendments can be found
here:  http://www.mwvlug.org/legislation/index.html

Off the top-of-my-head, the amendments that DAS wrote were that all
"paper work" requirements were removed, "must consider open source" was
changed to "shall also consider open source", the term "open source" was
added to existing statutes, and that all definitions were left up to
DAS under administrative rule.

The amended bill had no teeth what-so-ever, it only acknowledged
the general concept of open source.  I guess that in itself was too
threatening...

   "The proposed amended bill still says that in every new software
   acquisition, state agencies shall consider open-source solutions,"
   said Jim Craven, lobbyist for the American Electronics Association,
   which opposes the bill. "It still has a 'shall' in there. I am not
   lobbying in opposition to open-source systems. Our concern with the
   bill is the mandate to state purchasers that they 'shall' do this or
   'shall not' do that."

Sigh. I guess my arguement that my agency's purchasers supported the
bill (in its original form) and the fact that DAS itself suggested and
drafted the admendments was not good enough...


-Eric

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Wed May 28 00:23:01 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Wed May 28 00:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] which distro for compaq notebook...or am I screwed?
In-Reply-To: <3ED39774.19018.1517A18A@localhost>
References: <3ED39774.19018.1517A18A@localhost>
Message-ID: <200305301313.40550.matt@legalizefreedom.org>

If you are willing to wait for the packages to compile I would suggest Gentoo. 
It can be intimidating to a newbie.. You basically install and compile your 
system from scratch. There are no "compatible" systems - it will work for 
you. 

Upside: You get a fully optimized system, optimized for your 
processor/platform. Gentoo has the greatest user forums I've ever seen in my 
entire life, anywhere, for anything. Easy going, wonderful people who will 
bend over backwards to help you. Gentoo is quick, and lite if you would like 
(a bonus for notebooks.) Bonus: You learn how linux works from the ground up.

Downside: You have to wait for ALL packages to compile. KDE takes ~ 12 hours 
to compile on an average to modern system. It can be intimidating for a new 
user to hear "you have to compile everything" (portage does it for you.) You 
have to download all packages, taking bandwidth and time. Negative: You learn 
how linux works from the ground up. (haha)

If you do decide to go with Gentoo, my username on forums.gentoo.org is qubex 
- I'm always willing to help a newbie with gentoo! :-)

Matt

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Wed May 28 00:28:02 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Wed May 28 00:28:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] More games on linux!
Message-ID: <200305301318.20942.matt@legalizefreedom.org>

To fill the void left by the late and great lokigames, Gentoo has formed a 
commercial group called Gentoo Gaming..  
<quote>
Gentoo Games, Inc. is a gaming technology company created to deliver 
innovative Linux-based game technologies to the public. Our mission is to 
advance Linux gaming.

The initial efforts of Gentoo Games will be focused around the Gentoo GameCD 
technology, which allows anyone with a modern PC to put a CD in their 
computer, turn it on, and have the GameCD boot directly into the game. The 
game runs from the GameCD, and the GameCD handles the auto-detection and 
configuration of all hardware.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed May 28 09:06:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed May 28 09:06:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Setting up pine for out-of-office auto replies
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305280839520.12559-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305280859050.9709-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 28 May 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Is there a way to configure pine for automatic responses when I'm
> out of town? I haven't found such information so I'd appreciate a
> pointer.

I don't think pine has an autoreponse type of filter.

Plus, I'm not convinced that having a vacation-ish feature in a mail
client is a good thing. You'd have to leave pine running while you're
out of town, making it easy to lose track of mailbox locks if you 
check your mail remotely while you're away.

> Also, if it is possible, I'd want to configure it to respond to mail
> arriving in my inbox, not the mail list messages that are directed
> to their individual files.

If you rely on pine (as opposed to procmail or sieve) to filter
messages for you, then afaict you're out of luck.

If you use procmail for filtering, then you could pretty easily add a 
pipe-to-vacation rule at the end of your .procmailrc.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

makers refuse to use it, opting instead for the market leader's
ill-designed products. Nothing seems to convince them that
alternatives are needed. Their computers are attacked time and time
again, year after year, and still they refuse to even consider
alternatives.

Why not affirmative action for technology? It's what we do when
society refuses to cure its ills.

mature. You may want to reconsider this.

From ali at axian.com  Wed May 28 09:23:02 2003

I do this by putting the following in my ~/.forward file:

\ali, "|vacation ali"

This drops the mail into my inbox AND pipes it through the vacation
program, which will respond with the message that you've put into
~/.vacation.msg.  Look at the vacation man page for the gory details.

Ali

On Wed, 2003-05-28 at 08:57, ml wrote:
> [from the knoppix mailing list]
> 
> Hi,
> 
> I successfully installed the current (Debian/unstable) XFCE4
> in Knoppix.  It is the best "light" GUI, I've seen so far
> and could replace xfce, wmaker, icewm, whatever.
> 
> Four steps were necessary:
> 
> 1. apt-get install xfwm4 xfprint4 xffm4 xfce4-utils \
>    xfce4-themes xfce4-mcs-plugins xfce4-mcs-manager \
>    xfce4-iconbox xfce4 gtk2-engines-xfce xfdeskmenu4 \
>    xfwm4-themes
> 
>    Remove stuff you don't need, because Knoppix is already
>    at it's size limits.
> 
> 2. rm -f /usr/lib/xf*/plugins/*.a (because of bug #192726)
> 
> 3. Add the following code to /etc/X11/Xsession.d/45xsession
>    somewhere:
> 
> startxfce4() {
>     playsound
>     GDK_USE_XFT=1
>     export GDK_USE_XFT
>     if [ ! -e $HOME/.xfce4 ]; then
>        cp -au /etc/skel/.xfce4/ /etc/skel/.xfwm4rc $HOME/
>     fi
>     /usr/bin/xfce-mcs-manager
>     /usr/bin/xfwm4 --daemon
>     /usr/bin/xftaskbar4 &
>     /usr/bin/xfdesktop &
>     exec /usr/bin/xfce4-panel
> }
> 
>    and near the end:
> 
>   xfce4|XFCE4) [ "$FREEMEM" -ge "35000" ] && startxfce4 || \
>     starttwm lowmem 64;
>   ;;
> 
>    And in /etc/init.d/knoppix-autoconfig add xfce4 to the
>    list of desktops.  I set the default value to xfce4, but
>    YMMV.
> 
>    [Thanks to Klaus Knopper for the information.]
> 
> 4. Copy your ~/.xfce4 directory and ~/.xfwm4rc file to 
>    /etc/skel/.  Set things nicely before, e.g. set the
>    background image to /usr/local/lib/knoppix.jpg.
> 
> Did I forget something?
> 
> OK, now re-master and burn your Knoppix, reboot it with
> knoppix desktop=xfce4 and enjoy.
> 
> Cheers!
> _______________________________________________
> Xfce mailing list
> Xfce at xfce.org
> http://moongroup.com/mailman/listinfo/xfce
-- 
Olivier Fourdan <fourdan at xfce.org>
http://www.xfce.org

_______________________________________________
Xfce mailing list
Xfce at xfce.org
http://moongroup.com/mailman/listinfo/xfce

From michael at robinson-west.com  Wed May 28 10:22:01 2003
From: michael at robinson-west.com (Michael C. Robinson)
Date: Wed May 28 10:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] smbmount problems under Redhat 7.3 and newer...
Message-ID: <1054142143.22046.6.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

It used to be that you added the suid bit to smbmount so that ordinary
users could mount their smb shares.  If you try that now the prorgam
spits out an error that it is not allowed.  Logging in as root to mount
the desired share doesn't work as the files end up being owned by root,
which is wrong.  The smbclient approach is annoying.  I've looked in
info under fstab and su but I haven't found anything helpful that would
either mount a user's network shares to his/her home directory at boot
or otherwise allow users to mount their smb shares without root
priviledge the way adding the suid bit used to.

     --  Michael

From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Wed May 28 12:59:01 2003
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: Wed May 28 12:59:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Requium for HB 2802
In-Reply-To: <20030528191101.15226.67891.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20030528191101.15226.67891.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <1054153220.13377.56.camel@ida.dylanreinhardt.com>

Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> wrote:
> You
> say that Open Source will win the battle on its merit and cost.
> This doesn't happen in most Microsoft shops. If it did, why would
> there still be Microsoft shops? Why would companies, for example,
> still be using IIS?

Indeed.  

I believe our problem is far more basic than anything likely to be
addressed by state law, to wit: We aren't offering what people want.

Technical people fervently believe that technical products should be
evaluated and purchased strictly on technical merits.  But it should be
more than obvious by this point that this isn't how it works.

What the world wants to buy and what Linux gurus offer aren't typically
in sync.  It's (perhaps) sad but true that human factors will trump
technical excellence every single time.

> Why not affirmative action for technology? It's what we do when
> society refuses to cure its ills.

It's a last resort for redressing *provable* harm that was done to a
specific group of people.  It is not an appropriate way to "correct"
market differences among various products.

After all, why stop with Linux?  Why not have affirmative action for the
Amiga?  Why not require that a certain percentage of state records be
stored on punch cards or cassette tape?  Don't punch card vendors
deserve a piece of the pie too?

> 
> You also said that Open Source will win when applications become
> mature. You may want to reconsider this.

I'd amend this to say that Open Source vendors will win when open source
*marketing* becomes more mature.  Really, most of us are still out there
talking about technical excellence, failing to notice that few
purchasing decisions hinge on technical excellence.  

I'd strongly recommend the book _Selling The Invisible_ to anyone who's
having difficulty selling their services.  It will do a lot more to
improve your cash flow than any act of state government is likely to.

FWIW,

Dylan

On Wed, May 28, 2003 at 11:02:16AM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Well, that's what Don Marti wrote in March and what ESR wrote earlier this
> ... What really
> puzzles me is how SCO's lawyers or whatnots could have cooked up this
> cockamamie scheme when they lack both patents and copyrights. Without those,
> what could be a claim basis?

The Official SCO statement on the matter is:

   http://biz.yahoo.com/prnews/030528/law059_1.html
   SCO Statement on Novell's Recent Actions
   Wednesday May 28, 10:15 am ET
   
   LINDON, Utah, May 28 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- The following statement is 
   being issued by SCO (Nasdaq: SCOX - News):
   
   SCO owns the contract rights to the UNIX? operating system. SCO has
   the contractual right to prevent improper donations of UNIX code,
   methods or concepts into Linux by any UNIX vendor.

   Copyrights and patents are protection against strangers. Contracts
   are what you use against parties you have relationships with. From a
   legal standpoint, contracts end up being far stronger than anything
   you could do with copyrights.

   SCO's lawsuit against IBM does not involve patents or copyrights. SCO's
   complaint specifically alleges breach of contract, and SCO intends
   to protect and enforce all of the contracts that the company has with
   more than 6,000 licensees.

   We formed SCOsource in January 2003 to enforce our UNIX rights and we
   intend to aggressively continue in this successful path of operation.

So they're suing IBM over a breach of contract.  Now I want to know how they
are going to pursue the 1500 large companies that they sent letters to, the
ones that threated to sue them over infringing code.  Presumably they don't
have a contratural relationship with SCO.

From ed at alcpress.com  Wed May 28 13:32:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)

On Wed, 2003-05-28 at 13:20, Dylan Reinhardt wrote:

> > Why not affirmative action for technology? It's what we do when
> > society refuses to cure its ills.
> 
> It's a last resort for redressing *provable* harm that was done to a
> specific group of people.  

But that's exactly what's happening. The specific group
of people being harmed are those people who have strong
technical skills but now have difficulty finding work
because technical knowledge and technical excellence is
no longer in high demand. This is not a case, like
coal stokers on locomotives, where skills have been made
obsolete by technological improvements that benefit
society. This is a case where not only is a class of
people being put out of work but society as a whole is
suffering for it - though they don't know it.

It's already taken a toll on this country. Much of the
American IT industry work force were brought up on the
popular plug-and-play, point-and-click technologies
that insulate the underlying technical details from
not only users but support staff as well. They're not
capable of dealing with problems down at the bare metal
layers. Many American companies that need these skills in
their workers have to hire foreign nationals who still
know the stuff because their schools and Universities
can't afford the cutting-edge technologies.

I've written an essay on the subject that's based on my
experiences in the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia,
where I had an opportunity to discuss this very issue
with a Pakistani recruiter and technically-skilled Arab
men who were seeking work in the United Stats. I'll find
it and post it here. 


> It is not an appropriate way to "correct"
> market differences among various products.

Thus allowing illegal monopolies to flourish.


> After all, why stop with Linux?  Why not have affirmative action for the
> Amiga?  Why not require that a certain percentage of state records be
> stored on punch cards or cassette tape?  Don't punch card vendors
> deserve a piece of the pie too?

You're in the coal stokers area now. I'm don't think a
response is needed here.


> > You also said that Open Source will win when applications become
> > mature. You may want to reconsider this.
> 
> I'd amend this to say that Open Source vendors will win when open source
> *marketing* becomes more mature.  Really, most of us are still out there
> talking about technical excellence, failing to notice that few
> purchasing decisions hinge on technical excellence.  

I'll have to agree with you here, but this only reinforces
my argument for affirmative action.

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>

From pundit at teleport.com  Wed May 28 14:01:02 2003
From: pundit at teleport.com (Ken Barber)
Date: Wed May 28 14:01:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Action item: new Open source bill
Message-ID: <200305281358.16297.pundit@teleport.com>

Friends,

Sally at Rep. Barnhart's office says that it's time to "turn our 
tigers loose on the Senate."

An amendment has been proposed to SB 589 to change it from it was 
(an agricultural bill) into an open-source bill.  The language of 
the amended SB 589 is identical to what the amended version of 
HB2892 would have been had it lived.

The Chair of the committee hearing SB589 has consented to doing 
this, but the Senators on that committee need to hear support for 
the idea from their constituents before they're willing to vote 
it out.  Those Senators are:

Rick Metsger, Chair SD 26 (D-Welches) sen.rickmetsger at state.or.us 
Bruce Starr, vice-chair SD 15 (R-Hillsboro, Cornelius)
sen.brucestarr at state.or.us 
Ryan Deckert, SD 14 (D-Beaverton) sen.ryandeckert at state.or.us 
David Nelson, SD 29 (R-Pendleton) sen.davidnelson at state.or.us

We need support from at least three of these four to get the bill 
out of committee.  All four have already heard from Phil Barnhart 
and have a copy of the amendment, with several pieces of 
background material, in hand.  They understand what the bill is 
about and just need to hear from their constituents that there is 
support for it in their districts.

Considering the piece that ran in last Sunday's Oregonian, this is 
an excellent time to call or write to your State Senator about 
amending and passing out SB 589.

Ken Barber
Author, HB 2892

From sandy at herring.org  Wed May 28 17:43:02 2003
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Wed May 28 17:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Setting up pine for out-of-office auto replies
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305280924230.12559-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <20030528092223.A22129@zaphod.axian.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305280924230.12559-100000@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20030529004213.GA11811@kippered.herring.org>

On Wed, 28 May 2003, Rich Shepard wrote: 
> On Wed, 28 May 2003, Alice Corbin wrote:
> 
> > I do this by putting the following in my ~/.forward file:
> > 
> > \ali, "|vacation ali"
> > 
> > This drops the mail into my inbox AND pipes it through the vacation
> > program, which will respond with the message that you've put into
> > ~/.vacation.msg.  Look at the vacation man page for the gory details.
> 
>   Thanks, Ali. First I need to go find the vacation program so I have a man
> page -- and executable -- on the system.
> 
> Rich

Or... you can use Alan Stebbin's ackmail.rc, which I find more powerful than
`vacation'. If you've got procmail, then you need nothing else.
Unfortunately, I was unable to find it on the web just now. But... since I
have it, and it's GPL'd, you can now find it on my web site...

    http://www.herring.org/techie.html#procmail

The comments at the beginning are pretty clear on how to set it up. e.g.,
from my .procmailrc at work, I do this...

###
#Variables used by ackmail.rc
MY_ADDR=Sandy_Herring at adp.com
MY_NAMES="Sandy Herring|sherring|Sandy_Herring"
NOACKFILE=$HOME/vacation.noack
ACKMSG=$HOME/.ack.msg
VACAMSG=$HOME/vacation.msg
FROMSIG="Sandy Herring <Sandy_Herring at adp.com>"
MUA=default

INCLUDERC=$HOME/ackmail.rc


Note that ${NOACKFILE} is a flat file composed of regexps of addresses you
don't want to ack. e.g.

    plug-admin at lists\.pdxlinux\.org
    \.ru
    eudoramail\.com
etc.

To activate it, just create your vacation message ($HOME/vacation.msg in my
case). To deactivate it, rm or rename your vacation message. It builds a
cache of email addresses to whom it's replied and limits the acks to one a
day to each email address.

hth,
Sandy

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Wed May 28 18:03:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] smbmount problems under Redhat 7.3 and newer...
In-Reply-To: <1054142143.22046.6.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <20030529010223.97598.qmail@web40807.mail.yahoo.com>

I'm not sure if this answers your exact question, but
to make it so normal users can smbmount shares, you
need to set the following permissions:

  chmod 4755 /usr/bin/smbmnt
  chmod 4755 /usr/bin/smbumount
  chmod 755 /usr/bin/smbmount

-Scott

>>>>> "Steven" == Steven A Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com> writes:

Steven> I found his insinuations that I somehow had no idea how to
Steven> manage an enterprise Unix farm personally offensive and his
Steven> little rant about a co-worker walking a dog nothing more than
Steven> small minded FUD designed to damage and cause discontent. All
Steven> you had to do is live the same 3 years that I did in the
Steven> middle of dotcom and you would have seen the real meaning of
Steven> waste, those of you that saw this too - you have my deepest
Steven> sympathy. And yes Ed, anytime someone stoops to an SCO class
Steven> unsubstantiated FUD it deserves the sleaze award.

Maybe I missed something, but I read his "dog walking" story as
personal observation specifically countering your claim ("... the fact
that ODOT is already running leaner than any IT shop that I've worked
with in my 20 year career."), rather than attack.  Anyway, from my
reading, it was logically separate from the justification for the
bill.

Steven> I'll be the first one to admit that I may have been harsh on
Steven> Ken and I apologize to all of you that I may have offended in
Steven> being that way but even the friendliest of dogs will bite when
Steven> provoked. As far as the bill and what it appeared to be in the
Steven> beginning, I am certain that it was a lot of effort and I
Steven> have, and will, commend and respect anyone that feels strongly
Steven> enough about this technology to go to that distance, as long
Steven> as it's done with integrity. Unfortunately, that last comment
Steven> about one bad experience at the state which led him to author
Steven> the bill makes me feel like supporting 2892 is supporting
Steven> someones personal vendetta.  

Again, I read the reason for the bill as the twice weekly trips to
Medford and Coquille to fix silly Windows box problems, not the dog
walking episode.

At a macro level, I see no rational legitimate public-interest
justification for opposing this bill as amended.  One argument against
it here seems to be that it won't save any money immediately.  Maybe
not.  But the sooner people start converting _the sooner_ the money
can be saved.  Either in licensing costs or people costs, or more
likely both.  In "net present value" terms for the future cash flow,
that is still a win that gets smaller the longer it is delayed.  That
argues for starting now.  Even if no one gets laid off, there is an
opportunity cost to having IT staff driving to Coquille twice a week,
when they could be working on more productive problems and returning
more public-interest value for the money spent.  And lastly, on the
savings issue, even if there is none in dollar terms, there is the
matter of where the dollars that _are_ spent land: in the wallets of
your neighbor Oregon employees or in the overflowing bank accounts of
Redmond WA and similar locations.

From matt at legalizefreedom.org  Wed May 28 19:56:01 2003
From: matt at legalizefreedom.org (Matt Chorman)
Date: Wed May 28 19:56:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] which distro for compaq notebook...or am I screwed?
In-Reply-To: <3ED505AF.1010406@attbi.com>
References: <3ED39774.19018.1517A18A@localhost> <1054139700.28609.18.camel@apollo.spears.org> <3ED505AF.1010406@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <200305281555.34122.matt@legalizefreedom.org>

I have a P133 with 32M ram laptop (an old Micron Millenia Transport) running 
gentoo - I was lucky enough to have a cluster to compile with this last time, 
but the first time I compiled XFree it took close to 30 hours. It was not 
necessary that I use it during this time, so I did not need it and the 
compile time was not a problem for me.. My windowmanager on this is 
WindowMaker - it is surprisingly quick on this heavy, slow, old (but 
reliable) beast. Speaking of which, anyone have a battery for this model they 
would want to sell? ;-)

One thing that can save you a lot of time with an older system is to use a 
"stage3" install - this basically means you don't bootstrap your system (and 
you use precompiled glibc and gcc for your platform - they are generally 
optimized for each generation of processor.)

There are also precompiled packages available for KDE, Xfree, Gnome, 
OpenOffice.org, etc.. (All the biggies..) 

M

This is exactly why I do what I do. From the inside it's better for me
to be quiet about the bill but when I'm asked for an honest perspective
of where I see open-source deployment costs at this time I am going to
give it up. I understand that folks are free to beat on me for being
honest all they want but I'm not going to sit back and quietly get
kicked. 

<RELATIVELY_NON-OFFENSIVE_RANT>
ODOT IT folks maintain a network of MS products. In the year that I've
been at ODOT my NT workstation has not locked up once (and I'm a heavy
Visio user), the core infrastructure services have been stable as a rock
and I don't remember the last time I dropped a file share (including the
Windows SMB shares that I mount on my 6 Linux systems). You can't
maintain that kind of stability by being lazy idiots, it's simply not
possible. Even though the FUD is not pointed directly at me it's still
wrong to leave any group with a rotten impression of good folks you
don't even know. 

As for me, I work quietly in ODOT's mainframe group (Mr. Barber, you
were curious about where the hell I worked). In addition to the normal
engine count expected for a production z/800, this mainframe contains a
full-on IFL engine that services nothing but z/VM and Linux, it's
capable of concurrently running more Linux servers in that one small
cabinet than we could fit in a data center at about the same cost as 4
Intel rack-mount servers. I commute from Portland to Salem, put in my 9
hours for you and commute home to crack the books and talk to the wife.
I think you might be able to see now why I take offense to folks
grinding their ax with ODOT in an effort to push a political agenda.
</RELATIVELY_NON-OFFENSIVE_RANT>

BTW; If anyone is still interested in technology, I'm struggling a
little bit with our virtual hipersockets interfaces advertising all
zeros for their MAC addresses. It only seems to be picking up zeros to
Linux (/sbin/ifconfig -a) but the hipersockets network seems to see a
MAC for the connected systems. Since it's virtual to z/VM and only used
for Linux servers it's not exposed to the WAN (yet) but the technology
runs about twice as fast as the OSA IO layer so I would love to use it.
Any ideas folks?

Steve Adams
Workaholic Geek

From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Wed May 28 21:05:02 2003
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: Wed May 28 21:05:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Requium for HB 2802
In-Reply-To: <20030529010401.24714.96864.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20030529010401.24714.96864.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <1054182429.1431.147.camel@ida.dylanreinhardt.com>

Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> wrote:
> The specific group
> of people being harmed are those people who have strong
> technical skills but now have difficulty finding work
> because technical knowledge and technical excellence is
> no longer in high demand. 

[ snip ]

> Many American companies that need these skills in
> their workers have to hire foreign nationals who still
> know the stuff because their schools and Universities
> can't afford the cutting-edge technologies.

It's an odd situation, isn't it?  Linux gurus at every corner with "will
grep for food" signs and yet American companies act as though they can't
find qualified tech workers without going outside our borders.

I've had a chance to hear both sides of this seeming paradox.  There is
simultaneously a shortage of work and a shortage of talented workers. 
It's weird, really.

Again, I feel the best explanation is that much of the the open source
talent pool simply isn't offering what the market is looking for. 

The market is not looking for free (as in freedom) nor free (as in
beer).  The market is looking for easy (as in to use) and familiar (as
in brand names). Technical excellence will not carry the day... stronger
focus on human factors in communications and product design will.  

If the state government needs HB 2802 / SB 589 to evaluate software
intelligently, so be it.  I suppose it takes laws to do just about
anything in state government.

But the larger prize of Northwest business IT dollars will not be won by
activism, legislation, nor by technical distinction.  Business (and
jobs) will come around to open source only when we have begun to
communicate clearly and become more focused on effective marketing.

The ball's in our court, really.

Dylan




From griffint at pobox.com  Wed May 28 21:15:02 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Wed May 28 21:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: SDRAM scam?
Message-ID: <200305282114.12566.griffint@pobox.com>

Is this even possible:

Install a 256MB PC100 SDRAM module on a motherboard that supports
256MB PC100 SDRAM modules, and have it only detect 128MB?

I have what pretends to be such a case. My claim is that the modules in
question are not really a 256MB modules despite what the labels say.
The company that sold them to me claims that it's just not the right part
for the particular motherboard. The correct part (surprise) costs nearly
twice as much.

I installed one of the suspect parts in a second PC that has a completely
different motherboard. It also only saw only 128MB. I installed a known
256MB module from the second PC in to the first PC, and it saw 256MB.
This all reinforces my belief that the claimed 256MB modules are really
128MB modules. Technologically speaking, is there a chance in hell my
belief could be wrong?

Terry

From dholcombe at hotmail.com  Wed May 28 21:50:02 2003
From: dholcombe at hotmail.com (Devon Holcombe)
Date: Wed May 28 21:50:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: SDRAM scam?
References: <20030529043959.16DCE8F03@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <BAY2-DAV42bN4TZyabY00000ee5@hotmail.com>

These are likely sdram modules with higher density dram chips. If the
motherboard chipset was designed only to read or be compatible with lower
density dram chips, it will indeed only recognize half the ram when you
insert a module with higher desnity dram chips. Also if one of the dram
chips is bad and your motherboard detects this it may disable half the ram
so as to preserve stability and not access the part of the ram module that
is bad. There are multiple reasons why you could see only 128 megs of a 256
meg chip.

From mikedela at ipns.com  Wed May 28 21:52:02 2003
From: mikedela at ipns.com (Mike De La Mater)

Message-ID: <FXFB61MD8PLKR717197QO53XUKH.3ed59184@miked>

Have you gone through the whole single-sided, double-sided thing? If not, here's 
a quick thumbnail--

There are issues with SS RAM not registering correctly in older boards that were 
designed during the double sided days. Some of the older documentation was 
oblivious to the SS DS issue. You can tell which ones were aware because they 
mention it. If they don't mention it, they're prob not SS compatible.

Mike

Well you see, that makes it all the more suspicious. When you go to their web site,
you can do both forward and reverse lookups. You can search on computer
make/model (or motherboard make/model) and get a listing of the memory modules
that will work. Or you can search on the part number of a memory module and get a
listing of all the computers and motherboards that will take it. But if you enter the
part number of *this* suspect memory module, it doesn't turn up at all. It only
appears on their main listing of available PC100 modules. So it's not clear what the
intended target is for this 256MB module.

So yes. That was going to be my next question to their support staff.

Terry

On Wed, 2003-05-28 at 21:27, Dylan Reinhardt wrote:

> Again, I feel the best explanation is that much of the the open source
> talent pool simply isn't offering what the market is looking for. 
> 
> The market is not looking for free (as in freedom) nor free (as in
> beer).

The phenomenon is not limited to Open Source versus non-Open
Source. In fact, at the time I visited the UAE, Saudi Arabia,
and other countries, Open Source was not mentioned as often
as technical competence in specific disciplines that are not
"sexy" to Americans. For example, assembly language, AC power,
circuit design, robotics, Pascal, cooling (knowledge of Venturi
effects), etc. Many of the firms that need these skills are not
in the computer business directly; for example, telecommunication
firms.

The computer industry seems to have dumbed down the work
force with its emphasis on plug and play, point and click,
abstract away the details attitudes. We're now losing jobs
to those "less fortunate" people who attended schools that
could not afford the latest technologies and had to suffer
through learning the details.

But I'm getting way off topic...

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>

> > With that info we can calculate the size of the module.

> The module part number is conveniently hidden under the "warranty void if
> removed sticker", but the part numbering on the individual chips does hint at
> 256M-bits each (0317LD C256BWP3208-7). The chip maker is LD (?).
> 
> Terry
> 

10 or 15 minutes with Google and I came up blank.  No one seems to know
who 'LD' is.  They certainly aren't a well known manufacturer.  Judging
solely on the part number, I would say that the chip is a 32M x 8.  There
should be 8 devices forming a single bank of 32M x 64.

The Intel info on the 440BX says that the 82443BX C-1 stepping is capable
of supporting 128 Mb chips.  There is no mention of 256 Mb parts.  I think
that if you want 256 MB in a single slot, you will need a "double sided"
(two banks) module.  Even with that, your BIOS will need to have the
appropriate support.

galen

On Wed, 28 May 2003, Terry Griffin wrote:
> Install a 256MB PC100 SDRAM module on a motherboard that supports
> 256MB PC100 SDRAM modules, and have it only detect 128MB?

In addition to all the signle-sided vs dual-sided issues, it IS possible that
the chip is bad: I once had a 256M SDRAM chip which, after one reboot was
detected by the BIOS as 128M chip. I moved it to a different slot, and it
was 256M again, but soon after that it stopped being 256M in any slot (and
in other motherboards too, it was only detected as 128M). As 128M it still
works fine, and memtest86 reports no errors on it.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu May 29 08:24:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu May 29 08:24:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Named update denied
In-Reply-To: <1054183812.20107.320.camel@lana>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305290820490.16576-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 28 May 2003, Jon Jacob wrote:

> I have a log entry that goes something like this:
> 
> client 63.170.214.66#35098: update 'manymoons.net/IN' denied: 27 Time(s)
> 
> I see this a lot and with different numbers about the '#'.  What
> does this mean, and it is something that needs fixing?

The differing numbers following the '#' indicate the source port on 
the client machine.

What's likely happening is that you've got a Win2K or XP machine
that's trying to do dynamic DNS updates. There's a point-and-drool
method for disabling that behavior, but the exact procedure escapes me
just now.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From stever at woo-hoo.com  Thu May 29 08:39:02 2003
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Thu May 29 08:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: SDRAM scam?
In-Reply-To: <200305282114.12566.griffint@pobox.com>
References: <200305282114.12566.griffint@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <46325.207.173.0.68.1054222717.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

> Is this even possible:
> Install a 256MB PC100 SDRAM module on a motherboard that supports
> 256MB PC100 SDRAM modules, and have it only detect 128MB?

YES!


I just recently went to upgrade the memory in my 440BX-chipset
motherboard.  I didn't think it was that old, but then realized I bought
it in 1998!  I had a single 128MB stick which clearly is not enough
nowadays.  I went down to ENU and bought a 256MB PC133 stick and installed
it.  It only said I had 256MB total!  Removing the original said it was
back at 128!  Tried new stick in a VIA chipset motherboard and sure
enough, it read 256MB.
I consulted ENU and he said it was not a single- vs. double-sided issue,
but what he called "high-density" vs "low-density".  Lucky for me they had
what I needed, a 256MB low-density stick (which BTW was double-sided). 
Now the BX board has 384MB of memory, the new 256 and original 128.

See if they will exhchange it for low-density memory, or get a refund
altogether and buy from ENU.  On an unrelated note, this situation is why
I almost always buy locally.  It's much easier to do returns I find and
after shipping it isn't worth saving the few bucks only to wait longer to
receive it.

Regards

list. It has something to do with the changes in architecture that make it
RH9 instead of RH8.1

I'm sorry I don't remember all the technical details. I think it was
something about memory allocation or interrupt handling. RealPlayer8 can't
handle RH9's scheme, but I think there's a kernel compilation option that
will tell your kernel to work in a RP-compatible manner.

Too bad RealNetworks won't provide you the Sourcecode for their player. You
could recompile it instead and enjoy both their fine media player and the
more modern kernel design. You might also check with Real to see if they
have a new binary posted for RH9 users.

Again, I apologize for my vagueness; I've been messing-around with Redmond's
finest software products too much this week.

-djp
http://folding.stanford.edu - the brain you save may be your own!

I'm sorry I didn't post this here sooner.

The Accelerated Learning Center is offering a course
geared to those who want to learn Linux and are also
interested in becoming Linux-certified. If you've
shopped around for certification training, you know
it's expensive. The ALC course is less expensive and
achieves this with a hybrid of classroom time and
self-study.

The course is a 5 day/5 week course. Students meet in
the classroom every Monday (all day) for 5 weeks. On
the remainder of the days each week, students do guided
lab exercises on their own computers at home or at work,
thus reinforcing what they learned in the classroom.
Students have access to the instructor any time via email
and instant messaging.

You can get more information here:

http://panug.org/16

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu May 29 09:12:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)

Subject: [PLUG] Realplayer8
In-Reply-To: <1054214892.8209.14.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On 29 May 2003, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> I just cannot get Realplayer8 to work from a browser or terminal in
> RedHat 9. Nothing happens. Anyone have suggestions?

You'll need the "LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=2.4.1" hack. See

  http://www.redhat.com/docs/manuals/linux/RHL-9-Manual/release-notes/x86/

Search for LD_ASSUME_KERNEL.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

PPC is (probably for you) a different platform. PowerPC chips are the CPUs
in Macintosh and some IBM computers. They operate with different code than
Intel chips.

From raanders at acm.org  Thu May 29 09:32:02 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Thu May 29 09:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Named update denied
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305290820490.16576-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0305290920450.1537-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Thu, 29 May 2003, Paul Heinlein wrote:

> On 28 May 2003, Jon Jacob wrote:
> 
> > I have a log entry that goes something like this:
> > 
> > client 63.170.214.66#35098: update 'manymoons.net/IN' denied: 27 Time(s)
> > 
> What's likely happening is that you've got a Win2K or XP machine
> that's trying to do dynamic DNS updates. There's a point-and-drool
> method for disabling that behavior, but the exact procedure escapes me
> just now.

We just went through this during ALCPress' (Ed Sawicki) DNS Bootcamp.

Briefly:

Start, Settings, Network Connections, (Your) Connection, [Right Click],
Properties, [Select TCP/IP], Properties, Advanced, DNS, (at the bottom of
window) [UnCheck] Register this connection's address in DNS.


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 27 May 2003 09:33:28 -0700
From: Kevin Altis <altis at semi-retired.com>
To: moss at lists.freepan.org
Subject: [Moss]  Reminder: IEEE Speaker -Open Source IP Licensing - What
    You Should Know

=========================================================
INSTITUTE OF ELECTRICAL AND ELECTRONIC ENGINEERS (IEEE) OREGON SECTION
                PACE (PROFESSIONAL ACTIVITIES) MEETING

TOPIC:       Open Source IP Licensing - What You Should Know
SPEAKER:    Marcy L. Edwards, VP & General Counsel, PSC Inc.
DATE:        Thursday, May 29, 2002
TIME:         6:30 PM - 8:00 PM
                 Doors open 6:00PM
LOCATION:  Oregon Graduate Institute(OGI),
                 Wilson Center Main Dining Room
                 See directions below.
COST:        FREE and open to the public
REGISTRATION: http://www.ieee-or.org/events

This PACE meeting of the IEEE Oregon Section will discuss licensing issues
for Open Source intellectual property (IP). This is the follow-on meeting
from our September 2002 meeting on IP Licensing. Attendees should have
attended that meeting or have solid understanding of the framework of
intellectual property legal protections.

Abstract:

IP is the new buzzword for anything designed or created by engineers.
Software, hardware designs, HDL code, specifications, knowledge, etc. are
all types of IP. Open Source is an increasingly popular method to distribute
software to the market. Engineers are leveraging the Open Source concept for
other types of IP, such as HDL cores. But what happens if you use some Open
Source IP in your design? Does that make your entire design subject to Open
Source rules? What if you use some Open Source function in your software -
do you have to reveal all your source code too?

What are the rules of the game? How can you license your IP for best
advantage? What if you want to license IP from someone else for use in your
product? How can you take advantage of Open Source without giving away
everything?

Marcy Edwards will address these and other issues of Open Source IP
licensing in this talk. She has many years of experience with technology
licensing, intellectual property, internet and privacy issues.  Her
presentation will include insights on the following licensing topics:

  .  Nondisclosures
  .  Clear title/ownership/assignment of IP
  .  Assignment/licensing to third parties
  .  Development & Integration with third party products
  .  Implications in the use of Open Source and Linux O/S
  .  The importance of proper licensing
  .  Consequences of improper licensing

Speaker:

Marcy L. Edwards currently serves as V.P. & General Counsel of PSC Inc. PSC
provides innovative data-collection solutions for the retail supply chain
worldwide.  Its range of products includes mobile and wireless data-capture
terminals, warehouse management software, self-checkout systems, and
fixed-position and handheld bar code scanners. Headquartered in Portland,
Oregon, PSC has major manufacturing facilities in Eugene, Oregon, as well as
sales and service offices throughout the Americas, Europe, Asia and
Australia.

Prior to joining PSC almost two years ago, Ms. Edwards founded and ran a
private practice known as TechKnowledge Legal Counsel, LLC. Previous to
having her own practice, she was with the international law firm, LeBoeuf
Lamb Greene & MacRae where she was an integral member of the Intellectual
Property & Internet Practice Group that transitioned to the Preston Gates
Ellis law firm when LeBoeuf left the Portland area.  Ms. Edwards has
practiced law in Oregon and Washington for over 20 years and is very
familiar with Technology Licensing & Transactions, Intellectual Property,
Internet, and Privacy issues at the local, national, and international
levels.  She continues to operate her private practice on a part-time basis
for special clients with PSC's consent.

Ms. Edwards developed her strong background in corporate transactional
matters, technology issues, and the emerging areas of Internet Law and
Privacy law while serving as corporate counsel with Portland-based
technology companies over a period of 10 years.  She served as Analogy,
Inc.'s Corporate Counsel and Corporate Secretary from 1991 until 1998. While
at Analogy, she experienced the growth of a high-tech company from shortly
after the start-up stage through a successful IPO.  Prior to her position
with Analogy, Ms. Edwards was a Corporate Attorney with Mentor Graphics
Corporation for three years where she provided legal support to the
international offices of the corporation and negotiated third party
licensing arrangements.  Ms. Edwards also draws on her litigation and
transactional experience from private practice in the 1980's and her
litigation training with the Washington Attorney General's Office and the
U.S. Department of Justice.

Directions to Oregon Graduate Institute (OGI):

The meeting will be held in the main dining room of the Wilson Clark Center
on the campus of the Oregon Graduate Institute of Science and Technology,
20000 NW Walker Rd., Beaverton, OR 97006  (503) 748-1121. See
http://www.ogi.edu/maps/ for a campus map.

To get to OGI (Oregon Graduate Institute), from Portland, take Highway 26
west, take Exit 64 (185th) and proceed south (left) on 185th. Continue on
185th to Walker Rd. Turn west (right) on Walker Rd. OGI is at the top of the
hill on the left. Turn left onto Von Neumann Drive, parking is available in
the lot. Wilson Center is opposite the parking area.

For further information on the program, contact Ed Perkins at 503-612-9397
or e.perkins at ieee.org

From pundit at teleport.com  Thu May 29 11:49:01 2003
From: pundit at teleport.com (Ken Barber)
Date: Thu May 29 11:49:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [OT] Who is John Galt?
In-Reply-To: <1054182429.1431.147.camel@ida.dylanreinhardt.com>
References: <20030529010401.24714.96864.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> <1054182429.1431.147.camel@ida.dylanreinhardt.com>
Message-ID: <200305291146.56139.pundit@teleport.com>

On Wednesday 28 May 2003 21:27, Dylan Reinhardt wrote:
> Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com> wrote:
> > The specific group
> > of people being harmed are those people who have strong
> > technical skills but now have difficulty finding work
> > because technical knowledge and technical excellence is
> > no longer in high demand.

Amen, Ed.

> Again, I feel the best explanation is that much of the the open
> source talent pool simply isn't offering what the market is
> looking for.
>
> The market is not looking for free (as in freedom) nor free (as
> in beer).  The market is looking for easy (as in to use) and
> familiar (as in brand names). Technical excellence will not
> carry the day... stronger focus on human factors in
> communications and product design will.

Amen, Dylan.

In other words, competence no longer matters.  One's skills, 
knowledge and ability to do a particular job no longer matter.  
What matters is how socially well-connected one is:  who one 
knows, and how well one knows them.

This is the very kind of world that Ayn Rand warned against half a 
century ago in her novels "The Fountainhead" and "Atlas Shrugged" 
and now it's coming to pass in the high-tech sector.

I got into this line of work two decades ago because, among other 
things, it was one of the few remaining fields where excellence 
still mattered -- and I practice excellence in everything I do.

There are certain places (such as a state agency where I once 
worked) where this makes me unpopular.  Sometimes I wonder if 
I'll ever find work again....

<sigh>  Oh, what's the use?  Who is John Galt?

Ken
-- 
"The creator's concern is the conquest of nature.  The parasite's 
concern is the conquest of men."
	-- Ayn Rand, "The Fountainhead"

From pundit at teleport.com  Thu May 29 12:51:02 2003
From: pundit at teleport.com (Ken Barber)
Date: Thu May 29 12:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Yellow Dog Linux on an old-world SCSI Mac
Message-ID: <200305291248.06728.pundit@teleport.com>

After weeks of aggravation, I finally got Yellow Dog 3 to 
successfully start up on a beige PowerMac G3 tower.

I don't know if I should clog up the lists with grisly details, so 
here's a short version:

The problem occurs when installing YDL 3 onto a SCSI drive in a 
Mac with the old-world ROM.  Terrasoft forgot to include SCSI 
drivers in the "BootX" kernel!

It's maddening because the SCSI drivers ARE there in the 
install-time kernel -- but as soon as the install is finished you 
get a kernel panic when the runtime kernel tries to mount the 
drive.

To make a long story short, I installed YellowDog to a temporary 
IDE drive, recompiled the kernel for SCSI support and then copied 
the new kernel onto both the SCSI drive (where YDL had already 
been installed) and the MacOS partition (which is where Linux 
actually boots from if you have an old-world ROM).

More details available to anyone who asks.

Oh yeah, by the way-- since Yellow Dog 3 is just RedHat 8.0 
recompiled for the PPC architecture, it has all of RedHat's bugs, 
including the maddening little RPM bug that RedHat never fixed in 
version 8.

Ken Barber
-- 
"Never attribute to malice that which can be adequately explained 
by stupidity."
	-- Hanlon's Razor (corollary to Occam's Razor)

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu May 29 13:11:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu May 29 13:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Moving Files
In-Reply-To: <12DC2CF9.405@vancleve.com>
References: <12DC2CF9.405@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <868ysph5y4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jason" == Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com> writes:

Jason> How should I do this?  If I use mv now, it fails because the
Jason> directory exists in the new location.  If I use cp, even with
Jason> all the flags that seem appropriate, I get all kinds of errors
Jason> saying it can't create hard links between file x and file y.  I
Jason> don't know why it would want to, because x and y are different
Jason> filenames, so I'm really confused here. rsync would probably do
Jason> it, but I'm working from a rescue system (different shell this
Jason> time) and don't have rsync at my command.

If you've got tar, you can pipe tar-to-tar:

  tar -C <srcdir> -cl . | tar -C <destdir> -xpv

This will stomp on files that you have changed in <destdir> though, so
be careful if that is the case.

On 28 May 2003, Steven A. Adams wrote:
> On Wed, 2003-05-28 at 18:25, Dan Haskell wrote:

> > And yet it's pretty obvious to everyone reading this thread, that you have
> > a personal agenda for opposing the bill. 
> 
> Well, there's a couple of quiet individuals on this list that know
> better. In fact, I had several meetings with a boss or two about
> supporting it even with the "Avoid" language that was originally in
> it. But hey, at the end of the day I still support and deploy Linux
> products in ODOT.

First off, I'm not doubting your Linux creds.

The point was that you said you couldn't support the bill because you
believed it to be part of a "personal agenda", while at the same time you
were acting on a personal agenda of your own. It's pretty clear that you
see the bill as a vendetta against ODOT and it's employees. It also clear
that, to some degree, you take that personally. I'm guessing that is why
you made fifteen postings, in this thread alone, arguing against a *dead*
bill. The end result is you appear to be criticizing others for something
you are doing your self.

Furthermore, you were criticizing the bill based on the intentions of the
author, rather than on the text of the bill. That sort of maneuver
actually hurts your argument more than it helps. Ken's intentions are of
little consequence in this situation - what matters is the content of the
bill. The only time his intentions would become an issue would be if they
were expressed in the proposed law. Unless you can point to a clause that
pointlessly hurts the State, the argument fails.

Please note that none of this is intended to be personal criticism. It is
just my take on that particular argument.

Best of luck on your work at ODOT,
Dan

-------- Original Message --------
Subject: [Ed Foster's GripeLog] The GripeLog Column: "A Defining Moment"
Date: Thu, 29 May 2003 10:00:35 -0700
From: Ed Foster <foster at gripe2ed.com>
To: edfoster at gripe2ed.com

========================================
ED FOSTER'S GRIPELOG
The Reader Advocate Column
========================================

Thursday, May 29, 2003
By Ed Foster

A DEFINING MOMENT


Once all the lawyers have finished having their fun with the SCO vs. IBM
madness, what will they do for an encore? After a long look in my
crystal ball, here's my prediction for the next episode of intellectual
property terrorism:

BELLEVUE, WA, July 15, 2004 -- Semi-Unabridged Webster Corp., publishers
of the Semi-Unabridged Webster Dictionary of 1923, today announced it
has granted a license of English language intellectual property rights
to Microsoft Corporation. The licensing deal makes Microsoft the first
company to ensure its products and services will be in copyright
compliance with the use of English.

"We are very grateful for Microsoft's acknowledgement of our
intellectual property rights and for their support in our efforts to
make English available to all for a reasonable licensing fee," said
Preston Gates Ellis, CEO and General Counsel for the recently-formed
Semi-Unabridged Webster (SUW).  Ellis acknowledged that Microsoft
received a particularly favorable licensing due to its "small
investment" in his company, but declined to provide detailed numbers.

A Microsoft spokesman said the company will not participate in the
lawsuit SUW recently filed against AOL/Time-Warner for copyright
infringement over its use of English in various media properties. "This
move is just representative of Microsoft's commitment to respecting
intellectual property and its healthy exchange through licensing," the
spokesman said.

Ellis reiterated his earlier statements that SUW does not claim to have
intellectual property rights to the entire English language, but that
"crucial words and usages have been appropriated in clear violation of
our rights." He declined to give specific examples of such infringement,
as that might aid in helping the infringers disguise their culpability.
"The best guideline we can offer at this point is that, if you want to
use English, you need a license."

Legal observers have pointed out that other dictionary publishers also
have rights to use the Webster name, but SUW is in a unique position
because its dictionary was published in 1923.  Due to the Sonny Bono
Copyright Term Extension Act, all previous dictionaries have entered
into the public domain, leaving the long out-of-print Semi-Unabridged
Webster tome with priority as the oldest copyrighted lexicon.

SUW Corp., which acquired rights to the dictionary shortly after forming
earlier this year, plans no legal actions against individual users of
English until after its lawsuits with AOL/Time Warner and possibly other
media conglomerates are settled. "We would suggest, however, that
everyone be mindful of today's announcement in that regard," Ellis
added. "At this point, for example, it should be understood that MSN is
the only on-line service that is legally authorized to send or receive
e-mail messages written in English."

Ellis also reacted angrily to critics who've suggested his company is
just a legal stalking horse for Microsoft and not actually a dictionary
publisher. "We are in the dictionary business, and we will prove that by
putting out an update of the 1923 edition in the near future to further
extend our intellectual property rights." He also refuted claims that
SUW is threatening lawsuits only against those who are critical of it or
Microsoft. "We absolutely believe in everyone's right to speak their
mind freely," he stated. "But those who are unwilling to acknowledge of
rights of legitimate copyright holders shouldn't use our language to do so."

  Not only do I agree, but I'd like to point to SQLite, an embedded SQL
engine with features similar to both postgres and MySQL. Read all about it
in the June (2003) Linux Journal and here:
                      <http://www.hwaci.com/sw/sqlite/>

  I decided to use this for my contact manager and accounting system rather
than postgres. Don't ask me why for I do not consciously know. I _do_ know
that I put off these ports for about four years and now I'm burning the
midnight oil to get them done with sqlite. Go figure. It would be great if
more local folks used it so we could have our own support group. :-)

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu May 29 16:15:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu May 29 16:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Storing XML docs in  SQL database on Linux?
In-Reply-To: <62276.66.93.77.251.1054248403.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305291559070.16576-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

The question of storing XML in DB form is interesting to me (I'm in 
the middle of transitioning our technical documentation to DocBook 
using the XML DTD), so I poked around a bit. Here's a nice starting 
point:

* XML Database Products
  http://www.rpbourret.com/xml/XMLDatabaseProds.htm

His data are mostly correct, though one interesting project has been 
updated more recently that his table suggests:

* eXist
  http://exist.sourceforge.net/

This one, an Apache project, also looks interesting:

* Xindice
  http://xml.apache.org/xindice/

FYI: These are both Java-based projects, if that matters to you. They 
also both are based on some API-level work done at the XML::DB 
project: http://www.xmldb.org/

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
