From jeme at brelin.net  Thu May 29 16:44:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu May 29 16:44:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [OT] Who is John Galt?
In-Reply-To: <200305291307.39729.pundit@teleport.com>
References: <20030529010401.24714.96864.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
 <200305291146.56139.pundit@teleport.com> <3ED65CD4.90200@hevanet.com>
 <200305291307.39729.pundit@teleport.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305291513340.21266@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 29 May 2003, Ken Barber wrote:
> On Thursday 29 May 2003 12:17, david pool wrote:
> > Ken Barber wrote:
> > >This is the very kind of world that Ayn Rand warned against
> > > half a century ago in her novels "The Fountainhead" and
> > > "Atlas Shrugged" and now it's coming to pass in the high-tech
> > > sector.

I got the impression that Dylan was discussing the human factor in
software design rather than the human factor in the workplace, i.e.,
intuitive, pleasant interfaces, familiar vendors and support staff, and so
on.

> The real parasites were business executives -- James Taggart, Orren
> Boyle and a host of others -- that didn't want to compete with
> innovators such as Hank Rearden.  So they had their "man in Washington"
> begin taking action at the legislative level.
>
> Government was only doing what it was being pressured to do by
> what (in the real world) might be called "industry lobbyists."
>
> hmmm, it all sounds familiar somehow....

As the great American philosopher John Dewey wrote, "Government is the
shadow cast by business on society."  We see this every day and, more
often than not, it goes by without comment.

The effects of this relationship are even less frequently acknowledged and
almost never recognized.  Clearly, attempts to alter society by reshaping
government are like attempts to push a person around by applying pressure
to their shadow.  Any change that does not address the underlying
relationship will have no long term effect.  If government is going to
carry out the will of the people (and as a public agency -- an agency of
the people, the people's agent -- that is exactly its intended purpose),
it must be independent of business.  If power MUST be consolidated, it
should be consolidated through a willfull and coordinated act of people,
not the accidental or shrewd machinations of a businessman.

> Excellent point.  Maybe there's hope.  I surely would like to find work
> again someday at an organization that values excellence.

Well, there's more to life than efficiency and effectiveness.  I
personally don't think it's a slap in the face of excellent quality of
life to have interests in the workplace beyond the creation and
maintenance of a flawlessly efficient wealth-reaper.

Remember that business, "the market", and the workplace are all systems
designed by human beings with the intent of improving the world and making
life more worth living.  Whenever they make things worse, they are
failing, regardless of the accountant's bottom line.

It seems that lately society has become dedicated to improving the economy
rather than the economy being dedicated to improving society.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin

From plug at dylanreinhardt.com  Thu May 29 16:49:01 2003
From: plug at dylanreinhardt.com (Dylan Reinhardt)
Date: Thu May 29 16:49:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [OT] Who is John Galt?
In-Reply-To: <20030529201102.22306.12483.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20030529201102.22306.12483.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <1054253437.2830.86.camel@ida.dylanreinhardt.com>

Ken Barber <pundit at teleport.com> wrote:
> In other words, competence no longer matters.  One's skills,
> knowledge and ability to do a particular job no longer matter.  
> What matters is how socially well-connected one is:  who one 
> knows, and how well one knows them.

Technical skill still matters and open source has much to be proud of. 
Small victories and tiny steps forward take place every day.  

But I don't buy that the importance of marketing is an indication that
the world is dissolving into a merit-free cesspool. 

The problem is that technology products are evaluated primarily by
people who don't understand the details.  If you provide your customers
with technical excellence, odds are they'll appreciate that to some
extent... but they really won't understand your excellence at anywhere
near the level of detail you practice it.  They have even less hope of
evaluating your excellence prior to using the product.

That's a bit of a catch-22, because it costs a **lot** for people to try
new systems.  Changing systems may not cost a lot of money, but it costs
a lot in terms of the things that actually matter to business:
productivity, predictability, exposure to risk.  

Overcoming this barrier requires far more than technical excellence, it
requires *inspiring confidence*.  Unfortunately for us, such skills are
(at best) orthogonal to technical skills.

Human factors play an enormous role in the conduct of business.  This
may suck, but it seems, in most cases, inescapable.  We may offer the
Reardon Metal of computing, but we just can't expect that the world is
going to notice unless we're prepared to tell our story.


Dylan

From russj at dimstar.net  Thu May 29 17:45:02 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu May 29 17:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] OT: SDRAM scam?
In-Reply-To: <200305282114.12566.griffint@pobox.com>
References: <200305282114.12566.griffint@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <20030530004457.GR23599@sthelens.dimstar.net>

* Terry Griffin <griffint at pobox.com> [2003-05-28 21:15]:
> Is this even possible:
> 
> Install a 256MB PC100 SDRAM module on a motherboard that supports
> 256MB PC100 SDRAM modules, and have it only detect 128MB?

What is most likely happening is you have double density ram in a board
that only supports single density ram. 

There are two PC100 standards. Double density PC100 is not required to
be backward compatible with single density PC100. 

I ran into this exact problem with an Abit and an ASUS mainboard not too
long ago.

Russ Johnson

From pundit at teleport.com  Thu May 29 18:04:01 2003
From: pundit at teleport.com (Ken Barber)
Date: Thu May 29 18:04:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [lug] Yellow Dog Linux on an old-world SCSI Mac
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0305291724530.5031-100000@tpol.peak.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0305291724530.5031-100000@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <200305291758.51176.pundit@teleport.com>

On Thursday 29 May 2003 17:29, Allen Brown wrote:
> On Thu, 29 May 2003, Ken Barber wrote:
> > The problem occurs when installing YDL 3 onto a SCSI drive in
> > a Mac with the old-world ROM.  Terrasoft forgot to include
> > SCSI drivers in the "BootX" kernel!
> >
> > It's maddening because the SCSI drivers ARE there in the
> > install-time kernel -- but as soon as the install is finished
> > you get a kernel panic when the runtime kernel tries to mount
> > the drive.
>
> Did they provide a scsi loadable module with the kernel?  Does
> Yellow Dog boot thru LILO?  

No.  You're thinking Intel architecture here.  There's no LILO, no 
Grub on a dual-boot Mac.

Old-world Macs have to partially boot into MacOS, then use 
something called BootX to load the linux kernel.  Because of 
this, the kernel has to reside on the MacOS partition.

Weird, huh?  This is all new to me.  The last time I used a Mac 
was well before Windoze 3.0 came out.

Ken

I need from a series of lines taken from a 2D cartesian plane to detect
rectangles and verify that none overlap.  Evidently this can be
accomplished via raster scanning.  Any tips on what to put into google
for a search key?

These rectangles, actually any closed polygons are fine, can not overlap
because a laser is going to do a contour.  Lines here is a misnomer, I
going to have a series of points to work with where there is already a
progam to find the polygon a point is connected to.  The explanation I
was given was a series one: polygons from left to right 1 2 3 3 2 1 
valid.  If the polygons are encountered 1232, etc., this is not valid. 
It's an onion approach, one skin cannot go through another.

     --  Michael.

On 29 May 2003, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

> I need from a series of lines taken from a 2D cartesian plane to detect
> rectangles and verify that none overlap.  Evidently this can be
> accomplished via raster scanning.  Any tips on what to put into google
> for a search key?

  Computational geometry.

> These rectangles, actually any closed polygons are fine, can not overlap
> because a laser is going to do a contour.  Lines here is a misnomer, I
> going to have a series of points to work with where there is already a
> progam to find the polygon a point is connected to.  The explanation I
> was given was a series one: polygons from left to right 1 2 3 3 2 1 
> valid.  If the polygons are encountered 1232, etc., this is not valid. 
> It's an onion approach, one skin cannot go through another.

  Convex hulls and search and intersection algorithms. A line sweep
algorithm will do what you want.

Steven, I give you credit for being persistent, but I can't make sense of
your argument with the bill which leads me to suspect your motivations
(sorry, but that is a natural consequence...)

Affirmative Action is a response to an inappropriate balance of power, in
this case the power over the marketplace of computing technologies. Either
you dissagree that there exists an imbalance or your dissagree with the
method for correcting it (or, as it often sounds, you just got caught up
in the personalization of it all). If you disagree with the method, then
you must have another method in mind, which I haven't really heard (aside
from your reference to ODOT's private/silent campaign? why not leverage
the larger hammer to get the job done right?).

Again, not being able to understand your method to get to the goal that
you claim to share with me (i.e., success of OSS, because it is good),
should I just conclude that you believe in "tough love" for OSS instead?
(Note: we agree that the free-market method to achieve the goal falls
apart when monopolies are involved, right?)

From alex at daniloff.com  Thu May 29 19:22:01 2003

Subject: MySQL vs PostgreSQL formerly --> Re: [PLUG] Storing XML docs in SQL database on Linux?
In-Reply-To: =?utf-8?q?

=20=20=20=20?= <62276.66.93.77.251.1054248403.squirrel at webmail.tearitalldown.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Message-Id: <03052919213106.05705 at gate>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Robby,
Let me respectfully disagree with you on PostgreSQL vs MySQL issues.
I've worked with both databases and tested them throughfully in our
engineering environment over two year period. 
Finally our dept. decided to go with MySQL for all our engineering 
applications, data collection and statistical analysis. 
MySQL with InnoDB tables (which are ACID compliant) beats PostgreSQL
in terms of speed, number of simultaneous connections, security and
scalability. All these extended features in PostgreSQL as subqueries, stored 
procedures and such are easily implementable on the API level in Perl.
To pull data of 1,200.000 rows Mysql spends just about 3.5 seconds, 
PostgreSQL spends over 20 seconds on the same hardware.
We have no problem with over 250 simultaneous client connections to MySQL
server and  we had problems with PostgreSQL when number of simultaneous
connections reached just 80 on the same hardware.
MySQL takes a full benefit of RAID0, PostgreSQL doesn't have such an 
optimization. 

Regards.
Alex


On Thursday 29 May 2003 03:46 pm, you wrote:
> Alex,
> I've been a fan of MySQL for a few years, but now I think PostgresSQL is
> much more efficient for business use, not to mention it has more features
> that MySQL doesn't...because they are mainly interested in speed.
>
> You're not going to loose much speed pulling back a largeobject from psql
> as you would pulling back a blob from mysql.
>
> -Robby

On Thu, 29 May 2003, david pool wrote:
> So suppose businesses do that, and design systems that improve the world
> and make life more worth living. Wouldn't it be good if that business
> then helps coordinate people and helps them wield consolidated power?

It's not part of the mandate right now.  There's nothing in it for the
bigwigs.  It requires long-term (like posterity) considerations that are
far beyond most people's decision-making capacity.  That's basically the
reason why consolidated power is a bad thing.  Obviously, it can be used
to actively oppress people and that's bad.  But it is also bad because it
allows for greater effectiveness and efficiency.  If a single person
wielding a single person's power makes a mistake, the repercussions are
usually small and the system can adapt and compensate.  If a mistake is
made with massive amounts of consolidated power, you get premature
extinction, rivers catching fire, poverty, and war.

J.

It's encouraging. We're gaining ground, there's a lot more work to do
but there are a small (but growing) number of us that are dedicated to
making it happen. For example, I just got news this afternoon that
another agency wants to make use of Linux 3270 services starting on the
magic date of July 1. This will allow them to avoid buying the latest
and greatest XP compliant emulator software for all of these users.

All in all it is really interesting. When business units start seeing
that they can run services under Linux on the z/800 they see it through
a totally different set of eyes. They get IO performance and stability
that they see as unsurpassed ( I'm starting to agree with them on that
one ) and centralized configuration management they warm up to the whole
OS change pretty fast. It really is selling itself to some units and I
am sure that more will follow - the decision makers and technologists
really are intelligent people.

Steve

this point, MySQL wasn't a contender because it didn't have
transactions. But now it does and, from what you are saying, it is
significantly faster than PostgreSQL.

part of my app wants transactions (of course). But the other part of my
app is going to be using some linear algebra equations and I would like
my table to be memory resident. Is this practical with the latest
versions of MySQL?

intention is to be driving it off a Java servlet. Do you have any ideas
on how it will perform using JDBC?

On Thursday 29 May 2003 11:32 pm, you wrote:
> Oracle.
>
> >
> > Robby,
> > Let me respectfully disagree with you on PostgreSQL vs MySQL issues.
> > I've worked with both databases and tested them throughfully in our
> > engineering environment over two year period.
> > Finally our dept. decided to go with MySQL for all our engineering
> > applications, data collection and statistical analysis.
> > MySQL with InnoDB tables (which are ACID compliant) beats PostgreSQL
> > in terms of speed, number of simultaneous connections, security and
> > scalability. All these extended features in PostgreSQL as subqueries,
> > stored
> > procedures and such are easily implementable on the API level in Perl.
> > To pull data of 1,200.000 rows Mysql spends just about 3.5 seconds,
> > PostgreSQL spends over 20 seconds on the same hardware.
> > We have no problem with over 250 simultaneous client connections to MySQL
> > server and  we had problems with PostgreSQL when number of simultaneous
> > connections reached just 80 on the same hardware.
> > MySQL takes a full benefit of RAID0, PostgreSQL doesn't have such an
> > optimization.
> >
> > Regards.
> > Alex
> >
> > On Thursday 29 May 2003 03:46 pm, you wrote:

From alex at daniloff.com  Fri May 30 06:41:02 2003
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Fri May 30 06:41:02 2003
Subject: MySQL vs PostgreSQL formerly --> Re: [PLUG] Storing XML docs in SQL database on Linux?
In-Reply-To: <3ED6F0EC.9010307@nutriware.com>
References: <61388.66.93.77.251.1054244486.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com> <200305300221.h4U2LVx05821@gate.daniloff.com> <3ED6F0EC.9010307@nutriware.com>
Message-ID: <03053006402201.06544@gate>

Ron,
MySQL supports some linear algebra equations embedded in queries
which don't require to run subqueries. 
All complicated stuff you can easily implement on the level of API.
MySQL has IHOP table format which resides in memory (RAM), 
though it doesn't support indexing.
We use IHOP tables to create temporary tables when we run complicated
subqueries. 
My personal observation is that if you run subquery, using its API 
implementation in MySQL and IHOP as temporary tables, it runs much faster 
with less overhead that the same subquery entered directly in PostgreSQL. 
Assuming the same amount of data to be pulled and the same hardware.
You can use JDBC with MySQL, but what for?
Perl provides much better API for MySQL than anything else, especially if
you implement it as FCGI over your intranet .

Regards.
Alex


>
> Thank you for this perspective Alex (and Robby, too). I am at a point in
> this project where I must choose between MySQL and PostgreSQL. Up until
> this point, MySQL wasn't a contender because it didn't have
> transactions. But now it does and, from what you are saying, it is
> significantly faster than PostgreSQL.
>
> So a question to you, Alex (and to the assembled masses). The financial
> part of my app wants transactions (of course). But the other part of my
> app is going to be using some linear algebra equations and I would like
> my table to be memory resident. Is this practical with the latest
> versions of MySQL?
>
> Also, I haven't done any "real" programming of MySQL yet, but my
> intention is to be driving it off a Java servlet. Do you have any ideas
> on how it will perform using JDBC?
>

Alex Daniloff wrote:
| Ron,
| MySQL supports some linear algebra equations embedded in queries
| which don't require to run subqueries.

Now that sounds good!

| All complicated stuff you can easily implement on the level of API.
| MySQL has IHOP table format which resides in memory (RAM),
| though it doesn't support indexing.
| We use IHOP tables to create temporary tables when we run complicated
| subqueries.

In my case, indexing would be a waste of resources. The tables that will
be used for the recursive linear algebra equations will be locked in
memory. There are almost 40 columns in a 1000 row table that I will need
to fit into a pattern that will change with each step so that I will
potentially have to go back and modify the previous constraints anywhere
from four to eight times.

| My personal observation is that if you run subquery, using its API
| implementation in MySQL and IHOP as temporary tables, it runs much faster
| with less overhead that the same subquery entered directly in PostgreSQL.
| Assuming the same amount of data to be pulled and the same hardware.

And that is the answer to my big question. So it seems like MySQL is the
appropriate choice for this application.

| You can use JDBC with MySQL, but what for?
| Perl provides much better API for MySQL than anything else, especially if
| you implement it as FCGI over your intranet .

Why use JDBC? Perhaps because the application is written in Java? Not to
start a flame war (I *really* don't want to do that), but I consider
Perl to be a really useful tool for easily solving most sysadmin tasks.
For serious software engineering, where the problem is both large and
highly complex (as in having to use linear algebra for a critical /part/
of the solution), I think that Java is really the only serious
cross-platform contender (which is a fundamental requirement).

So back to the second part of my question: How good is the JDBC support
on Linux for MySQL compared to PostgreSQL?

Peace,
- -Ron

Ron,
I don't want to start flame war ether, but let me point out on 
this fact that Java applications are running differently on different
OS platforms due to differences in its VM implementations.
So Java's cross-platform compatibility is just a mere of definition of
what it is. Perl is also cross-platform compatible as well as a bunch
of other programming languages.
We were trying to use Java for our eng. purposes and finaly dropped
it. Performance wise it's lagged far behind Perl. 
For example, the same application written in Java was starting its VM
on HP-UX for nearly 30 seconds, on Sun Solaris it takes about 12
seconds, on Linux 2.4.x it takes about 7-8 seconds, on NT/2000/XP it
takes from 3-5 seconds. 
Answering your question - JDBC support on Linux for MySQL is very 
good as well as for PostgeSQL. We had no problem with it whatsoever.

Regards.
Alex

On Thu, 2003-05-29 at 08:50, Petcher, Danielx J wrote:
> I could swear I saw this matter discussed a week or three ago on the PLUG
> list. It has something to do with the changes in architecture that make it
> RH9 instead of RH8.1

It has to do with the Threads libraries that RH9 has implemented. The
fix is in the RELEASE-NOTES... 

       If an application does not work properly with NPTL, it can be run
       using the old LinuxThreads implementation by setting the
following
       environment variable:

       LD_ASSUME_KERNEL=<kernel-version>

       The following versions are available:

       - 2.4.1 - Linuxthreads with floating stacks

       - 2.2.5 - Linuxthreads without floating stacks

       NPTL support for all dynamically-linked applications can be
disabled
       by using the following boot-time option:

       nosysinfo

From robby at planetargon.com  Fri May 30 12:33:02 2003
From: robby at planetargon.com (Robby Russell)
Date: Fri May 30 12:33:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [PDXLUG] bind 9.2.x view problems with nslookup externally
In-Reply-To:

References: 
     <64741.66.93.77.251.1054321301.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com>
Message-ID: 
     <64960.66.93.77.251.1054322590.squirrel@webmail.tearitalldown.com>

I think I figured it out:
recursion. seems to work now


view "external" {
        match-clients {
                any;
                };
        recursion yes; //<-------was set to NO

        zone "." {
                type hint;
                file "named.ca";
        };



};

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri May 30 14:42:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri May 30 14:42:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Sort of another xml/sql/php question...
In-Reply-To: <4AE0FBA6-92E2-11D7-883B-003065436BB2@mac.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0305301425061.19118-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Fri, 30 May 2003, Kelly Guimont wrote:

> I have a data set that will be updated (sometimes frequently) and I
> want to separate the content from the page layout as much as
> possible and generate the pages on the fly. It will be served either
> from my OS X machine or the 2k Server machine.
> 
> I kind of figured that XML would be the way to go since I'm familiar
> with HTML already, but I've had people say that XML is lots of work
> and that I should go with some sql/perl/php configuration.

Me, I'd have a hard time keeping a straight face saying that setting 
up an XML system would be "lots" more work than "some sql/perl/php 
configuration."

I would need some more questions answered before giving a considered 
reply:

* Will the data insert/edit/delete interface need to support multiple 
  concurrent users? A 'yes' answer will definitely point to a database 
  solution.

* Do you need easy version control? A 'yes' answer points to XML files 
  in the filesystem.

* Are you well-versed in SQL and client/server stuff? A 'no' answer 
  means the database solution will be hard.

* Do the data need to be type checked at input time (e.g., do you 
  absolutely need to be sure that column 5 contains an integer, not a 
  string?) If so, a RDBMS will do the checking for you.

Other considerations:

* all things considered, data manipulation is easier in an XML file 
  than in a database

* it'd probably take you a lot less time to work up a simple XSLT 
  stylesheet for transforming your XML into HTML than it will to work 
  up an LAMP-ish solution

* if network transparency/availability is an issue, an SQL solution 
  will probably serve you better in the long run

> I don't have anything stored in any format yet, so I'm looking for a
> solution before I get too far into this mess.

As long as the data are parseable, the initial format isn't too much 
of an issue. You're only a Perl script away from reformatting it as 
XML or a set of SQL INSERT clauses...

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

> Steven, I give you credit for being persistent, but I can't make sense of

Persistent I am, always right I am not. My motivations for saying the
things that I did are deduced from experience, looking closely at the
numbers and trying to remember that operating systems are nothing more
than tools to help us work instead of gods to pray too.

> Affirmative Action is a response to an inappropriate balance of power, in
> this case the power over the marketplace of computing technologies. Either
> you dissagree that there exists an imbalance or your dissagree with the
> method for correcting it (or, as it often sounds, you just got caught up
> in the personalization of it all). If you disagree with the method, then
> you must have another method in mind, which I haven't really heard (aside
> from your reference to ODOT's private/silent campaign? why not leverage
> the larger hammer to get the job done right?).

The proper application of Affirmative Action should work well to assist
in ceasing the oppression of a people but I don't believe that it would
apply at all to operating systems or software. The MS bucks are huge
enough that the FTC and Justice Department is willing to look the other
way even with conclusive evidence that they are an illegal, predatory
monopoly. So you see, it's not that I oppose Affirmative Action, I just
oppose the application of Affirmative Action as it relates to
technology. 

Yes, I have a method, my method is to continue to work on deploying real
Linux based solutions as ODOT. This is where I can make a difference
that we will all see in the shortest amount of time. My method has the
blessing of senior ODOT management all the way up. This method has
proved to be successful and is growing in support from within, it would
be great if it enjoyed the same support from the community.

Your correct to assume that I was caught up in the personalization. You
would likely be equally offended if you were in my shoes. The way that I
handled my temper in this instance was immature and unacceptable and I
have since apologized for my outrage and the offense that it may have
caused.

> Again, not being able to understand your method to get to the goal that
> you claim to share with me (i.e., success of OSS, because it is good),
> should I just conclude that you believe in "tough love" for OSS instead?
> (Note: we agree that the free-market method to achieve the goal falls
> apart when monopolies are involved, right?)

Not at all. I have just as much love for computing platforms as I do my
Hitachi hole shooter, I use the tool for what it's good for and am
usually happy with the results. This stuff is not a living, breathing,
biological entity that is worthy of love, in my opinion, it's just
another tool in my toolbox. Do I want to see OSS fail? Of course not, if
that were true I would be working all day and night on z/OS or MVS
instead of putting together Linux solutions for ODOT business units. Do
I want to see Windows fail? Not at all, I would like to see the
management at MS clean up the way that they do business and make the
conscious decision that greed and ruthless domination is not more
important than quality and integrity.


I sincerely hope that this answers your questions. If for some reason
you would like to continue this conversation please feel free to use my
personal e-mail address as I think PLUG has probably grown weary with
this thread.

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri May 30 17:38:01 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri May 30 17:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] [OT] Who is John Galt?
In-Reply-To: <3ED7699D.2020005@hevanet.com>
References: <20030529010401.24714.96864.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
 <200305291146.56139.pundit@teleport.com> <3ED65CD4.90200@hevanet.com>
 <200305291307.39729.pundit@teleport.com> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305291513340.21266@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <3ED6A045.4030606@hevanet.com> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305292036590.24787@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <3ED7699D.2020005@hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305301229500.4125@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 30 May 2003, david pool wrote:
> So we wouldn't want systems that are designed to improve the world to
> have greater effectiveness and efficiency? Because there's some strictly
> deterministic cosmic law that ties consolidation of power to burning
> rivers?

Increased effectiveness and efficiency magnify unwanted effects as much as
expected benefits.  There is a strictly deterministic "cosmic law" (called
cause and effect) that ties massive effort with massive impact.
Consolidated power and wealth means narrower focus of effort and
decision-making.

We are not always right.  We have to stop acting like we are.
We make mistakes.  We have to stop acting like we don't.
We do not know everything.  We have to stop acting like we do.

What makes anybody think they know how to repair an ecosystem?  What makes
anybody think they know how to build a functioning society?  What makes
anybody think they know how to make others' lives better?

There are known and unknown effects of all of our actions and the more
effective and efficient we are at taking action, the more efficiently we
will produce those unknown effects (right along with the known ones).  We
can make plastics fairly efficiently.  That means we are efficiently
producing waste that is not food.  We can efficiently move cars and trucks
on freeways.  That means we are efficiently destroying local economies and
small town (as well as merely regional) culture.

Better to decentralize, break up power, and distribute wealth so that when
something goes wrong, the effects are localized in time and space.  There
is time to learn and space to contain the problem.

> I guess I'm not talking about mandates for far off bigwigs. I'm talking
> about "us". I'm talking about improving the world ourselves.

You're talking about influencing bigwigs or becoming bigwigs.

> It's kinda like the distinction between grousing about politics as
> opposed to writing a bill like SB 589 and shepherding it through the
> legislature.

So you want to use the coercive force of consolidated state power to
impose your agenda on the public.

That's not a value judgment, by the way.  It's a statement of fact.  The
value judgment comes later when we see the effects.  History makes the
value judgments.

> We can start and run businesses that value long-term considerations. If
> we do it well, we'll show people a better way - which I believe is more
> convincing to most people than rhetoric and exhortations.

The problem here is that you must play by the rules of the game developed
and refined by entrenched power.

First, you'll have to compete with the profiteers.  Profit-making is
two-fold destructive (at least).  It consolidates wealth by short-changing
labor and/or abusing public resources (the air, water, land, etc.) and it
provides a reserve operating budget unrelated to income with which one can
undermine market competition itself (a single firm operating in multiple
industries or vertical markets of one industry has this same second
effect).

Second, you have to find a way to pretend to be privately operated while
being publicly funded.  This is perhaps the least understood aspect of
industrial capitalism.  It's simply not possible for an organization to
operate at national or international scale without massive state support
in the form of tax exemptions, subsidized loans, state enforced
monopolies, and government contracts.  All of these are methods of using
public resources to prop up private power.  The entire modern American
economy is based on finding new ways to directly convert public funds into
private wealth.  Here is one area were efficiency is exactly what you do
NOT want.  The less efficiently that system operates, the more people can
benefit.

Third, even if you don't compete up-front, you will eventually have to
compete on the back end.  You may attempt to operate in a market currently
untouched by profiteers and operate at a low margin or as a co-op of some
sort.  This is the usual way of side-stepping problem one.  You may also
choose to operate at an appropriate scale that doesn't necessarily require
state subsidy (local or regional).  This set of choices significantly
decreases your ability to impact the greater world.  Operating at low or
no profit marginalizes you socially and means you won't be taken seriously
by the entrenched power and the society that it must indoctrinate to its
values in order to prevent active revolt.  Limiting your scope and scale
obviously limits the number of people with whom you can have direct
contact.  And as soon as you prove that people WANT what you offer (that
is to say, as soon as you create the market), the profiteers will swarm in
and defeat you with their existing structures of power and wealth and
operate more successfully in the industrial capitalist mode since they are
unhindered by your ideals and long-term considerations.

Lastly, your long-term considerations are never long enough or well-enough
considered.  You will find that you are wrong about some things.  If you
had been successful in achieving your original goals, you will also have
been successful in inflicting unintended harm (in addition to whatever
harm you may have intended).  This, of course, is a best-case scenario and
assumes triumph over the first three insurmountable challenges.

I'm not saying that real change is a hopeless cause.  I'm saying that real
change that doesn't also change the nature of our society and economy
(modern industrial state-capitalism) is hopeless, delusional, and
wrong-headed.

The problem throughout history has been that you cannot fight entrenched
power without destroying the base of that power completely BEFORE the
revolt.  However, this means completely undermining and dissolving the
basic ideals and structure of a society which leaves the people extremely
vulnerable to exploitation.  The russian revolution is a great example.
The people fought to get a change that they knew they wanted, but they
didn't have the deep knowledge and education required to build a new
society from scratch.  They needed leaders whom they could trust
implicitly since they were not capable of understanding what needed to
happen to get what they wanted.  So they get Stalin.  Stalin was just a
power-monger who wanted the implicit trust but really shared none of the
ideals of brotherhood and prosperity that the russian people expected of
their leaders.  The american revolution is another great example.
Absolutely nothing was done to modify the base of power and wealth in this
land (sympathetically, "this land", though it's thousands of miles away)
and so the revolution had really no effect in making the people more free
or happy, except for the ruling elite who were already the most free and
most able to pursue happiness.  The ideals of liberte, egalite, fraternite
that fueled the revolutions of the enlightenment period were only part of
the propaganda in the american revolution, whereas they were part of the
ideals of the leaders in the french revolution (and they ended up with
Napoleon, who, like Stalin, just took advantage of a nation in disarray).

The solution is clearly to slowly transition and move people in a new
direction rather than attempt to overthrow the power all at once.  We can
undermine the entrenched power by teaching new ideals and developing a
parallel system that doesn't have the same flaws as the system we hope to
replace (it will have different flaws, surely, but hopefully on a
manageable scale).

Free Software is a great tool because it works against many problematic
aspects of our society simultaneously.

Free Software obviously contradicts current ideas about the so-called
"intellectual property".  I think we all understand that part pretty well.
But another important effect of this is the undermining of the general
concept of property and economics itself.  Economics is the science of
scarcity and software (at least in its distribution and availability) is
not a naturally scarce commodity.  It is abundant.  There are as many
copies of Windows as the world could ever need.  The very fact that we
refer to every instance of a piece of software as a "copy" shows that
there is no original and therefore no economic value in the supply/demand
sense.  The entrenched power is fighting against this realization with all
kinds of methods from generational degradation (SCMS, etc.) to binding the
software to a physical device (key dongles, etc.).  Obviously, these are
crippling technologies tacked on and independent of the actual function of
the software or data.

Since there is and always will be demand for software (and, indeed, all
forms of human expression and invention) not yet devised, Free Software is
able to shift the focus of value from the product to the producer.
People are more important than things (or, in this case, functional
abstract expressions).  Perhaps more fascinating here is the notion of
competition _within a cooperative framework_.  Free Software allows
individual packages to compete for "market share" and individual
programmers and project leaders to compete for prestige and honor while
still, ultimately, operating in a cooperative environment where work can
be freely incorporated from any source to produce the most good for the
most people.  This is really the ideal environment for human beings to
excel.  The notion that cooperation and competition are the same force in
opposite directions (sometimes this appeared to be Rand's thesis) is
absurd and forces a choice that does not have to be made.  We can be
individualists in a collective context.  The forces of competition and
cooperation are orthogonal, but with the strange relationship that when
they are not equally balanced, they tend to destroy one another:  too much
competition and the entire purpose of civilization gets lost, we appear to
value nothing but the law of the jungle; too much collectivism and the
entire purpose of living gets lost, we lose our sense of self.  But when
the forces are in balance, the individual and the civilization can
flourish.

The GPL is called a "copyleft" because it, in the words of Stallman,
"turns copyright against itself."  Most people just think of this in terms
of being freely commercially distributable whereas copyrighted works have,
of late, been burdened with royalties and licensing agreements.  While
this is all true, it really has nothing to do with turning copyright
against itself.  Copyright is a state program which uses coercive power
(fines, jail time, and in some cases corporal or capital punishment) to
enforce the monopoly of a private party against the public.  Copyleft uses
this same state program of coersion to protect the public against any
private party that might try to hide away that which is not theirs to
hide.  Shockingly, a copyleft uses public funds and ostensibly
democraticly supported power to directly benefit the public: a strange
reversal in these strange times.

To be frank, the "information economy" was a joke from the beginning and
as soon as the capitalists realized this, they started to recoil in fear
and revulsion.  Everything associated with the internet and information
ecology is tainted with democratizing force and enlightenment ideals.  If
there weren't so many capitalists in the business of computing, I think
the rest of the business world would be backing out of the whole deal.  I
really doubt IT departments pay for themselves.  It's all just added
complexity and cost without commensurate profit-making value.  We're kind
of lucky they're stuck with it, though.  I believe that the internet (and
the things it allows to grow) is our best hope for subverting the powers
that be.

Let's just hope that we have the fore-knowledge, wisdom, and strength to
keep other methods for consolidating power and wealth from sprouting from
the severed neck of state capitalism.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

On Fri, 2003-05-30 at 19:00, Eric Harrison wrote:

There are currently 457 people subscribed to the PLUG list.

The last time I checked the Linux in Schools Mailing list, which is
an off-shoot of PLUG, it had ~900 subscribers (the "show subscribers"
function just broke, I don't the exact numbers at this moment: last
figure I have is 898).

The amount of communication between schools is quadrupling per year,
on a local, national, and international level. The communication
between schools and other government agencies is expanding quickly as
well. There is a huge amount of momentum behind the scenes.


BTW, these bits are traveling over ODOT-owned assets. My employer, MESD,
the City of Portland, and just about every other government entity in
Multnomah County formed a partnership a couple of years ago. City of
Portland's relationship with ODOT was leveraged to utilize ODOT fiber
assets to connect MESD to Portland, which in turn connects to Mount
Hood Cable Regulatory Commission funded fiber assets which connects to
the Oregon Public Education Network backbone router at the Pittock Block.

Leveraging open source software is only one aspect of what government
agencies can do to save tax-payer money and provide better serivce.
Trust, communication, and accountability of government agencies is a 
wonderful thing, especially when it can be done from within.

From ron at nutriware.com  Sat May 31 11:51:02 2003
From: ron at nutriware.com (Ron Braithwaite)
Date: Sat May 31 11:51:02 2003
Subject: MySQL vs PostgreSQL formerly --> Re: [PLUG] Storing XML docs
 in SQL database on Linux?
In-Reply-To: <200305301632.h4UGWl506875@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200305301632.h4UGWl506875@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <3ED8F94F.7020008@nutriware.com>

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Alex Daniloff wrote:
| Ron,
| I don't want to start flame war ether, but let me point out on
| this fact that Java applications are running differently on different
| OS platforms due to differences in its VM implementations.
| So Java's cross-platform compatibility is just a mere of definition of
| what it is. Perl is also cross-platform compatible as well as a bunch
| of other programming languages.
| We were trying to use Java for our eng. purposes and finaly dropped
| it. Performance wise it's lagged far behind Perl.
| For example, the same application written in Java was starting its VM
| on HP-UX for nearly 30 seconds, on Sun Solaris it takes about 12
| seconds, on Linux 2.4.x it takes about 7-8 seconds, on NT/2000/XP it
| takes from 3-5 seconds.
| Answering your question - JDBC support on Linux for MySQL is very
| good as well as for PostgeSQL. We had no problem with it whatsoever.
|
| Regards.
| Alex

First off, thanks for reassuring me on JDBC.

When you talk about Java apps running differently on different OS
platforms, you are (I'm pretty sure) talking about one specific area of
Java that I tend to: the user interface.

In Java, the bits are stored in files in one way. I don't have to worry
about big/little endian and so on. Stuff that really is different (such
as the exact syntax of some SQL strings), can be isolated in a variety
of ways. For instance, resource bundles can hold the stuff that is often
different.

Application performance is definitely relative from platform to
platform, based on a variety of factors. However, there are techniques
that can dramatically improve the startup time of an application. I have
a patent pending (that I share with Mark Hanley) on how to dramatically
speed up the startup performance of an interpreted or intermediate-coded
applications. (Incidentally, I do NOT approve of the philosophy behind
patents and copyrights - it was just a condition of employment at a
former employer). At any rate, since this application is going to
running under Tomcat, most of the overhead involved in instantiating the
JVM is missing.

And this brings us to the final point about *my* preference for Java
over Perl. And that is syntax. I very much like Java's syntax and I very
much dislike Perl's. This point of view is a personal thing, but
something I am very willing to defend. But over beer and not on this
list and not at the risk of starting some sort of flame war.

Language preferences are very personal things. Our choices about what
sort of tools we gravitate towards have more to do with how we approach
problem solving than about any real virtue or limitation of the tools
themselves.

I learned two languages in 1980: Forth and C. There was much about C
that I admired (and still do), but it was a compiled language. There was
this intermediation of the compiler and the performance that made
possible and the immediacy of the interpreter and the expressiveness of
absolute extensibility.

So why did I prefer Forth? It was because I was (and still am) an
assembly language programmer at heart (I've done assembler on over 40
different processor families). When I gave a paper at the Trenton
Computer Faire (the East Coast equivalent to the West Coast Computer
Faire in SFO), I described Forth as: An extensible macro assembler for a
stack oriented pseudomachine.

So it was the fact that I genuinely grock how a processor works that led
me to prefer Forth over C. So much so that I was the Document Editor for
the first three years of the ANSI Forth Technical Committee.

But at the same time, there was this fundamental problem with Forth. My
heresy that Forth was not the ultimate tool for every problem. Even
though we had this wonderful extensibility and Forth is /capable/ of
being used as an object oriented language (I presented my first paper on
Object Oreiented Programming at the Asilomar FORML conference in 1983),
it is all too easy to violate those OO principles and end up biting
yourself in the butt. Forth really doesn't scale very well.

Either late in 1985 or early in 1986, a good friend down in Sun Labs
told me about an interesting new language called Oak and signed me up on
the list for that. I got really excited about that language on reading
its spec and followed the discussion. I wrote a crude benchmark program
from the language spec and within a couple of hours of the first alpha
release of the language, I had it running - perhaps the first running
program on Java outside of Sun Labs (beyond Hello World - there were
several who beat me on that one).

I like Java. It is a truely high level, object oriented language. The
advantages of C++ are so overwhelming, I shudder every time I have to go
back and use what is merely a pre-processor for a 30 year old systems
programming language. C++ is butt ugly, in my opinion.

But that preference for Java over C++ has far more to do with me than
with the virtues of either language. And that aesthetic advantage is
more in my eyes than in any objective analysis (up to a point).

But I was ranting about Perl, not C++ or Forth.

My problem with Perl is actually, my problem with C++, only more so. The
absolute unesthetic code that is produced in Perl drives me mad. The way
there are so *many* different ways to do the same thing and the
undisciplined way of jumping out of the middle of one routine or into
the middle of another just has me pulling my hair out at times.

Mind you, I have written quite a bit of code in Perl. I've done lots of
database stuff and if I have a problem that requires any heavy input
parsing, Perl is the first thing I reach for.

But, just like Forth, Perl doesn't scale. I cannot imagine a project
where 15-20 programmers share a Perl code base. I cannot imagine a
project with a million lines of Perl code.

Not to say they don't exist. Forth has been used in a couple of very
large scale projects, too. But they are most definitely the exception.

But in the final analysis, it is my personality that causes me to prefer
Java to Perl. Just as it is your personality that causes you to prefer Perl.

We can disagree based on our preferences, while still respecting each
other's abilities. The mark of an adult is the ability to disagree
without disparaging the other's choice.

Sorry about the long diatribe, but I just got on a roll.

Peace,
- -Ron

On Friday 30 May 2003 16:26, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Fri, 30 May 2003, david pool wrote:
> > So we wouldn't want systems that are designed to improve the
> > world to have greater effectiveness and efficiency? Because
> > there's some strictly deterministic cosmic law that ties
> > consolidation of power to burning rivers?
>
> Increased effectiveness and efficiency magnify unwanted effects
> as much as expected benefits.  There is a strictly
> deterministic "cosmic law" (called cause and effect) that ties
> massive effort with massive impact. Consolidated power and
> wealth means narrower focus of effort and decision-making.
>
> We are not always right.  We have to stop acting like we are.
> We make mistakes.  We have to stop acting like we don't.
> We do not know everything.  We have to stop acting like we do.
>
> What makes anybody think they know how to repair an ecosystem? 
> What makes anybody think they know how to build a functioning
> society?  What makes anybody think they know how to make
> others' lives better?
>
> There are known and unknown effects of all of our actions and
> the more effective and efficient we are at taking action, the
> more efficiently we will produce those unknown effects (right
> along with the known ones).  We can make plastics fairly
> efficiently.  That means we are efficiently producing waste
> that is not food.  We can efficiently move cars and trucks on
> freeways.  That means we are efficiently destroying local
> economies and small town (as well as merely regional) culture.
>
> Better to decentralize, break up power, and distribute wealth
> so that when something goes wrong, the effects are localized in
> time and space.  There is time to learn and space to contain
> the problem.
>
> > I guess I'm not talking about mandates for far off bigwigs.
> > I'm talking about "us". I'm talking about improving the world
> > ourselves.
>
> You're talking about influencing bigwigs or becoming bigwigs.
>
> > It's kinda like the distinction between grousing about
> > politics as opposed to writing a bill like SB 589 and
> > shepherding it through the legislature.
>
> So you want to use the coercive force of consolidated state
> power to impose your agenda on the public.
>
> That's not a value judgment, by the way.  It's a statement of
> fact.  The value judgment comes later when we see the effects. 
> History makes the value judgments.
>
> > We can start and run businesses that value long-term
> > considerations. If we do it well, we'll show people a better
> > way - which I believe is more convincing to most people than
> > rhetoric and exhortations.
>
> The problem here is that you must play by the rules of the game
> developed and refined by entrenched power.
>
> First, you'll have to compete with the profiteers. 
> Profit-making is two-fold destructive (at least).  It
> consolidates wealth by short-changing labor and/or abusing
> public resources (the air, water, land, etc.) and it provides a
> reserve operating budget unrelated to income with which one can
> undermine market competition itself (a single firm operating in
> multiple industries or vertical markets of one industry has
> this same second effect).
>
> Second, you have to find a way to pretend to be privately
> operated while being publicly funded.  This is perhaps the
> least understood aspect of industrial capitalism.  It's simply
> not possible for an organization to operate at national or
> international scale without massive state support in the form
> of tax exemptions, subsidized loans, state enforced monopolies,
> and government contracts.  All of these are methods of using
> public resources to prop up private power.  The entire modern
> American economy is based on finding new ways to directly
> convert public funds into private wealth.  Here is one area
> were efficiency is exactly what you do NOT want.  The less
> efficiently that system operates, the more people can benefit.
>
> Third, even if you don't compete up-front, you will eventually
> have to compete on the back end.  You may attempt to operate in
> a market currently untouched by profiteers and operate at a low
> margin or as a co-op of some sort.  This is the usual way of
> side-stepping problem one.  You may also choose to operate at
> an appropriate scale that doesn't necessarily require state
> subsidy (local or regional).  This set of choices significantly
> decreases your ability to impact the greater world.  Operating
> at low or no profit marginalizes you socially and means you
> won't be taken seriously by the entrenched power and the
> society that it must indoctrinate to its values in order to
> prevent active revolt.  Limiting your scope and scale obviously
> limits the number of people with whom you can have direct
> contact.  And as soon as you prove that people WANT what you
> offer (that is to say, as soon as you create the market), the
> profiteers will swarm in and defeat you with their existing
> structures of power and wealth and operate more successfully in
> the industrial capitalist mode since they are unhindered by
> your ideals and long-term considerations.
>
> Lastly, your long-term considerations are never long enough or
> well-enough considered.  You will find that you are wrong about
> some things.  If you had been successful in achieving your
> original goals, you will also have been successful in
> inflicting unintended harm (in addition to whatever harm you
> may have intended).  This, of course, is a best-case scenario
> and assumes triumph over the first three insurmountable
> challenges.
>
> I'm not saying that real change is a hopeless cause.  I'm
> saying that real change that doesn't also change the nature of
> our society and economy (modern industrial state-capitalism) is
> hopeless, delusional, and wrong-headed.
>
> The problem throughout history has been that you cannot fight
> entrenched power without destroying the base of that power
> completely BEFORE the revolt.  However, this means completely
> undermining and dissolving the basic ideals and structure of a
> society which leaves the people extremely vulnerable to
> exploitation.  The russian revolution is a great example. The
> people fought to get a change that they knew they wanted, but
> they didn't have the deep knowledge and education required to
> build a new society from scratch.  They needed leaders whom
> they could trust implicitly since they were not capable of
> understanding what needed to happen to get what they wanted. 
> So they get Stalin.  Stalin was just a power-monger who wanted
> the implicit trust but really shared none of the ideals of
> brotherhood and prosperity that the russian people expected of
> their leaders.  The american revolution is another great
> example. Absolutely nothing was done to modify the base of
> power and wealth in this land (sympathetically, "this land",
> though it's thousands of miles away) and so the revolution had
> really no effect in making the people more free or happy,
> except for the ruling elite who were already the most free and
> most able to pursue happiness.  The ideals of liberte, egalite,
> fraternite that fueled the revolutions of the enlightenment
> period were only part of the propaganda in the american
> revolution, whereas they were part of the ideals of the leaders
> in the french revolution (and they ended up with Napoleon, who,
> like Stalin, just took advantage of a nation in disarray).
>
> The solution is clearly to slowly transition and move people in
> a new direction rather than attempt to overthrow the power all
> at once.  We can undermine the entrenched power by teaching new
> ideals and developing a parallel system that doesn't have the
> same flaws as the system we hope to replace (it will have
> different flaws, surely, but hopefully on a manageable scale).
>
> Free Software is a great tool because it works against many
> problematic aspects of our society simultaneously.
>
> Free Software obviously contradicts current ideas about the
> so-called "intellectual property".  I think we all understand
> that part pretty well. But another important effect of this is
> the undermining of the general concept of property and
> economics itself.  Economics is the science of scarcity and
> software (at least in its distribution and availability) is not
> a naturally scarce commodity.  It is abundant.  There are as
> many copies of Windows as the world could ever need.  The very
> fact that we refer to every instance of a piece of software as
> a "copy" shows that there is no original and therefore no
> economic value in the supply/demand sense.  The entrenched
> power is fighting against this realization with all kinds of
> methods from generational degradation (SCMS, etc.) to binding
> the software to a physical device (key dongles, etc.). 
> Obviously, these are crippling technologies tacked on and
> independent of the actual function of the software or data.
>
> Since there is and always will be demand for software (and,
> indeed, all forms of human expression and invention) not yet
> devised, Free Software is able to shift the focus of value from
> the product to the producer. People are more important than
> things (or, in this case, functional abstract expressions). 
> Perhaps more fascinating here is the notion of competition
> _within a cooperative framework_.  Free Software allows
> individual packages to compete for "market share" and
> individual programmers and project leaders to compete for
> prestige and honor while still, ultimately, operating in a
> cooperative environment where work can be freely incorporated
> from any source to produce the most good for the most people. 
> This is really the ideal environment for human beings to excel.
>  The notion that cooperation and competition are the same force
> in opposite directions (sometimes this appeared to be Rand's
> thesis) is absurd and forces a choice that does not have to be
> made.  We can be individualists in a collective context.  The
> forces of competition and cooperation are orthogonal, but with
> the strange relationship that when they are not equally
> balanced, they tend to destroy one another:  too much
> competition and the entire purpose of civilization gets lost,
> we appear to value nothing but the law of the jungle; too much
> collectivism and the entire purpose of living gets lost, we
> lose our sense of self.  But when the forces are in balance,
> the individual and the civilization can flourish.
>
> The GPL is called a "copyleft" because it, in the words of
> Stallman, "turns copyright against itself."  Most people just
> think of this in terms of being freely commercially
> distributable whereas copyrighted works have, of late, been
> burdened with royalties and licensing agreements.  While this
> is all true, it really has nothing to do with turning copyright
> against itself.  Copyright is a state program which uses
> coercive power (fines, jail time, and in some cases corporal or
> capital punishment) to enforce the monopoly of a private party
> against the public.  Copyleft uses this same state program of
> coersion to protect the public against any private party that
> might try to hide away that which is not theirs to hide. 
> Shockingly, a copyleft uses public funds and ostensibly
> democraticly supported power to directly benefit the public: a
> strange reversal in these strange times.
>
> To be frank, the "information economy" was a joke from the
> beginning and as soon as the capitalists realized this, they
> started to recoil in fear and revulsion.  Everything associated
> with the internet and information ecology is tainted with
> democratizing force and enlightenment ideals.  If there weren't
> so many capitalists in the business of computing, I think the
> rest of the business world would be backing out of the whole
> deal.  I really doubt IT departments pay for themselves.  It's
> all just added complexity and cost without commensurate
> profit-making value.  We're kind of lucky they're stuck with
> it, though.  I believe that the internet (and the things it
> allows to grow) is our best hope for subverting the powers that
> be.
>
> Let's just hope that we have the fore-knowledge, wisdom, and
> strength to keep other methods for consolidating power and
> wealth from sprouting from the severed neck of state
> capitalism.
>
> J.

parents [should be] required to use contraceptive chemicals, the 
government issuing antidotes to citizens chosen for 
childbearing."
	--David Brower, Friends of the Earth

However, that doesn't mean I agree that the discussion has been subverted,
that the topic is "radical Left-wing Fear, Uncertainty and Doubt", or that
that is the polar opposite of Objectivism.

Really what I was writing about was anti-fascism, libertarian anarchism,
and social libertarianism.  The polar opposite would be state capitalism,
which, in my opinion, is not what the Objectivists claim is their goal.

If you really believe that what I wrote is the opposite of Objectivism,
then you believe that Objectivism promotes large consolidations of power
(be they state or private power) to crush attempts by individuals and
small groups without wealth and power to establish their own identity and
give shape to their lives and communities.  Really, that's all I wrote
against.

I welcome it. Or you can just continue to label and dismiss without
understanding.

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat May 31 13:51:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sat May 31 13:51:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] httpS vs http
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSU.4.21.0305311311300.11391-100000@garcia.efn.org>
References: <Pine.GSU.4.21.0305311311300.11391-100000@garcia.efn.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0305311342490.20190@shaft.bitmine.net>

I could be way wrong on this, but I'll give you my understanding.

On Sat, 31 May 2003, James wrote:
> Today I wiped out my Vhost file and started over.. I think I might have
> done something right this time because I am now able to access at least
> one of the virtuals (the main domain name), but ONLY if I use https://
> instead of http://
>
> I know this is because I have an SSL-enabled server port, but I haven't
> had this problem with my other server (probably because it isn't SSL
> enabled) so I am not familiar with this.  Will there be problems for
> people trying to access my virtual servers if they don't type https:// ?
>
> It seems like it should automatically jump to https:// if someone tries to
> visit my site with http://

Your web server is listening on the HTTPS port 443.  If the user's client
requests http, it's going to use the standard port 80.

Run `netstat -an` to see if you have anything at all listening on port 80.
(You can also do `netstat -an|grep :80` or `netstat -a|grep www`... it
really depends on how your ports are aliased in your /etc/services file)

I don't know about Mandrake packages or how they're put together (they're
just RPMs, I know, but I don't know about how those things are distributed
these days), but in Debian there's several different apache packages
including a separate apache-ssl package that is set to listen on port 443.
When I want a domain to have https and http, I run TWO apache servers
(apache-ssl and apache-perl, usually) with the same virtual host
configuration and use redirects on the http server for ssl pages and vice
versa (with some caveats that may or may not matter here).

Anyway, get a listener on port 80 to send attempts at your secure pages to
the secure server.

J.
